Strong bourbon, vanilla, caramel, and toffee flavors with a bold and full mouth feel.
36cl, exclusive American brew, thx to kraddel!, complex Scotch, malty/woody and slightly smoked/alcoholic, yet not too heavy, balanced, hazy, nearly no head, good brew

bottle , my ( way to small) share with bobochamp . 
got it as an extra from a VERY good trader. ive had the pleasure to trade with many good guys lately, so i kinda forgot who i got this from. if YOU read this, and are the sender, please tell me, ill add your name. till than, big thanx to mr X 

pours clear brown, small , fast fading foam (white) 
smell is pure bourbon. low carbo , bourbon taste . still ok ( not overwhelming) but i dont taste much else than bourbon.. its ok, could be worse...

Wow! On tap at meridian pint in DC.  Aroma is burbon, alchohol, sweet cheeries and hops.  Pours a dark ruby red.  Palate is a sweet hoppy delicous fruitcake of a beer!  Scotch and oak come through on rhe lingering palate.  Fantastic Brew!

350 ml bottle from czar, also shared with albatross. Pours a ruby reddish brown with a nice beige head. Aroma is wood, vanilla and brown sugar. Flavor is sweet, caramel-toffee, vanilla, wood, brown sugar, more caramel. Very flavorful. Finish is mostly fruity (red and darker berries), with a touch of vanilla. Strangely enough, it is quite soft and...accessible! Medium body, mellow mouthfeel, very good!
Very nice Barrel notes, vanilla and bourbon smooth out the base beer and almost give it a hint of creaminess. Maltiness is still present. One of my favorite BA beers.

Backlog rating 1-23-2008 (Bottle) This beer pours a small tan head with poor retention, no lacing and an orange-brown hue.  The Aroma is malty, bourbon, brown sugar, wood, roasty, and vanilla.  The Taste is caramel, bourbon, malty, and brown sugar.  The Palate is tingly with a warming sensation and this beer is medium bodied.  Overall, this is a very quaffable beer and a sipping beer at that.  It is worth trying and a beer that I not only would drink again, but also highly recommend.
Draught at HOTB. Strong Bourbon aroma. Dark dark brown color light head. Nice strong woody taste with sweet boozy finish. Sticks around so take your time.

Mahogany, thin off-white head. Nose is bourbon barrel, cinnamon toast, more bourbon. Taste is bourbon barrel, cinnamon, chocolate syrup, wet wood. Finishes with light barrel and a slight hop bitterness. Velvety mouthfeel, finishes dry.

bottle from tom10101, thanks! pours clear dark copper-red with a very small off-white head, very little retention. nuttied caramel, lightly boozy, tons of caramel and dark fruitiness, some burnt ones, hint of smoked malts. soft carbonation, medium body, oily and sticky, good use of bourbon barrels, some sweetness, nice earthy and grassy finish. not too boozy. good balance. much enjoyed it!
Bottle to snifter. Deep redish mahogany with a thin, tan head. Toffee, sugar, bourbon, wood and dark fruit aromas. Similar flavors but a much more caramel finish.

Pours a cloudy dark ruby-amber with a quickly attenuating scorched caramel-colored head. Lovely vanilla on the nose accompanied by tempered bourbon. Moutfheel is a little thin, but smooth as silk. A bit of a burn on the finish from a combination of carbonation, hop, and alcohol. The flavor is amazing. It would be perfect, but theres just some alcohol bitterness that detracts from the heavenliness. Toffee, vanilla, bread, and bourbon, all in spades. Its reminiscent of my favorite beer on planet Earth--Double DBA from FW, but a scaled down version.
Pours mahogany with very little head.  Nose is bourbon and vanilla.  Flavor is the same with a malty sweetness and some dark fruit notes.  Nice beer, especially after some a year plus of aging.

Pours deep brown with a cream head. Aroma is of vanilla, oak, caramel, with a touch of citrus-floral hops. Taste is very sweet and malty, but there are a few different caramelized tastes that prevent the beer from being too cloying. The finish is woody and hoppy, a little herbal. Pretty excellent beer.

The Backwoods Bastard pours a very dark amber brown that is almost black and features an eggshell head that leaves good lacing. The aroma is a complex mixture of caramel, chocolate, dough and floral hops. I could smell this all day. There are so many flavors that it is hard to follow. It tastes like roasted caramel toffee with chocolate up front with a hint of bread and then floral hops hang on the end. Overall this is an excellent brew and I am quite happy I am enjoying this.

Color is a beautiful ruby amber, carbonation is on the low side. Sweet caramel malt and a little coconut scents are most prominent. Coconut and chocolate come through strongly on the palate. Sweet caramel rounds out the palate, but the overall effect is surprisingly not sickly or overly sweet. The mouthfeel is lighter than many Scotch ales. Almost dessert-like if the alcohol werent so readily apparent. Not for those who dislike sweet beers, but if thats where your tastes are, this is a great beer.
Great after dinner beer. Huge vanilla and Bourbon taste. Smooth and the alcohol is well hidden

Big thanks to Hopshopenstein for sending this my way. Dark, dark red color with a minimal head. The aroma on this was just great, vanilla, bourbon, sugar, wood. Great! The flavor was not nearly as good, sort of muddled. It had hints of the vanilla and bourbon but i really couldnt get a feel for the base beer beneath. If the flavor matched the aroma this would be top notch.

Serving type: bottle

02-11-2013 01:20:30
Nice oakey aroma with spices. Malty, slightly sweet with a hint of hops on the palate.

Ugghhh.  For me, this is the nastiest thing labeled beer Ive tasted in quite a while. Its like watered down maple syrup with a hint of bourbon.

When I have a hankerin for a beer, the last thing I want is sugar-water.

"Big and delicious for your perty mouth." Founders more or less sums this beer up in seven words. Year after year this a favorite. This is my last bottle this year, oh so sad. Big oaky bourbon, vanilla nose. Let this one warm up, if you didnt already know. Enjoying with my two best friends, 2 pit bulls!! Poured from a bottle.

She changes personalities as she warms up. Bourbon up front, vanilla and oak. Caramel notes, but a well balanced sweetness. For such a big beer its relatively medium bodied. Several months ago I was privileged enough to be at a party with a keg of this, its very possible to enjoy several of these. 

This is one of the best beers out there. No matter what style beer you enjoy try this!!

Bottle Thanks to Jstax..Pour is dark brownish red with a cream tan head..Nose is vanilla, oak,nutty,smoke,roast,biscuit..Taste is vanilla,oak,smooth bourbon,spice,nutty,smoke..Very smooth finish aksing for more.

Awesome brew on tap at Kellehers. Part of their barrel aged event, like an arrogant on a trip! Sweeter, more body and a great palate after taste.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

From the minute you crack the cap off, this beer has it all going on. The taste of caramel, vanilla, and bourbon are a wonderful mix. The golden color is appealing. The overall taste, appearance, and aroma make this bourbon barrel brew one of the best. Perfect for chilling in your favorite chair watching  your favorite ice hockey team.

Thanks, Time4lunch! Aroma is big oak and bourbon, some caramel, cherries, light earthiness, and a hint of nuts. Pours a swamp water brown without much of a head. Taste is big bourbon, some earthy qualities, more caramel and light traces of fruits. Very cool brew!

Bouteille 355ml, courtoisie de Fred. De couleur brune-cuivrée foncée et légèrement voilée. Nez de vanille et boisé (fût de bourbon), de caramel, léger de butterscotch et de toffee avec des notes de fumée de bois, de fruits (petits fruits confits) et dalcool liquoreux. Moyenne-ronde en bouche avec un pétillement doux ainsi quune texture liquoreuse. Goût boisé (fût de bourbon), de vanille et  très léger de fruits lors de lentrée en bouche auquel se rajoute un goût de caramel toffee aux notes rôties, fumées (fumée de bois) et terreuses. Parallèlement, lon retrouve un moyen goût dalcool liquoreux réchauffant avec des notes de biscuits et ce, jusquen finale. Post-goût long, composé dun moyen goût dalcool avec un léger goût boisé et de vanille ainsi quun résiduel de caramel et de faibles traces fruitées.

UPDATED: FEB 24, 2013 The nose on this one was pretty impressive. Lots of vanilla, sweet bourbon, honey and cherries among caramel and light hops. The taste was not as sweet, but rather full of caramel, hops and oak with a satisfying hop character for the finish. The alcohol was very well hidden and... wow was this good shit. Thanks OmegaX!

Bottle - Reddish brown pour.
Brown sugar aroma, roasted nuts, toffee, some barrel-rather nice kind of sherry note, spiced bourbon, vanilla. Swirl brings out leather.
Taste - Like a fruit and chocolate bomb. Thick caramel sweetness. 
Chewy, thick mouthfeel. Begins with a nice bitterness then becomes sweet and sticky. 

10.2abv. Thats got to be a mistake..?

330 mL bottle, served in a snifter at a tasting at Chris place. Pours clear mahogany with a minimal head that fades and leaves a small amount of lace. On the nose, there are notes of toasted malts, oak, bourbon, chocolate, smoke and touches of earth and coconut. The flavour is moderately sweet, with roasty malts, bourbon, cherries, oak and vanilla. The finish is long and infused with bourbon and oak. On the palate, it is medium-full in body with a smooth, creamy texture and soft carbonation. Overall, this is a great Scotch ale with an amazing bourbon oak character. Complex and harmonious, very well brewed. 2012-11-23

UPDATED: NOV 18, 2015 Rereate again: 4,2 On draft in Illinois.  Lots of wood and vanilla.  Good mouthfeel.    

Rerate draft:  3.9 Very thin head.  Palate is not thick enough.  Disappointing on palate.  Overall I would reach for an oskar blues.

4.0 Nice Carmel malt aroma.  Appearance is thin.  Head falls away.  Nice carmel oak bourbon aroma.  Nice and sweet, with a  hint of vanilla and Carmel and bourbon, very complex very nice.  Just maybe a tad to sweet, but if you are ready for Carmel charm greatness... imagine a carmel sunday with bourbon... top notch.

A bit too sweet for my taste. But, after reading that the beer is a "sipping beer", i can see where some would like it.  

Tastes a bit too much like the yucky hard candy my grandmother (born 1902) used to keep in her candy dish).

UPDATED: FEB 17, 2013 On draft it poured a very dark amber with a mild tan head. Aroma was of vanilla, coconuts and barrels. On the palate I was overwhelmed with smokey sweetness and vanilla followed by burnt caramel. Mouthfeel was a nice smooth medium feel with low carbonation. Good beer but expected much more.
ZztV, Rood/bruine kleur, beige schuimkraag, eikenhout,noten, caramel, drop, heel zoet.

Bottle thanks to phatdog1. Poured an unfiltered dark brown color with a thin thin cream colored top. Aroma of straight bourbon. Front loaded boozy taste of whiskey, followed by notes of caramel, spice, vanilla, cherry, & roasty malts. Medium body, highly carbonated.
Great beer. Delicious full flavored beer. This beer has a robust presentation that develops in flavor as you savor it.

So I got THE LAST 4 OUNCEs outta the tap at Somerset Hills Tap Room.  If this was "the dregs" from bottom of the tap, I can only imagine how intense the fresh keg must have been. Beautiful deep amber color, malty scotchy aroma.  Really really complex malt profile, just enough hops to balance it out.  Description from the brewery is all true, you can taste the oaky bourbon barrel complexity, roasted malts, cherries.  If this "sounds good" to you, just buy it if you are lucky enough to find it.  Maybe not for everyone, but very accessible for anyone who is attracted by the description.  Frikkin awesome.

Brown with a small creamy tan head. Molasses, vanilla, malts, milk chocolate aroma. medium body I expected to be fuller. Delicious beer. Caramel, milk chocolate, vanilla bourbon, oak. The alcohol is completely hidden. Great.
All the hoppy bite of the regular bastard are mellowed out by the vanilla sweetness from the oaky aging. Very sweet and malty with an alcohol/syrupy finish. Very good.

8oz Draught from Taproom. Appearance is dark, caramel brown color with little to no head. Aroma is sugary sweet, bourbon, vanilla, and wood. Taste is caramel malty, scotch alcohol, vanilla, and oak. Amazingly balance with just enough booze flavors not to be overpowering. Palate is full-bodied, ultra smooth texture, fine balance, little carbonation, and a long finish. Truly one of the great American beers out there.
UPDATED: DEC 14, 2013 One of my favorites at two years plus. Sweet tobacco, caramel and coffee, creamy oak laden spirit. This is a malt and barrel lovers dream. Fn yummy.
Dark amber pour with a very thin tan head. Oak wood and Carmel aroma with hits of vanilla. Burbon taste with a bit of dark fruit and vanilla very drinkable with the strong alcohol content.
Draft at Over the Bars in Pittsburgh.  My favorite so far in 2013.  Heavy tastes of scotch and bourbon with a few fruits thrown in.  A delightful sipping delicacy.

UPDATED: MAR 26, 2013 Pours a dusty burnt orange, with about a finger of head, and little carbonation to be seen. The sediments floating remain frozen in place once the pour settles. The smell starts off of sweet bourbon whiskey, and very sugary malts. There are also notes of raisin, fig and even vanilla cupcake. The taste starts off with the sweet malt, which segues into a light, but fairly defined, scotch taste. I also pick up stronger hints of vanilla and butterscotch toward the end. The taste finishes with lingering spice and scotch. Palate is very smooth, and warm. Despite this having a 10% ABV., this was not as boozy as one would expect.

Homey dont play dat. insulting.


bold shit. crazy finish, makes me feel good

12 oz bottle. What can I say. This was simply outstanding. Gorgeous deep red pour, kind of a claret color, with an almost non existent thin beige ring of a head. Wonderful bourbon/vanilla/oak wood aroma. Flavor was sweet, but not syrupy or cloying. Lots of brown sugar, cherry notes, citrus hops all blanketed with the oak it rested in. Bourbon flavor as well, but ever so perfect. Not overwhelming. Full bodied, smooth and gut warming. Wonderful!
Poured a reddish brown with deep vanilla bourbon and caramel aroma. Tastes of big vanilla bourbon and some smoky dark roasted malts. Extremely smooth and well balanced.

Potent beer. Pours like red oak, ruby tinged with some lacing. Aroma of candy, honey, oak and booze. The latter stays through aftertaste and gives a sweet end to it. Thick and syrupy on palate. Also some hot spice in finish. On tap at brewpub.

Aroma is dominated by rich caramel notes, both light and dark caramel. There is also some toffee and a light chocolate aroma. Aroma has above amount of vanilla with some oak present as well. No hop aroma. Low to medium, but clean alcohol aroma. Some carmelized fig and raisin notes as well. Also some dark cherry notes if you take a deep breath. 
Pours a dark brown with some ruby highlights on the edges. A thin, dark tan head recedes fairly quickly leaving a film on the edges. Light lacing and small legs. 
Flavor is similar to the aroma. Lots of sweet caramel of varying darkness. Light toffee and chocolate notes as well as a faint smokiness. The flavor has more oak than the aroma but the vanilla is still present as well. Some raisin notes and carmelized fruit. No hop flavor but moderate bitterness. A medium amount of alcohol and low oak character in the finish. 
Mouthfeel is medium bodies with medium low carbonation. Alcohol warmth is moderate and astringency is low. 
Overall this is a very good beer. I am enjoying it more than I remembered liking it. The complex caramel character works nicely with the oak and vanilla notes from the barrel. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

12 oz Bottle: Pours a dark brown with ruby tones and a thin light tan head. Aroma is sweet with hints of raisins, vanilla and a mild oaky alcohol presence. Roasty flavor is sweet with a oaky presence and hints of cherries, dark fruit, caramel, and vanilla.  Has a creamy texture and a warming mouthfeel in the finish. A good sipper.
2001 vintage on tap.  Pours murky red, no head.  Funky, fruity smell.  Dry and funky, dry white wine, cream, caramel, vanilla.  Dry sour finish.

UPDATED: NOV 5, 2014 2012 bottle.  Pours a clear brownish red with little head but great lacing.  Aroma of vanilla, spice and that oaky bourbon.  Taste the bourbon and caramel malt up front with the earthy spice and sweetness mid palate.  Finishes with oak and some bitterness but just enough to balance.  Medium full mouthfeel with alcohol warmth that is also just enough to be enjoyable.  A sipper for sure but a very well done bourbon barrel aged ale.  One I can enjoy because it is nicely balanced.  Plus Im discovering I like wee heavies.  

2013 bottle.   Pours a clear dark copper with some ruby.  Small head but leaves a persistent ring and decent lacing.  Aroma of molasses, dark bread and malt, some fruit and a bit of bourbon.  Taste is sweet and malt forward with molasses, some breadiness and a slight charred flavor.  Has some oak and bourbon taste with alcohol warmth and spiciness that isnt overpowering.  Finishes with some of that charred character.  Mouthfeel is somewhat slick with a medium body and carbonation.  Good but I remember liking better last year.  
2013 bottle aged one year - aroma is very nice.  Molasses, toasted malt with a dark bread aroma, caramel sweetness and scotch.  Flavor is very smooth and somewhat sweet up front with molasses and brown sugar.  Toasted malt that hints at being roasted and has some dark bread character.  A pleasant musty hint of oxidation and oak along with some scotch and bourbon.  Very good.
---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Copper with a ring of white foam. Cereal grain, oats, mild booze. A little warm on the back end. Alright.

Pours a mahogany brown and red with little to no head.  Smell is oak, scotch and caramel.  Taste is the same with some acerbic alcohol taste around the edges.  Oily mouth feel and lacing.  Definitely strong and needs to be sipped. Good. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours a brownish red color, with a small head. Nose is sweet and alcoholic with a definite oaky aroma. Taste is woody, with a vanilla oaky taste and a bit of cherries. No hiding the alcohol on this one, carbonation is soft, texture heavy. Finishes like a single malt scotch, a nice complex scotch ale. Quaff Score 8 / 10

Pours a red brown with a thin tan head and sweet aroma of bourbon, malt, oak and vanilla. Taste is delicious and complex, sweet with bourbon notes, malt, oak, vanilla, and caramel with a long, oaky, burning finish. Very flavorful brew

Aroma: Bourbon and raisins with light molasses and vanilla.

Appearance: Poured a rich dark brown with light head.

Taste: Very bourbon heavy with strong underlying vanilla tones. This is a very sweet beer. 

Overall: Although this is a very good beer, it is just not quite my thing. It is almost too sweet. Still a really good beer but I wouldn't actively seek it out again.

12oz bottle. Very dark red color with almost no head. Aroma is pretty mild, sweet whiskey and smokey. Flavors are really well blended and smooth, but Im not seeing what makes this a top 1% beer. I like the smokey character and rich body, but Im not seeing world class.

12 oz. Bottle from 9/28/12 poured into snifter. Pours a deep amber brown almost completely opaque with a small, quickly dissipating light tan head. Aroma of oak, bourbon, vanilla, butterscotch and dark fruit. Flavor has a big hit of bourbon and smokey oak at the start followed up with vanilla, toffee and fig. Leaves a warming bourbon taste on the finish. The mouth feel on this beer is great, nice and smooth. Medium body with low to medium carbonation.  Overall a fantastic beer, great balance of woody bourbon with the sweetness and very smooth.
Nice bourbony sweet flavour. Quite aromatic and flavourful. All around quality product.
Pours a thick rich mahogony with creamy head. Big boozy aromas along with sweet caramel. Wamr and boozy flavours and more sweetness and peat. Very nice!

A lightly hazed reddish brown ale with a thin lacing off white head. In aroma, wonderful mix of treacle, plums, white wine, vanilla and Brett notes, wow! In mouth, a sweet vinous malt with licorice, tobacco, treacle, complex, warming alcohol, beautiful winter warmer. On tap at J.Ryans, Nov. 29 2012.

Great barrel aged flavor to what tastes like a scotch ale base. Hints of vanilla and slightest bit of chocolate 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
12 ounce bottle pour.  4 pack for $14.99.  2012 vintage.  Phenomenal beer and the bourbon notes are very pronounced.
Pours a dark reddish brown with strong bourbon aroma, very smooth with caramel malt and a sweet finish
hhad on tap at Founder Brewery. Dark brown color with little head. Aroma of sweet bourbon and malts. Not over powering on the alcohol. Taste of vanilla, caramel and wood.

It pours a dark brown color and givers the same color body. With a nice half inch white foamy head, it quickly dies to a film coating the top of the body. Nice filmy spotty lacing is seen around the sides of the pint glass. The smell was bourbon directly in the face, theres practically nothing more powerful than this. Only after it warms a bit, some light fig and bready notes come out. The taste has the bourbon powering through once again with the light fig and bready notes coming in subtlely. Alcohol burn comes through in the suspected sense. The mouthfeel is about a medium with some slight alcohol harshness on the tongue. Overall, the bourbon is actually a bit overbearing at the moment. Im hoping to age this a bit to hopefully mellow it out a bit.

Bottle. Aroma of bourbon and malt.  Taste has huge notes of toffee and butter.  Like a liquid Heath bar.  Damn good.  Thick, creamy mouthfeel.  Been wanting to try this for a long time, and it was worth the wait.
Taste is slightly malty with a distinct vanilla/oak and bourbon combination. Not too heavy or thick given the ABV; overall great sipper.

12 ounce bottle with the updated label art that looks nothing like the picture shown here.  They should switch to the throwback version. Aroma is sweet, lots of caramel and only minor levels of bourbon, delivering a modest, balanced and approachable nose.  Appearance is dark copper and some suds collecting around the rim of the glass. Flavor is all delicious: caramel covered vanilla cherry sucker on an oak stick, all dipped in the nice, old and gentle side of bourbon.  Palate is robust with enough backbone to carry assertive flavors without getting filling.  Theres a pleasant carbonation sizzle that helps deliver the excellent flavor package.  Overall this is a straight up A grade beer that will might even win over those bourbon barrel skeptics out there.

I stupidly did not see that this was a bourbon ale. Very good if you are into that thing, just not my scene. The rating is high though because I feel Founders achieved what they wanted to achieve with this brew.

Poured into large tulip. Small, non lasting head. The color is beautiful...very deep red, bright and clear. Aroma is of oak tones, earthiness, and wonderful bourbon. The flavor is amazing. No bitterness, a little underlying sweetness, great woody flavors, strong bourbon but not overpowering, maybe a hint of good scotch too. Clean on the palate with a lingering bit of alcohol and bourbon sweetness. Great stuff. I have to edit and upgrade here. This got even better as it warmed over the hour it took me to drink it. IMHO this is outstanding and it is officially a bummer that there was only one lonesome bottle on the store shelf.
Bottle, aroma was strong and flavour was a nice sweet bourbon and a nice smooth finish, overall, the beer was tasty,

Bottle: pours burgundy reddish brown with brief tan head that fades away. Nose is scotch, woody notes, caramel malts and toffee. A fair amount of bourbon flavors on the tongue with some lingering spicy heat on the finish. Not as sweet as one would expect as this could use some aging but it's tasty. Big beer

Aged over 1 year in bottle.  Pours brown with a sweet boozy smell.  Taste of roasted caramel.  A great scotch ale.

Aged 1 year. Huge vanilla aroma. Rich caramel color. Lots of bourbon at first, not too boozy. Well done. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottled October 5, 2012 and enjoyed December 23, 2012.  Pours with a faint amount of head.  Wonderful dark amber color.  Initial scent is oak, vanilla and bourbon and so is the taste.  Texture is rather thick , leaving a nice flavorful coating on the palate, and smooth as hell.  Warming bourbon flavor throughout.  Sweetness from Dirty Bastard is tempered nicely with the bourbon, though the two flavors live harmoniously with one another.  This has been my favorite beer for years, and this years offering does not disappoint.

This backwoods bastard can lock me in it oaky shed at will. Smells superb, all barrel-riffic, oaky vanilla thing. On the tongue you get that too, plus big caramel/toffee flavors and nice spicy zing. Squealin' like a pig right now.

Had on tap.

Arrived with a clear dark brown body with no head at all.

Aroma is nearly all bourbon and the characteristics that go along with it. Lots of vanilla, caramel, and wood.

The bourbon continues over to the flavor but it is very smooth and quite sweet; not harsh in the least. Caramel and vanilla dominate along with some pleasant fruitiness. Alcohol is pretty well hidden considering the strength of this beer.

Overall, if you like bourbon you will absolutely love this beer. The flavors mesh perfectly and the mouthfeel is just right; full but not too sweet. A really amazing beer.

Bottle.  A murky deep brown/amber color pours out without mustering much of a head.  Black plum, raisin, sugary dates, and bourbon-soaked wood invades the senses.  While the aroma isnt as bourbon heavy as I anticipated, the flavor is.  This doesnt really bother me since I generally like bourbon aged beers and Im not a huge fan of Scotch Ales anyway.  Some cherry skin, toffee, and raisins are noted as well.  A bit earthy.  This doesnt come across as overly complex but its quite tasty.  A good one to sit back and relax with during a cool night for sure.

A:  Heavy caramel, dark fruit, layered with peat, and bourbon. Incredibly lovely. Nothing overwhelms anything and for being a boozy beer, the alcohol is restrained and mellow.

A: Pours a deep chestnut brown--very formidable looking. Very marginal lacing.

T: My first impression is that isnt as sweet as I would have believed. It is more woody bourbony than anything. There is bitterness but it is only to tamp the more agressive aspects of this beer. As it warms, it gets more assertively smoky and also picks up a meaty aspect. Overall, I dig this beer. However, I believe it is toned down from last year. It could do with a bit more complexity.

P: Medium bodied and not as heavy as one would expect. Surprisingly active carbonation for a beer of this caliber.

O: I really enjoy this beer. Although, it is not something that I would want to drink frequently, but on cold nights, it is a wonderful choice.

Bottle to shaker glass.  Pours a clear dark amber with a sparse tan head that laces great.  Smells boozy, definitely taste the bourbon.  Woodsy flavor.  Im not getting a lot of hop flavor.  Malty with a strong bourbon backbone.  Nice.

This beloved beer, is one that I have had a very good number of times by way of small 1 to 3oz samples served on draught at the bar where I work. The reason why Ive tried it so many times is because honestly Im a little amazed that what Im tasting when I take a sample of it could ever be a beer rated within the 99th percentile on Ratebeer. To put it shortly Ive been up till this point wholly unimpressed with my encounters with this beer.
When I spotted single bottles for sale at a local liquor shop I decided that perhaps Im drinking too little of the beer, too fast, and at too low a temperature... perhaps the 3oz taster glass is a poor receptacle for the beer.... So I sank the $3.50 so that at the very least I could drive the nail into the coffin and proclaim that I never want to drink the beer again, or adversely find that through serving the beer the beer properly in a tulip glass, at a cellar temperature, and with enough volume to wrap my head around any before missed subtitles that I may experience what so many others seem to love about this beer. 

The color of the beer is really quite beautiful, a very deep reddish orange, the head is small, but well retained. 
 
I will admit that the aroma is inviting and far more pronounced at the higher serving temperature. Initially out of the bottle rich woody, boozy, and vanilla bourbon notes were dominant. But while the glass sits these notes become more subdued (although they never go away). The beer is sweet and boozy smelling with cherries, toffee, and toasted nuts. 

My goodness the flavor of this beer is a different animal from the bottle at cellar temperature. Far less brash with much more character. Yes it is still a tad on the sweet and boozy side for what I generally prefer, but the beer is still nice. Vanilla, whiskey, mild spice, dark sweet cherries, woodiness, red apple skins, and light smoke are enjoyable and satisfying notes. There is something familiar about the beer that I cant put my finger on, but I think it might be akin to cavendish tobacco. 

The beer is too sweet and boozy for me to really love, but its weird... I like some beers that are sweeter and/or boozier than this one. The other elements... while good, are maybe not fantastic enough to overly wow me, but I must say I do enjoy the beer, and propa serving technique meant the world for the aroma and flavor of this beer. 

I admit, I understand the appeal now... and this makes for a fantastic nightcap.
12 oz - The nose tells you instantly this is not a toy. Creamy front, bourbon back. Yum

From the 12 fl. oz. bottle.  The pour is a handsome looking amber-brown with an off-white fluffy head that lasts for a time.  The aroma is alive with bourbon and wood along with caramel malts, butterscotch, and a little smoke.  The body is medium to bold.  The taste is much like the aroma with a touch of vanilla tossed in and a long, lingering bitter bite at the end.  Very nice indeed.

pours dark brown without much head.  aroma is mainly wood (oak) and bourbon, with a little bit of vanilla as well.  taste is almost entirely caramel and toffee sweetness; vanilla and malt are also there, as well as some sharp dark fruit notes near the end.  rich, smooth, and boozy.
Aroma is fruit, malts and a heavy hint of sweetness.  The flavor is is malts, oak/fruit and vinous/alcohol note in the finish.
The nose is vanilla, wood, and bourbon.  Deep brown with a quickly disappearing head.  Sweet malt with some earthy bitterness in the back.  Full bodied and warming.

Pours red amber hue with a off white head. Nose and taste of bourbon, toffee, vanilla, caramel, and oak. The level of bourbon is perfect, enough to know its there... And not overpowering the rest of the beer. Body is big and silky. A great sipping beer.
Bottle pours a brown tan head good fizz. Tastes smells of smoke sweet malt caramel vanilla booze whiskey. Spicey. Not bad at all should maybe pick up a few more for long winter.
pours dark amber with a red tint.  Decent head. Smells of oak, sweet malt, bourbon.  The taste is very sweet, the bourbon takes over. I like normal Dirty Bastard better.

UPDATED: DEC 19, 2015 Update: Dec 2015
I dont know if they have changed anything from earlier years, but this is working much more beautifully for me now. Gorgeous stewed dates, prunes, caramel, licorice, vanilla, and a beautifully spicy, boozy woody edge in the aroma translate into sumptuously caramely, fruity, vanilla-oaky goodness in the mouth. Sweet malty and fruity flavors are rounded out by the wood, for a slightly acidic, boozy, earthy, spicy, dry finale. Beautiful and much more balanced than I remembered it being.

Original rating (Dec 2011 and Dec 2012): 7/4/8/4/14
It pours a deep, translucent mahogany without much of a head  only a thin bone-colored foam shows up momentarily and quickly dissipates. The aroma is caramel, vanilla, brown sugar, licorice and wood sustained by a strong backbone of ethanol. Its super boozy, to say the least. Silky mouthfeel with minimal carbonation. The taste is mainly caramel, brown sugar, and malted grain up front, with a dry, earthy, woody scotch aftertaste. It greets the stomach with soothing warmth.

Bottle. 2012. Aroma is so intense and complex it is difficult to describe. Back and forth between alcohol/burnt sugar and oak and scotch whiskey. Layers and layers of sweetness. The flavor itself is caramel, toffee, and vanilla alcohol flavors. Super dense body and warming sensations. Some earthy yeast flavors as well. Delicious.

11 vintage.  Minimal head with no lacing.  Big sweet oaky bourbon nose and caramel malts.  Taste follows-very rich and sweet with bourbon and caramel and some maple syrup notes.  Almost too sweet, but not quite.  Want to try this fresh-think I may find it a bit more balanced.    Glad I split it with the missus-its a great autumn sipper.

In a snifter, pours dark amber with a small disappointing head, no suprise here because of the ABV.  Big Bourbon, Vanilla, alcohol, dried fruits on the aroma, very complex.  Flavor is sweet and full with oak, bourbon, dark rum, spice, vanilla, and chocolate notes. Very warming flavorful, complex beer. I only could have one of these a night.
Lots of caramel malt, molasses and bourbon. Very hot tasting alcohol is straight up front. Overall, not bad but not worth excess cost.

UPDATED: NOV 17, 2014 Pours deep amber brown with small, orange brown head. Smells of whiskey, vanilla, smoke, candy sweet malt, butterscotch, toffee, and a hint of dark fruit. Very sweet but with some bite and smokiness to balance it out. Alcohol warmth and bourbon for sure, with a huge burst of vanilla. Slick and heavy on the palate. Very nice and very complex flavor.

UPDATED: MAR 10, 2013 On draft as part of Zwanze 2012 at West Lakeview Liquors in Chicago.   Generally not a big barrel aged guy but this one, with the little extra room that a scotch ale provides, was excellent plus.  Nose and initial taste was heavy with vanilla and bourbon...which for a 2 oz pour is pretty much what you get...very tasty!

UPDATED 3/10/13...fresh bottle from Sherm1016...thanks.  A full glass, not a taster, helped me enjoy this even more...upgraded to a 4.1...very very tasty.

Beautiful clear deep red amber color. Nice off white two finger fluffy head. Aroma is bourbon, oak, vanilla, some caramel and toffee.

Taste is veeeery bourbon forward. Nice full mouthfeel and pretty sweet. Also get alot of sweet caramel malts. Almost no hop prescence. 

I can see why people like this beer. For me it is a little bit too much bourbon character in there but I guess that is just personal preference. 
All in all a good brew. =)
draft at Coles, Buffalo. rich, toffee notes, caramel maltiness, sweet bourbon notes. wonderfully complex. big rich mouthfeel. great sipper

Dark brownish reddish tint pour into snifter..slight head at the sides..more carbonation than expected..aroma of boost sweet bourbon, vanilla bean, char, oak, scotch..and hint of dried fruit..quite busy and complex nose..palate is dominated by the booze,warming presence..prefer this type of presence more from a stout..not a giant fan of scotch ales..good sipper and interested to see what some age would do to the abundant booze presence..dont really find this too sweet..

Pours cloudy, brown-red with a minimal tan head.
Nose is dark cherry, smooth bourbon.
Taste is....a lot... cherry, vanilla, bourbon barrel (well-presented barrel, I might add)
Smoky sweet, some chocolate, dark fruit, caramel.
Astonishingly smooth with a wonderful back-throat burn....
Absolutely stellar......amazing beer.
Bottle. Pours a dark maple syrup with no head. Aroma is caramel and some booze. Flavor is syrupy with caramel, malts and some bourbon. Overall a good beer.

The smell and taste tell you that this beer spent some time in an oak burbon barrell in the backwoods. The burbon taste is not overwheling though. Dark, strong scotch ale that I had off tap served in a brandy snifter which was perfect.
On tap.  Comes dark reddish brown with a small biege head.  Aroma of dark fruit, bourbon, and malt.  Taste is bourbon, caramel, cherries, malt, and caramel.  Rich and warming.  Very nice.

This is one of the better seasonal releases from this fine brewery in Grand Rapids, Michigan. I love Founders and everything they have. 

Aroma- Starting out you get bourbon, but as you focus more the malts really come forward in this one. Terrific and enjoyable.

Apperance-Yes! this stuff looks so awesome in a glass. Makes you feel like youre drinking one of the best beers crafted around. Thick head and a wonderful dark and rich color.

Taste-Wow!!! this is heavy on the scotch flavor. Much more than its cousin Dirty Bastard. The bourbon really comes through as well

Overall- This beer will kick you squarley in the balls if you are not careful,  but it is deliicious. Drink with buddies and show off your excellent taste.

Why, oh, why did I feel the need to purchase this beer? Founders is a solid brewer, but I dont care for Scotch Ales and Dirty Bastard was no exception. I was in a beer store and in a hurry. I rarely spend half this much on beer, so I guess the label got me. Lesson learned. Bottle. Deep brown body with a little garnet at the edges. There is a thin light tan head. The nose has some strong caramel and marshmellow candy. There is also a bit of bourbon and vanilla sweetness. This has a slight hint of wood. Otherwise, it is candy sweet. The taste is woody boozy caramel and leather. There is also a hint of hay in the finish. A little dusty. A warming boozy brew that is like sugared up scotch and wood. The barrel aging dominates and that is not a good thing. Wow, this is an overpriced mess. I guess its for the scotch ale lovers and those that love barrel aging regardless of the results. A purchase I immediately regretted and tasting did not change my attitude.

Draft at Tuskies. Pours dark brown with an inch of khak foam. Smells of peat and whiskey on the nose. Big alcohol taste on the tongue which amplifies the scotch notes. Slight alcohol burn on the finish. Quite lovely!

Tap @ Tuskies Mill - pours a dark cherry red thats clear when held up to a light. Aroma is fantastic, dark cherries, bourbon, malt, vanilla oak, and a faint touch of warm winter spices like cinnamon and nutmeg. Taste is sweet with a lingering smokey burn of alcohol. Palate is just dry enough to make you want to take another sip. Its a big beer so take your time and enjoy it with good company over a great meal. Overall, probably one of the best beers Ive had in months.

Delicious head.  Sweet but Ok for the casual drinker.   Very good high gravity beer. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
very interesting beer. Drank from a growler purchased yestersay so the carbonation wasnt great. chocolate or medium steak taste

Ill be real honest..I am not a BIG fan of barrel aged beers. I have two drinking favorites, good beer and good bourbon. My interest in the mixing of the two is tolerable at best. If you want a good beer , then drink a good beer. If you want a good bourbon the sip a good bourbon. Now that said thats exactly what philosophy I stick too. However, as much of a pain in the ass it was to find , the reviews of the Bastard made me curious. So foregoing against my better nature I was in the right place at the right time and was able to procure a couple of 4 packs. Well hell, I admit it is pretty damn good. Obviously dark color with faint whiskey undertones as well as mostly stout type characteristics, vanilla, caramel, toffee, etc.. I immensely enjoyed it whilst preparing the turkey on Thanksgiving.

12 oz bottle,  It pours a dark brown color with a thin, light tan head. The nose is rich and vinous with notes of bourbon and stone fruit. The flavor has a good bit of bourbon with sweet, dark caramel, fruitcake, fig, and dried cherries. A slight earthiness lasts start to finish. Rich in body with a good bit of drying alcohol on the back end. Potent for sure, the alcohol is obvious from start to finish and very warming on the way down.
Nose is delicious layers of toffee, marzipan, whiskey and wood. The bourbon barrel treatment really works well for this beer.

Pours a hazy brown. Aroma of sweet whiskey and malt. Taste is whiskey, alcohol burn and malt blending like coconut. Incredible blend of burbon barrel aging and a base beer. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours a clear reddish brown color. Minimal head. Aroma is toffee/caramel and bourbon. Taste follows the nose. This is a big malty beer. Loads of bourbon flavor followed by malty sweetness. Barely kept in check by hop bitterness. Very good and definitely worth trying not something i want a lot of though.

12oz bottle picked up at Beers of the World in Rochester.  Clear red-brown pour with a small head. Aroma is bourbon, wood, and caramel; taste is smooth and balanced dark fruit, wood, vanilla, maybe toffee, and some bourbon.  Very sweet, good.
Growler from my parents.  From Growlers.  Clear brown pour with a small head.  Aroma is bourbon, wood, and caramel.  Taste is vanilla, boozy, dark fruit, a little chocolate, and a nice woody finish.

Picked up a 4 pack for $13 from the local Co-Op. 2012 vintage. Dark amber brown, 3 finger tan head that fades to 1 finger and sticks around. Nose is sweet apricots, plums and vanilla. Wow. Very sweet beer with tons of complexity. Lots of burnt and roasted tastes. Love the vanilla booziness this has but its a bit too sweet.

A nice brown pour with a small head. Minimal lacing on my class. Aroma of bourbon shines through, making me a bit nervous actually. Add a little vanilla to the smell and now Im ready to drink it. Not as much whiskey in the flavor, still very present, but not overpowering. Lots of flavors in this. The more I let it sit it started tasting like almond joy candy bars. Really nice brew.

12oz into pint glass.  Dark brown, small tan head.  Aroma is basically all bourbon, some malty sweetness but dominated by the bourbon.  Taste is all bourbon too, fairly hot, fairly rough if Im being honest.  Pretty hard to tell what the base beer is, the bourbon just dominates.  Body is on the thin side, carb is just right.

12oz bottle----> tulip.  Pours a dark brown with no head or lacing.  Aroma is oaky bourbon and vanilla.  Has tastes of sweet fig, oak, and a hint of smoke.  Thick and smooth on the tongue.  A decent enough beer, but a bit too sweet for my likings.

New Beer Distributors, NY 355ml ($4.25): Pours a brownish color with a very small head. Aroma is whiskey, vanilla, wood, and malts. Taste is less whiskey than the aroma, but still plenty whiskey. Huge amount of complexity. The beer is most beer oriented towards the front. The finish and the after taste are straight vanilla and wood. There is a bit of booze. There be some smoke. Some fruitiness. Quite good, but Im glad I just have one.
At the brewery, dark brown pour.  Smoke and scotch nose, very tasty with caramel malts and overwhelmingly good.

12oz bottle - pours mahogany with thin khaki head and spotty lacing. Nose is woody, smoky, peat, and alcohol. Flavor adds chocolate. Very dry finish as in the liquid evaporated instantly and left a sticky film on the tongue. Sweet. Strong burning sensation. Fruity notes as it warms. Really takes me back to when I could afford scotch.

Courtesy of Simon, from Cave à Bulles, ParisMahogany color with medium sized creamy head. Strong aroma where the oak blends well with roasty notes and chocolate; a tobacco note adds a nice complexity. Rich dark chocolate flavor, roasted malts, correct bitterness, vanilla oak.Very good.

Smells like toffee vanilla bourbon goodness. Taste is of roasted chocolate and coffee finishing with caramel and vanilla. Very dry tannic finish.  This is probably from the peat taste of the bourbon in the wood. Overall a great beer but lacking in mouthfeel.  Its a little thin for all the flavor.  If this were addressed id give this beer a 4.3+ rating. Sort of sad that this one disappears as fast as Kbs these days.  At least oc is still not sought after like this one yet.

Bottle to snifter, minimal head disappears within seconds. Looks to be crisp deep brown with some reddish hues exposed when held up to the light. Nose is boozy + peaty, almost underwhelming, because I know how good its about to taste. Yessir! So much going on doughy bread, jam, slight astringency, caramel, and wood. All flavors play well together without ever being to sweet. The barrel-aging absolutely compliments the style of beer. Mouthfeel is smooth, slightly hot (doesnt detract from taste), goes down way too easy. Not the most challenging style off beer but Founders hits it out of the park, love it.

DELICIOUS, ABSOLUTELY DELICIOUS! Thank you Bud Starr! Shared from a 12oz brown bottle into a tulip glass. It poured a slightly hazy, deep reddish amber color with a thin but persistent off-white head and lace. Malty sweet, caramelly, toffee, oak, vanilla, coconut, white chocolate, Scotch Ale, fruity, earthy, boozy. Very smooth, slightly less-so as it warmed. Noticeable alcohol, warming but well-integrated.

Pours dark rust with minimal head. Smells of toffee, brown sugar, and oak aged bourbon. There is a smooth syrupy mouthfeel that only enhances the beauty of the taste. Molasses, oak, and bourbon come together in viscous harmony. Beautiful beer.

Bottle->stem.  Deep amber, no head.  Aroma is deep malt and grain.  Taste is bourbon, bourbon, bourbon with some malt.  Alcohol overpowers the good taste.  For me, a great beer (Dirty Bastard) has been lessened here by the current urge to age everything in a bourbon barrel.

UPDATED: NOV 20, 2014 Draft. Medium brown in color, malty and slightly boozy on the nose, this beer is a dream to drink. You sip and want to linger on the palate extra long. UPDATE: 11-20-14, Super thick molasses smell, sugary nose, with a boozy and coconut mouth. Way more coconut this year. Actually, too much coconut, probably.

One of my all-time favs. Super close to drinking a good bourbon. Beautiful color. Heavy booze and vanilla in the nose. The taste is warming throughout but has a great complexity with caramel, oak, vanilla, and scotch. Wonderful cold weather sipper that happens to come out right around my bday every year. Fine stuff indeed. .
Tap at the source.  Aroma is sweet and strong booze.  Tastes like burnt sugar and caramel sweetness.
Dark brown, with a hint of ruby.  Aroma of sweet soft bourbon.  Taste of bourbon, vanilla and toffee.  Mdeium to heavy thickness.  Tasty stuff.

On tap at bodega. Pours a murky brown with medium head. Smells sweet with oak and bourbon. A little smoke. Tastes more b ourbony than I expected and kind of makes the scotch ale flavor.  Palate is super creamy.  Still tasty.

Delicious aroma. Vanilla and bourbon present at first sip. Nice coloration. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

From bottle in a snifter. Pours with a decent cream head and disperses to the sides of the glass quickly. Dark brown and crimson hues that is nearly opaque, with a bit of red light coming through. Sweet caramel on the nose with good hits of scotch. Lots of malt character immediately, followed by a smooth whiskey aftertaste that lasts. Cant wait to put one of these in the cellar and wait a few years. Also very good on tap, a pit more mellowed out of the whiskey.
color is that of burnt caramel. at firrst smell you get those bourbon barrels with tanned leather. hops is very resiny and woody. overall this is a very delicious beer. I will be back for more

Side by side with Dirty Bastard. Deep reddish brown, maybe a little thicker than DB.  Aroma is quite different - a lot of bourbon, oak, hot alcohol vapour in addition to a light smokiness.  Taste is lots of smoky malt, some sweet caramel and a ton of oaky bourbon.  This is a fantastic sipping beer.  Lives up to the hype!

Easily the best Old Ale (Im calling it old ale because it doesnt taste very wee heavy at all) Ive ever had, besides Curmudgeons Better Half.  Just wonder bourbon scent, caramel, syrup . . . bourbon in beer form.  Fills the palate with warmth and sweetness.  Earthy a tad.  Excellent!!

Clear red colour, brown hue, slight white head. Aroma of caramel, malts, honey, bourbon and wood. Light dark red fruits. Sweet malty flavour, caramel and honey. Long finish, caramel, light bitter, roasted malts, wood.
Nice.
(From 35cL bottle shared @ ZZT V. Obtained through trade with mikem409. Thanks!!)

Take one of my favorite beers and throw it in a bourbon barrel...cant beat that. As this warmed up a bit, the taste just got better and better. Caramel malt mixes with some brown sugar and bourbon made this taste pretty amazing. I cant wait to see how this ages.

Serving: Draft at Fire Works Leesburg.  It pours a dark brown color with a thin, light tan head.  The nose is rich and vinous with notes of bourbon and stone fruit.  The flavor has a good bit of bourbon with sweet, dark caramel, fruitcake, fig, and dried cherries.  A slight earthiness lasts start to finish.  Rich in body with a good bit of drying alcohol on the back end.  Potent for sure, the alcohol is obvious from start to finish and very warming on the way down.  Perfect for cold winter days.
What an aroma! sweet bourbon, malt, toffee and booze.  bigger body without being over sweet.  flavor backs the aroma, bourbon, malt, pleasant sweetness, hint of smoke.  Awesome!

Nice bourbon color with almost zero head.  Aroma is almost pure bourbon.  The perfect beer for the bourbon lover!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
From bottle. Pours dark red/brown with little to no head. Aroma is sweet bourbon with a raisin, dark fruit smell. Taste follows with a boozy burn. A little sharp.

2012 bottle. Pours dark, clear brown with ruby hints. Latte-colored head that dissipates pretty quickly. Big bourbon punch right up front, but quickly recedes and coalesces into the other elements: smoked peat, burnt toffee, bits of cherry and spice. Low carbonation, smooth mouthfeel. A little hot on the finish, but otherwise pretty great.

Dark amber brown with a small off white head, that sticks around the rim. Smells of caramel and bourbon, oak and a tinge of earthiness. Sweet vanilla caramel taste that's pretty boozy, a little of the bourbon comes through and some spice at the finish. Very good sipper. Recommended. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

I kept trying to find something wrong with it, but I couldn't find anything.  Really like drinking a fine spirit.  Boozy, but balanced with soft hints of vanilla.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
A dark reddish brown beer with a medium tan head.  The aroma is malty, vanilla, alcohol, and wood.  The flavor is sweet malt with wood, alcohol, and bread.  A nice creamy body, too.

UPDATED: MAR 21, 2015 12oz bottle from Kalamazoo megabev. Pour is dark brown like cola, reddish hues. Head is offwhite sort of orangeish looking, quarter inch high. Moderate lacing. Smells like alcohol, maple, supple leather and perhaps a hint of cheddar? Tingly mouth feel, fairly low carbonation. More maple and vanilla in the taste, then whiskey and honey, slightly bitter pine hops are detectable as well. Finish is scotch flavored and has an alcoholic burning tingle. Updated 23-May-2013: Bottle aged from October 2012 . Liquid appearance the same but no head. Smoother, sweeter aroma. Same scents just less harsh. Smoother flavor as well, bitter malts reminiscent of most scotch ales, even more vanilla and possibly less maple flavored than fresh. Definitely a little bit better.
21-March-2015: Appearance unchanged from last time. Aroma is deep dark fruits, bourbon, molasses, similar to previous but harsher than description. Mouthfeel not tingly but oily and creamy. Flavor is verging on grain alcohol. Wouldnt recommend aging for 2.5 years.

Another kick ass brew from Founders.  Are they the best brewery east of the Mississippi?   Hmmmm.   Big, huge, vanilla, oak, bourbon, spice and caramel.  This beer is as good as it gets......love it.

pours an amber red that is clear with no turbidity and a tan  head. in my old Scotch aRoma with some vanilla and butterscotch. Taste is strong at first and is more boozy than dirty bastard. Real nice mouth feel

UPDATED: APR 15, 2013 Aromas of rich vanilla, butterscotch, peat, toffee, and caramel, with some mild alcohol.  Deep, dark ruby with a minimal, beige head.  Dry and strong with a roasty bitterness, and flavors of vanilla, bourbon, dried cherries, caramel, and alcohol.  Medium bodied and smooth, uniform, with low carbonation and a boozey mouthfeel, finishing with notes of American oak/vanilla and whiskey liqueur.  Complex and delicious.
Very dark brown color with zero head and minimal oily lacing. Aroma was sweet with bourbon and vanilla. Flavor was all smoky bourbon and light malts.  Pretty good overall

From 2012 bottle, fresh. Pours a deep, dark red, with almost no head. Aroma is good - very boubon heavy - but lacks complexity. The bourbon is still overly strong in the beer itself, but the scotch ale complexity hits in full force after the bourbon starts to die off, giving it a great finish. Mouthfeel is spot on for the style. This beer will probably age well to one or two years old and hit a nice sweet spot. I plan to put a four pack away.

Pours a thick burgundy/brown. No foam to speak of.  Aroma is sweet malty caramel. Taste is dark malt, caramel and vanilla. Maybe some coffee? Lightly bitter finish. Heavy mouth feel with moderate carbonation. This is a wonderful beer. Complex and evolves as it warms. 

More beer please...

Aroma- sweet scent of Bourbon
Appearance- 
Taste- follows the nose sweet beautiful lingering
Palate- thin but lasting
Overall one of the best beers I have ever had. It fits my palate perfectly.

Very little head sweet tasting smelling very chocolatey reminds me of old hickory seven Devils Powerful liquor taste really quite enjoyable

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Fresh 2012 bottle.  It was bottled just a few weeks ago.  Smells a little boozy and bourbony, tastes smoother than smooth.  A caramel, butterscotch vanilla mixture really makes it pop.  For 10.5, its really smooth too.  Cant wait to age a few bottles.

Bottle from Binnys (thanks Alex!). A good election night beer. Pours a deep copper-brown, almost no head to speak of (could be the glass though) Nose is whiskey, toffee and dried figs.  Mouth is big and bad (good bad!).. creamy, toffee and raisins up front with booze lasting throughout. Finishes with a lingering bittersweetness. Ill be honest, I dont relaly like Scotch-style ales (especially after over-doing it a few years back with about 6-too-many Robert The Bruce), but this might make my top-5. Im a sucker for barrel-aged anything, and this one is no exception... George Jones could write a song about it.

Deep brownish red in color with a very thin whispy tan head, light spotting. Sweet nose, dark fruit, vanilla, dark malts, raisin, bourbon. Pretty boozy in flavor, sweet dark fruit, malty backbone with a big boozy finish, a little chocolate in there too. Silky feel and medium carbonation.

pours very dark burgundy with minimal head.aroma is bourbon,wood,dark cherries.molasses and is quite boozey.flavor is big on the bourbon.oak,dark cherries,vanilla and has a pleasant alchohol warming feeling in the back of my throat.medium body with a sticky/creamy mouthfeel.has a long bourbon finish.very soft carbonation.another big beer by founders.love the big bourbon flavor and warming alchohol.i will save one for the cold snowy michigan nights.excellent.

Very intriguing aroma of bourbon and active brown-black appearance with a balanced taste and warming mouthfeel.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

UPDATED: JAN 23, 2014 Tap. Pours hazy ruby with a small tan head and nice lacing. Aroma is molasses, cognac, resin, wood. Flavor is the same, quite sweet and minimally bitter. Strong alcoholic warming finish. Full bodied and creamy. Retry in bottles; more of cloudy hazel, head dissipates fairly quickly. Aroma is fairly light, but nice. Flavor is medium sweet, a little bit boozy, but pleasant mix of bourbon and dark sugars, with oak mixed in.
Nice oak scents and some sweet malt, can also smell some alcohol. Taste is similar with some oak and nice hop character.
From a 12 bottle shared at home.  Pours a clear reddish brown with a short lived off white head.  Aroma of bubble gum.  Strong bourbon notes. Slight bitter finish.

UPDATED: JUN 21, 2013 Poured smooth with almost no head. Looks pretty, very dark ruby appearance.Smells great. Toffee, caramel, bourbon, all great things.Amazing middle of the road body and outstandingly smooth.Tastes pretty good. The bourbon is a little overwhelming though.  toffee, dark cherry, vanilla, slight smokiness

Simply fantastic ale. I am a fan of Oaked brews. Wish there were more available in my area. This is one of the best ones I have had. Smooth as a fine scotch. Hints of oak and cherry. Good malt flavor with perfect amount of hops to finish it off. It will knock your socks off. Carmel red color with good aroma. Not much lacing, but taste over comes the lack of foam that I find visually pleasing. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle.  Deep, dark red, nicely active, but with a thin head.  The aroma is distinctly sweet with a hint of the whiskey within.  This drinks with an artful blend of flavors ... brown sugar, black cherry, and of course some good ol down-home bourbon.  Assembled with the utmost finesse, the whiskey a beautiful complement rather than an obtuse topping.  Outstanding!  (#4815, 11/4/2012)

UPDATED: JUN 11, 2016 Rerate. 2013 vintage. Bottle shared with koleminer20. Aroma is caramel, malt, toffee, bready, booze, barrel, nice. Appearance is ruby brown, light tan head, clear. Taste is caramel, toffee, vanilla, some booze, barrel, malty, nice. Mouthfeel is medium to heavy body, light carbonation, vanilla and malt aftertaste. Overall, this one is great.

Kind of lackluster when I first poured it. No head, and kind of translucent. The aroma builds after letting it sit for a bit. Unbelievable sensation on the palate. Excellent tones of bouron. One of my favorites!

Pours a deep amber with almost no head. Bourbon aromas clobber you over the head when you sniff this viscous liquid. Taste reveals heavy oak, booze, bourbon notes. High residual sugar. Very, very boozy tasting yet not hot on the palate. Good stuff, but a sipper for sure...

Extremely dark brown with a nice head. Aroma is almost all bourbon. Masks the taste quite a bit too. I would never know this started as Dirty Bastard if it was a blind taste. Tasty but disappointing. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours a murky reddish brown color with small head that dissipates quickly and leaves almost no lacing.  Big, fantastic aroma of bourbon, oak, dried fruit, roasted malts and a little smoke.  Taste follows the aroma with the oaky/earthy flavors a little more up front.  Its pretty well balanced with big malty flavors but just a slight overall bitterness.  The finish if pretty clean with a bit of smoke that lingers.  Its got a medium body and pretty lively carbonation.
Bottle. Pours a dark reddish brown color with white head. Bourbon, caramel, vanilla flavors. Bourbon, vanilla, oak aromas. Really tasty beer.

From bottle. Pours a deep ruby red with an instantly vanishing beige head. Bourbon, thats the initial blast of aroma. Once that settles down I get some lighter hints of vanilla, dark fruit, and more bourbon. Taste is much of the same, and delicious. The bourbon is very forward, nicely balanced with vanilla and roasted malts. MF is what you would expect, just enough body to be velvety without being stout-like. Finishes with a nice warm bourbon feel. Truthfully, I dont normally drink scotch ales, but this one is outstanding.

UPDATED: FEB 1, 2013 Outstanding. HUGE bourbon and incredibly rich caramel characters - vanilla and some coconut, wood, caramel - rich butterscotch and toffee. Taste is very sweet as well with big bourbon, wood, and caramel - very sweet and very smooth, soothing burn like a good bourbon. I am very excited to see what this drinks like with some age one it - already getting notably better with a few months on it.  An outstanding beer that reveals something new with each drinking experience.

Pours a rich deep copper color with a finger of eggshell foam that settles fairly quickly. Aromas are warm and barreled. Oak, vanilla, smokey earthy spice and a touch of sweet dates... on the palate it is a lot of the same. Nice smooth balance between sweetness, booze and earthy notes. Masterfully crafted I must say !  Great stuff. Mellow and complex

Une superbe robe rouge foncée.  Un simple anneau de mousse?  Peu importe.  Un nez fortement touché par du caramel et de la mélasse qui suinte la tire dérable, les fruits et le bourbon vanillé.  Au goût, denvoûtantes flaveurs maltées qui se lovent dans un bourbon gras et généreux.  Une cohésion bien intéressante entre les malts caramélisés et leau-de-vie américaine.  Voilà une belle manière de faire les choses.  En bouche, un corps énorme qui est capable de faire face à la force du fût.  Un pétillement justement bas et une texture riche.  Une finale chaude qui montre un savoir-faire malté bien agréable.  Une bière à partager qui doit être bue à petite lampée.

Petite bouteille partagée par Patrick. La robe de cette bière est rouge avec une mousse beige et mince. Le nez est assez unidimensionnel  avec une tonne de vanille du fût de chêne. Le sucre transperce le nez, ça sent le sucre dorge. La bouche est tout aussi en vanille, cest piquant. La texture est agréable, la bière est ronde. Il y a un caramel sucré et cest boisé. Surprenant et agréable. Une bière à partager. 7/10
Amazing aroma predominantly of scotch and caramel.  Nice smooth earthy taste that has hints of vanilla.  Aftertaste lingers a bit, but all in all really love this beer.

Dark red, light haze and a thin beige lace. Raisins, dry wood and raspberries. Nice sweetness, concentrated aroma. Solid amount of bitterness, woody taste. Pecan. Sticky yet not thick. Alcohol warmth. Good. (At ZZT V)

12 oz. bottle, bottled 10/07/11, served in a Deschutes Snifter.

A: Pours a very dark cherry wood with a deep body. An off-white head forms on the pour and dissipates to a nice ring and some floating wisps. Light really shines off this brew.

S: Smells of bourbon with some light chocolate and subtle oaty malts. Very sweet smelling sugars as well.

T: The bourbon is up front with some nice caramel malts. Bready malts, brown sugar and molasses create a nice sweet backbone. There is a slight vanilla sweetness on the finish with a little heat.

M: Medium bodied, well carbonated with a sweet finish and some heat.

O: The barrel is well integrated yet again in a Founders beer. This is sweet, but not overly sweet. Great beer.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 11-03-2011

Bottle @ ZZT V. Superb dark brown color with a dark red glare coming through, small beige head that disappears almost instantly. Smell malts, liquor, sweetish, oak, wood, bourbon. Taste malts, bourbon, wood, oak, liquor. Wow, I really like this one! Medium to full body, medium to full carbonation.

@ZZT V. Copper to ruby colour with no head. Smells very sweet, wood, malty, some red fruit and it smells kinda thick. Tastes very sweet, lots of wood (oak), resin, nuts (hazelnut and almond). Quite great! Full body, low carbo, slightly silky.

Bottle from whole foods, aged for about  a year. Nose is all bourbon, flavor is molasses, bourbon, dark fruits. If you like your bourbon upfront, you'll love this beer.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

UPDATED: SEP 27, 2012 On tap 4 oz. pour at Meridian Pint in Columbia Heights, Washington, DC. This is the 2011 version, aged an extra year at Meridian Pint. Clear, very dark mahogany with a small head and very good lacing. Aroma of molasses, bourbon, dark roast malt, dark fruit, vanilla, toffee, caramel, dark cherry and plum. Taste of molasses, bourbon, dark fruit, roasted malt, caramel, toffee, oak and maple. Full/medium body and light/medium carbonation. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Poured from the bottle, this beer has a dense, dark, and cloudy chestnut brown color with a crimson-tinged halo around the edges. The aroma is intensely woody, giving an impression of being in a pine forest at dusk after a storm. There is also a mild, fruity, cherry-like sweetness that wafts out from under the wood. The flavor is similarly rustic, with notes of charred wood and dark caramel, but any nuance to the flavor profile is difficult to appreciate under a substantial alcohol heat. Overall, though, despite some identifiable faults, the total experience with this beer is still satisfying.
Bottle to taster. Looks solid; a semi-transparent Brown with off-white lacing. Smells good; malt and bourbon. Tastes like it smells with a good mouthfeel. Nice!

Bottle. Thanks RamyG4 for this great beer. Pours hazy deep amber with a medium creamy beige head. The aroma is loads of barley and sweet caramel with notes of oak and vanilla bourbon. Ripe fruit and wood. Huge dark fruity flavour with heavy notes bourbon, toasted malt and has a warming alcoholic finish. Great!
Best scotch ale ever?  This may in fact be true.  Absolutely delicious.  So much complexity!
Taste is very soft and creamy. This is a hell of beer which makes you very happy while drinking it. The alcohol is well hidden.

2011 vintage 12 oz. bottle fairly hard poured into a Founders Brewing Company snifter.

Pours a dark amber with a two finger beige head. Good retention and noticeable lacing as the head recedes. A lot of bourbon on the nose with oak and toffee. Opens with a shot of bourbon, toffee, vanilla, and rich caramel maltiness. The mouthfeel is amazingly creamy, perfect carbonation, and frankly feels like velvet. A truly amazing brew that sets the standard for barrel-aged scotch ales.

2011 Vintage. Bottle at home courtesy of Armin, Thanks Man!! Poured a clear brown with a crimson tint and a small tan head that quickly dissipated. Coconut, bourbon, wood, light alcohol, and vanilla in the aroma. Taste is cocoa, dark fruits, licorice, dark chocolate, light espresso, and oak with a lingering coffee aftertaste. Mouthfeel is medium with soft carbonation. Very smooth, and well-balanced; really easy to drink.

Murky amber color with fleeting tan head. Big smooth whiskey, caramel aromas. Medium body with soft co2. Big boozy bourbon, wood char flavors with sharp caramel, pit fruits, boozy warming finish--boozy
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text: Big mouth feel, malt is amazing with a lingering sweetness. A great beer to sip on and enjoy.

Oh this is good. Pours dark tree branch brown. Very heavy malt, molasses, touches of bourbon.  Rolls thickly in the mouth with an alcohol edge. Nice finish. Dirty Bastard++

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Pours cola with no head. Smell strong bourbon vanilla and red fruit, bit of black licorice. Taste creamy woody flavors, malty scotch, dry finish. A bit of heat, but a lot of flavor, great beer.

Of the 1000+ beers in my journal this is the one which set the standard. My all time favorite beer. Its not only good, it is a beer with my name on it.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

25th October 2010Cloudy brown beer, very short lived tan head. Light effervescent palate, soft. Vanilla oak with a trace of butter cream. Perfect amount of bourbon, sweet cream and a little aniseed in the finish. Lovely.

Bottle (cellared for 2-3 years). Very strong bourbon and maple aromas. Light dirty brown color with little head. Heavy bourbon in initial, which continues in mid, and in final with warming alcohol. Medium body. Alcohol is well masked in general. Extremely pleasant stuff, if a bit one-dimensional.

Thanks to Adam for sharing this brew.

A: The beer has a brown transparent appearance, with tinges of crimson. There is a small head and a touch of lacing.

S: Scents include sweet malts, toffee, oak, and bourbon.

T: The beer packs some flavor. The initial taste brings oak and bourbon flavors, followed by a malty sweetness and peat from the scotch ale lurking beneath the wood and booze.

M: The feel is moderately thin, with a slight alcohol burn in the finish.

D: Drinkability is somewhat limited, as the strength and sweetness make this a slow sipper.

UPDATED: JUL 22, 2014 Draft at Khyber Pass in July 2012. Very dark orange amber with a thin fizzy head that mostly disappears. Looks identical to the non-barrel aged version (Dirty Bastard) but one whiff and you know your not in Kansas anymore. Big boozy bourbon barrel flavors pole vault out of the glass. Having just had the Dirty Bastard immediately prior, this one feels not so much "aged" but "infused" with Bourbon barrel goodness. The sweet crisp malts in the original are now flush with Bourbon. Maybe by a third. The addition tames the blunter notes. Certainly an improvement, but was still hoping for some darker notes. Huge alcohol here but finishes smooth. UPDATE: Having again at Khyber Pass in July 2014. My palate has improved far enough in just two years to better recognize that is one fantastic beer! Liked it from the start but after having 200 similar beers since then I can appreciate just how good this one is. Balanced and smooth despite the bourbon. Top notch!

Poured from a 12 oz. bottle into a tulip.

Backwoods Bastard pours a dark cherry brown color; there is a nice tint where the light sneaks through in the edge of the glass.  A bit of sediment gradually sinks to the bottom of the glass, and there is not much head to speak of on top.

Bourbon definitely comes through in the aroma.  Bourbon and oak coat a very malty base beer.  Caramel, maple, and smooth grains provide the base aroma.  

The flavor is strong, smooth, and reminds me of a bourbon barrel old ale (in a good way).  The bourbon is noticeable first, with sweet caramel, raisins, with a bit of molasses, peat, cocoa powder, and hazelnut as well.

The body is full and rich, with carbonation on the low side.  There is a very light alcohol burn on my tongue and in my throat, but I expect this in a 10% Wee Heavy.  There is a little bit of oily residue behind my lips after each sip.

This has less peat and smoke than other Scotch Ales, but being mistaken for a very good old ale is not a bad thing.  I distinctly enjoyed this beer and would like to have it again.

UPDATED: JAN 26, 2013 2011 vintage putting this bottle at about 8/9 months old. 12 oz bottle into a tulip glass. Wasnt a fan of this fresh so I decided to age a bottle. Reviewed on 07-10-2012.

A - Dark red/brown clear body. One finger high light khaki head settles down to a patchy cap and thick edging. Swirling produces a huge and tight head. Decent lacing and retention but massive alcoholic legs. 4.0/5

S - Bourbon soaked figs and raisins, roasted malts, vanilla, brown sugar, and toffee. Really decadent and rich with the perfect balance between the bourbon and dark fruit. 4.5/5

T - Bourbon soaked dark fruits and loads of scotch ale notes. Vanilla, toffee, and brown sugar. The finish is pretty abrupt with a light lingering sweetness. Theres also an odd bitterness after each sip that really goes against the sweet flavors. 3.5/5

M - Alcohol is well incorporated but it does warm the mouth at cellar temperature. Light to medium mouth feel with silky carbonation. 4.0/5

O - Age had does wonders on this beer. Crazy smooth and tasty. Not a fan of the bitterness in the aftertaste though. 3.88/5

---

2012 vintage, bottled on 10/12/12. 12 oz bottle into a Founders 15th Anniversary glass. Giving this a proper re-review since I now love this beer and style.

A - Pours a dark red/brown body that almost appears purple. This particular bottle is chill hazed with some floating protein particles. Ive had many bottles of this batch that were crystal clear though. Three fingers worth of tan foam fades away into a patchy cap with attractive silky bubbles. Sticky lacing with modest retention.

S - Such an amazing and inviting aroma. Gobs of rich and sweet english toffee with layers of vanilla, butterscotch, and oak. Brown sugar drenched raisins. Such a fantastic bourbon presence. 

T - Sweet toffee malts. Rich brown sugar and dates. Smooth bourbon with a noticeable but pleasant alcohol burn. Finishes with some butterscotch, vanilla oak and a touch of peat. Excellent.

M - Thin to medium with silky carbonation. Drinks wonderfully and the alcohol is complimentary but never over the top.

O - This has quickly become one of my favorite beers. Just bourbon drenched toffee perfection. Absolutely world class stuff.

Bottle 355 ml. Huge thanks to SourNotes for this one! Dark amber-brown. As expected, almost no head but beautiful fully lasting brown lacing. Aroma is dominated by bourbon with notes of oak, vanilla, caramel and smoke. Taste is also dominated by bourbon with woody notes, caramel, smoke, spices and vanilla. Strong warming alcohol Very nice sipper. This is a really good scotch ale. Bourbon may be a tad too present (it affects drinkability) but still bring this beer to another level. I would be interested to taste this beer with a couple of years under the belt to see if bourbon as mellowed and give the beer a better balance.

Pours a very dark amber color with a small amount of head.  Huge sweet boozy aroma.  Caramel malt, bourbon, smoke, and toffee aromas.  Taste is very sweet but balances nicely with bourbon smokey flavor.  Medium body with a very chewy mouthfeel.  A noticable alcohol burn on the finish which leaves a sweet caramel malt flavor on the tongue along with some smoke too.  Definitely a sipper with tons of bourbon flavor.  Glad I finally got to try this.

Quite thin for 10.2%. 
Good nose of Carmel, vanilla, and coconut.  Taste follows nose
Issue was palate as was quite thin and watery. Thought barrel propped up the base beer

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours a rich amber with no head. Aroma is overpowered by bourbon. Taste follows. If you like bourbon you will like this. Rich bourbon

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

On draft at Prohibition Taproom.  Pours brown and hazy with fluffy tan head.  Aroma is sweet malts with caramel, toffee, vanilla, sweet brown sugar, smoked peet, and bourbon.  Solid mouthfeel with a boozy aftertaste.

UPDATED: SEP 7, 2015 
35,5 cl bottle @ home. Rated on 18.06.2011
Aroma is sweet with lots of malt, some caramel and sour cream. Flavour is really sweet with malt, caramel, toffee and vanilla. One can observe also the oaky notes here. Sticky and sweet stuff.

8+4+6+3+15 = 3.6


35,5 cl bottle @ home. Rated on 06.09.2015
A tad too sweet still, even though alcohol balances the equation here without becoming too sharp (it is close to that though). And the barrell aromas are nice here, they just seem to build up the sweetness...

8+3+7+4+15=3.7

This is the beer that started it all for me. My brother gave me a bottle and said something along the lines of "This could change your life." Up to that point, I enjoyed Jack Daniels and various large batch brews. Then. I. Tried. Founders.

Game over. Now, I pine for the day that I can "happen upon" the KBS or CBS, or make a pilgrimage to the brewery. And, Ill have the beercation, soon.

I had a bottle (capped 2/10) of Backwoods Bastard in a pint glass, slightly warmed by my hands and consumed over time.

A: 4.0. I loved the gorgeous amber color, with hints of deep red. Very little head, some bubbles and a smell that made you pull your head towards the glass.

S: 5.0. Where has this taste been all of my life? I was weaned on Jack Daniels and have recently found Makers Mark to be the ultimate in a good drink. But, to find a beer that provides the bourbon taste without being too boozy or too pretentuous? This changed everything.

T: 5.0. Everything that I look for in a superior taste ... with each sip, I would pause my conversation, say "wow" and then relax for a moment. 

M 4.0. The taste the experience and the flavor made the mouthfeel darn near perfec.

O: 4.5. After this beer, I started to listen to my brother, watch reviews online and pine for another "good beer."

Why would anyone drink a Bud after having this type of beverage? (Ill never know!)

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 11-05-2011 01:15:10

Pour from bottle into tulip. Dark red/brown with medium head.  Boozy, boozy bourbon aroma caused me to wonder if this would taste like a shot and a beer.  It was very smooth, but I thought the booze overwhelmed the first sips.  Then the flavor came through: slightly syrupy sweetness, oak, vanilla, more bourbon, and some typical Scotch ale malt/peat.  A very unique taste. Left me feeling warm and fuzzy.

Aged bottle from cellar - have had this fresh and remember enjoying it, but didnt take any notes.  Pours an opaque deep reddish brown with a very thin off white head that doesnt stick around for the party.  Aroma is a bit subdued, probably due to the age...some sweet bourbon, candied fruit and caramel in there.  Flavor is nice and easy going...bourbon up front, definitely some dark fruit, brown sugar...and some alcohol is still around.  Palate is full bodied but not overwhelming, as this one drinks quite easily at this point in its life.  Nice offering - some day Id like to give it a try on tap!

UPDATED: JUL 13, 2012 Multiple bottles and drafts, this review is a recent bottle. This beer on tap a couple years ago was out of hand. Still good but a slight letdown. Pours a deep and murky brown pour, zero headn tiny bit of lacing. Aromas really are single malt scotch, other notes of bourbon, oak, caramel, nuts, some dark plum hidden in their. Taste was cherry malts, buttery oak, chocolate, bourbon, figs, and some subtle spice. Great beer.
Draft. Hazy golden color, small white head. Aroma of summer fruit and caramel. Taste is boozy fruit and sweet malt. Boozy!

Originally reviewed: 4/6/09. Pours a tawny deep maroon. Very thick and cloudy (yeast?). No light comes through this beer at all. Smells of caramel, chocolate, oak, licorice, molasses. This is a full nose for sure. Mouthfeel is thick and syrupy, almost chewable. Yet there was a slight crispness to it. Flavor is of syrup, booze, some woodsy notes, and big bourbon smack. This wasnt what I expected at all. Way too boozy and thick for my liking. Interesting beer.

This beer has the pure aroma of bourbon.  Smells fantastic!  Pours a deep brown/amber... almost matches the color of the bottle perfectly.  Very little to no head, just a touch around the edge of the glass.  Bourbon is apparent at first sip.  Alcohol is mostly covered up, but a bit of heat does come through.  A tiny bit of sweetness is in no way overwhelming and balances nicely with a bit of hops that comes through on the back.  Has a wood-like taste that is pleasant.  Overall a great sipper, very delicious.  Its a little bit ale and a little bit stout-like.
