UPDATED: JAN 21, 2011 Bottle pours dark brown with thin off-white head.  Malty aroma.  Sweet taste with bourbon, malts, scotch, caramel, vanilla, oak.  Palate thick bordering on syrupy.  Finish brief with a little hops.  Alcohol apparent.

Nice, almost has a barley wine feel to it.

Poured from a 12oz bottle from Tytoanderson.  Thanks Bro!  Pours a very dark brown with minimal head...lots of lacing.  Aroma is vanilla, bourbon, and smoked peat.  Taste is loads of vanilla, bourbon, brown sugar.  Smooth and very drinkable at 10.2%  This is an amazing example of the Scotch Ale style.  Awesome stuff.  It is right up there with Alesmith Wee Heavy and Meantime Scotch Ale.

Burgandy color but no head. Definite aroma of the oak barrels; sweet but heavier like a red wine.  Slight bitter (but enjoyable) taste with hints of coconut. Feels heavy on the palate with an almost perfect amount of carbonation. This is an outstanding and unique beer. I sometimes hesitate when giving ratings this high, but I cannot justify going any lower. Great selection!

Bottle pours hazy burnt copper with a tan head.  Aroma is boozy with notes of bourbon, caramel, and a touch of peat smoke.  Flavor shows the same with the oak making its appearance as well as brown sugar, vanilla, and bourbon soaked cherries.  Overall body is moderate, with an underlying sweetness and nice warming alc on the finish.  MMMM.

Mmmm....pours nice dark brown.  Aroma is of what else?  Bourbon.  Taste is like drinking carbonated bourbon.  Very tasty if you love bourbon.  If you dont like bourbon?  Dont waste your time or money.
Poured dark with decen head smelled and tasted sweet oaky vanilla and bourbon with aftertaste of bourbon

Bottle: Pours a brown/amber color with modest head. I had this brew on tap at a tasting event and it blew my mind. On bottle was no different really - I think this brew is incredible, really. It is a symphony of Scotch, Oak (It doesnt dominate at all ;) ) Big caramel malts, smoke is questionable, and dark cherries is quite questionable but either way. Amazing.

UPDATED: NOV 15, 2013 Mid brown with a warm-hued brown head.  smells very strongly of oak, vanilla, bourbon- old grandad (as expected I suppose).  Flavor is the same, completely dominated by the oak character, with a bit of rye bread mixed in there at the end.

Update:  Difficult to drink this one in large quantities.  More Bourbon than oak this time around, less sweet seeming that the regular bastard.  Deserves more credit than I gave it.
Though a little too sweet, this was quite the excellent bb stout. Had one and wanted more. Unfortunately, couldnt find any in the liquor stores.

Bottle From Downer Wine & Spirits.  Pours a dark amber with pretty much no head.  Aroma is all bourbon.  Medium feel on the palate with nice carbonation.  Taste is a pleasant balance of bourbon, malt, and alcohol.  Its a shame this is a limited release.

12oz btl. Pours super dark copper with a nice frothy tan head. Awesome aroma of dark fruit, maple syrup, and caramel. Awesome body, smooth and sweet molasses with a nice dark fruit raisin underbelly. The maltiness is so sweet without being too rich which I love.The whiskey comes through in the finish with a tasty, spicy and lasting warmth. Not overpoweringly hot but just pleasant. That syrup comes through so sweet after it goes down, I dig it. My perty mouth cant get enough. Got to get another bottle.

UPDATED: NOV 14, 2012 12oz bottle - Wow!  Butterscotch, scotch, caramel, and yes, dark cherries are in there as well.  Just fantastic.  I treated this like I was drinking a scotch, even poured into a nice snifter.

pours a dark reddish caramel color with a one fibger tan like creamy head. aroma is strong scotch and bourbon with vanilla, cherry, and caramel. flavor is the same as aroma but stronger. leaves some nice lacing and probably one of the best barrel aged beers I have had. very nice and I wish this was as readily available like dragons milk.

This old mans a badass. Aroma is thick with the single malt scotchs barrel age to the point of overpowering, but the overall aroma is intoxicating by itself with a smoky, roasty malt brilliance. Head is amber and the brew itself is a deep golden brown. The taste is heavily muscled with roasty malts and scotch. Finishes on the palate like a shot of old Glenfiddich. This is definitely an evening ending monster. A fantastic concoction.

2010 bottle.  Pours a dark copper, brown color with a white head that goes away quickly.  Aroma is whiskey, oak, vanilla, and quite sweet.  Wow, this smells good.  Taste is malty and oak, with a little bit of bourbon coming through.  Very warming.  Texture is thin and a little sticky.  Nice finish.  I look forward to this one every year.

UPDATED: NOV 8, 2010 Appearance - Pours a dark ruby, thin head dissipates quickly. Smell - bourbon right off the top, and the dark cherries are prominent. Taste - Wow, you can REALLY taste the BOURBON. In fact, thats about all I can taste. Palate - Dry, bourbon and water. Medium bodied. Overall - I wish I didnt buy a 4-pack. If you love bourbon then you might love this beer. I do like bourbon, but this is not what I was expecting.  ***UPDATE*** What a difference 3 days makes. I drank this tonight as my 4th beer. Already buzzed, this tasted pretty damn good! A bit maltier than last time. Weird... I upgraded the ratings to reflect my newfound appreciation.

UPDATED: NOV 11, 2010 On draught @ Cypress Street, then had some out of the bottle.  Poured a murky brown with a tight light beige head with good retention from the tap, from the bottle not much of a head was produced.  Bourbon was the center piece, huge on the aroma, even more in the flavors.  The aroma, aside from mass amounts of bourbon contained some caramel, maybe some wood and hot booze.  This stuff was so bourbon heavy that it was hard to detect anything else.  There were subtle notes of sweet malts, maybe some raisins.  Almost no bitterness, some heat in the finish all while being smooth.  I still think Full Sails BB Black Gold takes the cake for the biggest bourbon bomb I have come across but this is a close second.  Its huge but nothing so overpowering its undrinkable.  This has become one of my new favorite brews, bourbon to the extreme but done in such a way that created a total winner.  I will continue to drink this stuff throughout the winter, should go hand in hand.

2 ounce bottle that was in my cellar -- no date found on the bottle -- but I believe this was 1-2 years old. Poured into a Founders snifter/tulip glass. Muddy dark brown, thin head recedes quickly. Big notes of bourbon, alcohol and a little rum. Thats pretty much all I smell. Starts with a little alcohol and malty sweetness. Some dark fruity flavors mix in with just a bit of tartness. Beer finishes with a little sourness notes. Medium to full bodied, some carbonation provides a tingly feeling in the mouth.
Overall a little disappointed -- not sure if the beer just doesnt age well, but the tart sour notes were a bit unpleasant and I would think unintentional.

2009 vintage...

Clearish brown pour.  A bit of tan head.

Aroma and flavor are VERY heavy on the whiskey - a bit too much for my taste to be honest.  This is one of the biggest bourbon bombs Ive ever had - to the point where it tastes less like beer and more like liquor to me.  Not bad, but not my favorite by any means.

It does have a very nice smooth mouthfeel, but overall not something Im going to be seeking out again.

Very strong but wonderful scotch forward nose with smoke and caramel undertones.  Clear amber color, little head.  Heavily sweet with a very mildly bitter back of tongue bite.  You could session this, if you want to end up passed out in a snowbank.

bottle(s) from Illini08.  a somewhat murky brown with a fast fading head, little lace.  aroma is all about the barrel with oak, vanilla, a hint of smoke and of course the bourbon.  flavor is more of the same with some peat making an appearance.  Ive always liked a good scotch ale and this one fits the bill!

Probably shouldnt have cracked this 10.2 ABV monster so late in the night, but its been taunting me from the fridge for a while now.  Sweet cherry malt and a light mintiness on the nose.  Lots of wood and alcohol grows as it breathes.  WOW what a great burst of unexpected fantastic flavors.  The nose gives no hint of how much is going on in the glass.  Big smooth nuttiness and alcohol.  Malty creamy chocolate and deep cherry.  Alcohol and vanilla and all around loveliness.  Damn this is good. And BTW, I rated this before I read the bottle or description above.

26-09-10 bouteille provenant du kentucky (thanks to my boys): Couleur brun-rouge, limpide, tout en étant légèrement trouble avec quelques minuscules particules en suspension. Puissants aromes boisés de chenes et de vanille. Moyennement sucrée, légèrement amer et tres boisé. Je serais curieux de gouter a cette biere sans le vieillissement en fut de chenes. Elle est relativement douce en bouche, avec une légère effervescence et une finale moyennement astrigente. Offre des saveurs de fruits rouge avec une touche de miel, mais le boisé prend pratiquement toute la place. Tres bonne biere.
Pours a bright ruby red, nose is super boozy. Tastes too much of whiskey, super dry, lacks amber character.

Bottle courtesy Sean.  Fresh bourbon, slightly roasted malt, scotch, and light oak in the aroma.  Peat-like taste with raisin alcohol notes.  Malt and caramel come through more as it warms and the finish remains clean.  Some sweet fruit noticeable just before the finish.
Pours dark with a slight head. Sweet at first sip, with warm malts and slight caramel taste, then a bourbon and coffee finish. Definitely a sipping beer at 10.2%
Big nose, slight bourbon nose, vanilla oak, malty sweetness. Flavor is sweet malt, some caramel with hints of bourbon, a tinge of alcohol as it warms. A little thin in the mouth.
Bottle split with Jredmond.   Dont remember a hell of a lot, but this was really nice for style.   Alcohol hidden very well.

12oz bottle.  Poured a hazy reddish amber color with a small white head.  The smell is bourbon and cola.  The taste follows suit with mellowed bourbon and sweet cola flavors.  Im not really a scotch ale guy, but it you can hide 10%abv in something this well, then Im onboard the down bound train...

Holy crap, this is tasty.  If you the regular old Dirty Bastard, then you will love this. It is like regular bastard with a pile of comlex oakiness, vanilla, bourbon... Too much to explain.  Each sip is different and complex.  This stuff is amazing!

Must have poured it a bit too vigorously, lots of particulate matter floating about in a murky red suspension. The barest hint of a head, even after the apparently too vigorous pour. The miasma, in a good way, from this backwoods swamp is sweet, earthy, and all Scotland. Not Islay-peaty but mainland. The flavor is more Kentucky than Scotland. Bourbon sweetness (dont think of Scotch as sweet), woody-vanilla fun-times. A mouth-full, swish, swish, coat the teeth, and linger.

2009 vintage bottle thanks to my son, Keith (fata2683) poured into a tulip glass.  Reddish dark brown body with thick tan head.  Every sip brought a new experience to my taste buds.  So many flavors;  semi-sweet chocolate covered cherries, caramel, brown sugar, roasted coffee beans, and more.  Absolutely delicious.  Need more of this.

Bottle. 12 oz. Split with James, Dallas, and Tony. Pours a hazy brown with a creamy beige head. Aroma of toffee, caramel, sweet malts, brown sugar, scotch, pepper, and cream. Medium bodied with a rich, warm palate. Nice boozy finish. Excellent scotch ale.

UPDATED: NOV 29, 2014 Bottle split with Dallas, Pat, and Big Tony. Pours a hazy ruby amber body with slight off white lacing. Aroma is maple, light alcohol, sweet nuts and malt. Mouthfeel is amazingly creamy - tastes like drinking caramel down a wooden luge. Sweet maple and molasses on the palate. Great Scotch.
Had with the guys via Jamess generosity. Pour is clear medium amber. Little head and minor lacing. Aroma is whisky alcohol and wood. Flavor is smooth but strong. Favor of wood chips and nuts.

12oz traded bottle from 2009. Dark brown pour with ruby highlights. Pretty lively but only a small off-white head and a little lacing. Aroma is sweeter malt and some molasses, plus some darker fruits like plums/prunes with just a hint of whisky. The taste is where the bourbon and vanilla really show up for me. Pretty nice and the 10+ ABV is well hidden until a little warming in the finish.

UPDATED: MAR 21, 2011 Poured from a bottle with a bottled on date of 10/27/09.
Pours a nice deep caramel color with a slight tan head, not too much carbonation it seems. Heads settles down fairly quickly.
Wow! Smell that bourbon barrel age right off the bat. Followed by caramel, malty aroma. Maybe its just me but kind of smells like banana too.
Bite of the tongue on the first sip. Strong flavor from the barrel aging process following by a meduim/heavy malt taste. Slightly bitter aftertaste followed by alcohol. Very little hop flavor which would be correct for this style. 
Similiar to Fouders Dirty Bastard but with an added kick of the bourbon barrel!
Re-rate: cracked another 09 bottle on 3/25/11, pours a deep copper brown color with a 1 1/2 tan head that leaves nice lace as it settles. The aroma is really subdued from what it was originally with notes of vanilla, barrel, and dark fruit. The flavor is much more mellow as well. Caramel, raisin, with a nice bourbon touch. Still awesome!

Thanks to savvy1982 for the share. Pours a dark red with almost no head. The aroma is quite malty with bourbon, oak, butterscotch, plums, figs, coconut there as well. The flavor has a nice oaky bite and a long sweet finish. Really nice. 10%... Wow, where did that go?
Bottle at a recent BA/RB tasting...  Poured dark reddish/amber with a tan head.  Plummy, boozy, bourbon, burnt toffee and brown sugar, oak, malted grains all swirling together nicely here.
Now this is a great beer! So much better than just dirty bastard. Big, rich, complex. Very good!

The aroma is bourbon or whiskey. Pours a dark reddish brown with a light brown head, creamy and mostly diminishing, virtually no lacing. The taste is sweet with some bitter, some bourbon taste. the body is medium, the texture creamy, the carbonation soft and the finish long.  Needs more aging in my opinion.
12 oz bottle provided by DuffManSW. Rating #557. Clear dark amber pour with a white head. Caramel maltiness in the nose. Sweet more caramelly flavors and some bourbon notes, good stuff. (1238)
user_location: Redlands, by way of Wisconsin,, California, USA

text: Bottle, thanks to fata2683. Pours hazy garnet, extremely thin head doesnt stick around; very soft carbonation. Saying the lacing is spotty is being kind. Nose is coconut/bourbon, red fruit, some malt; nice and woody. Flavors are rich, with more coconut and fruit, and a very slight brandyish character which is drying and keeps the beer in balance. Very nice and unexpected. Lovely.
a heavy and complex brew with strong aroma of alcohol and hops.  it has a gotcha flavor that is very malty and hoppy.  a wonderful barley wine.
Reddish amber colour thin head. Amazing arome very fruity and aromatic. Flavours of coconut and sweet malt, dark fruits, oak and scotch, but the coconut really stands out this is a fantasic brew!!
12 ounce bottle-hazy brown pour-small almost non-existent lite brown head-aroma and taste of bourban,caramel, vanilla,brown sugar-nice sweet bitter bourban finish

murky brownish color, little to no head, nose is bourbon, vanilla, oak and brown sugar. flavor is smooth with all the noted above flavors and a minimal alcohol burn mouth feel was silky. really nice.. at brewpub

He appeared in my glass dressed in rich murky browns, much like old musty wood that has seen many years of luscious bourbon aging in her round depths. A small head immediately fades into a khaki ringlet while a splotchy film tries and fails to cover her surface. A few swirls produce a decent showing of lace, but even better, a huge belch of bourbony proportions.


Mm bourbon. A moment please Thank you. Ok, and now we return to our regularly scheduled program.


Wood and spice, cinnamon and nutmeg specifically, are followed by candy apples, plums, raisins, and even more bourbon. Did I mention there is lots of bourbon in this beer? A flourish of vanilla extract and root leads into a warm tickle at the back of my nose right before I wrap thirsty lips around her liquid bounty. My first impression is of how well balanced his palate is. Bourbon sweetness and warmth is immediately evident, but not overpowering. Vanilla, cinnamon, and dry wood mingle atop giddy tastebuds, lingering long after each quaff. As he warms, the dryness spreads warm tendrils throughout my body, and each quaff is a soothing repeat of the last. Not as complex as some bourbon barrel aged ales, the apples, prunes, and raisins flitter in and out, weaving a dark fruit delight with apply sass throughout his palate. Exquisite, and even better, sessionable. Ill take another one, please.


Founders, how I love thee, why arent you in Florida? Just remembering this beer is making me thirsty. Just as with all Founders beers, should you stumble across this particular option, take home a sixer, or 12pack. Why err on the side of less when you could take home more.

UPDATED: OCT 28, 2010 09, courtesy of badnewsbeers, thanks! tried next to dirty bastard and this one takes the the cake. the bourbon adds a faint candy like caramel and cotton candy flavor to the aroma and taste. ive had this one several times, but waqs waiting to try it next to the regular to rate it. this is a well rounded maltinator, and the baing adds very nicely. founders proves to know what they are doing, yet again. 

re-rate,  one of my favorites. not a five, but just so damned reliable and so fuggin tasty.

(bottle) Mahogany body with thin, vanishing off-white head. Very aromatic: caramel, alcohol, wood, bourbon. Body is medium to full, oily, and soft carbonation - very nice.  Flavor is strong with alcohol, but it remains smooth and very drinkable (minimal burn). Flavor is pretty sweet; vanilla, caramel, wood, bourbon.

A- Body appears to be a dark brown color. Pours with a minimal <1/2 finger head that immediately fades to a very thin collar and no lacing is left behind in the glass. When held up to the light one can see that this is actually.

S- Sweet bourbon with an alcohol burn on the nostrils balances well with the dark malt profile offered by this Scottish ale. Sweet, like molasses and a chocolate presence added with bourbon sweetness and burn. Nice..

T-Upfront is a bit of roasted (but not quite bitter) malt that offsets the sweet caramel and bourbon flavors going on. The finish adds a touch of dark chocolate to what is already going on along with a bourbon alcohol burn. The bitterness is very well hidden the entire way through and the character of this beer is complex, slightly sweet, and very warm.

P- Low to medium carbonation and a body made up mostly of somewhat thick, very smooth, caramel and dark malt. Goes down very easily.

O- The more I acquaint myself to them the more I am loving Scotch Ales. This is a darn good one. The bourbon is a perfect compliment to this beer and I think its great. The alcohol is definitely not hidden...but it is not obnoxious either. Wonderful and definitely my favorite Founders brew! IMO, it easily Trumps Breakfast Stout and KBS. Wasnt expecting this to be so good!

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 01-15-2009 03:47:16
(12oz bottle via trade with BA gratefulbeerhead) clear copper with no real head. Nose of caramel, toasty grains, and light alcohol. Taste of metal, berries, caramel and lightly toasted grain.

I poured this and was distracted from noticing color and head by the aroma, which was bourbon and oak.  Flavor is Scotch ale lifted up with vanilla and oak, and pretty strong bourbon notes.  Alcohol is definitely there. Top notch. One of my all-time favorites.

On tap at Capones. Dark mahogany. Really nice brown sugar, caramel and vanilla aromas. Caramel and bourbon flavors. Medium-to-full body with a syrupy mouthfeel. Sweet with a somewhat abrupt finish.  Ill definitely be trying this one in the bottle.

This is the second time Ive had this but first time rating, I think this one is a little bit older than the previous one I had but that is a good thing in this case.  Tons of vanilla and oak in the aroma with hints of bourbon and maple. It smells like one of those amazing breakfasts with tons of waffles and pure maple syrup... The taste holds all those aromas in well and almost mimics what you smell. This ale is enjoyable and not overpowering in any way, I would say this is one you want to return to over and over again!

Dark red brown colored beer with a slight tan head. Didnt get a ton out of the aroma, mostly sweet malt, vanilla, and some booze.  Flavour was full of malts, some bourbon flavours. Pretty sweet malts but not sugary or syurpy. Very enjoyable and a nice lively body.

12oz bottle from CBX. Pours a dark reddish brown color with almost no head at all. Distinct bourbon smell, but not overly powerful. Of course the initial taste is bourbon. The thing I like about this beer though is that its not a giant slap in the face with the bourbon. Even though its very distinct, it doesnt make you feel like your drinking straight bourbon. Its a smooth, mild flavor. I could drink a few of these without getting sick of them. Good beer.
Brown frothy head, sweet, but not too much, whiskey, nice finish, likable, will buy again, would recommend - a nice heady brew.

Deep red-brown color; clear and perty. Vanilla, oak, rich caramel malt aroma, though the bourbon nose kind of takes over. Big whiskey flavor, oak and vanilla, with a bit of smoke. Smooth and full body. Tasty, though a bit too much on the whiskey. Good bitter finish. Not near as good as the regular Dirty Bastard.

Bottle: Poured a murky purplish brown with no head, aroma of bourbon, vanilla, oak, sweet dark fruits, and caramel. Flavor is moderately sweet, some plum, oak, vanilla. Alcohol finish. Interesting beer.

Bottle purchased at Corral Liquors in Granite City.
  Pours dark brown with an aroma of toffee and bourbon.  Smooth and creamy with a mild sweet bourbon taste.     Yummy!

What a nice treat.  Fantastic aroma of bourbon.  Reminded me of a scotch ale aged in bourbon barrels.  I got a four pack and savored every bottle.  I poured it in a small wine glass and enjoyed first the rich aroma and then the deep flavors that this brew had to offer.  Oak, bourbon and complex and interesting malt flavors.  I want more!

Pretty good beer. Dark brown pour. Malt, bourbon, black licorice, smokey, nuts, coffee, dark dried fruits. Pretty well balanced, but i think it was a bit too creamy/thick in the mouth as the sweetness was a touch too strong for my liking. Still an excellent example of this style.

Thanks to pantanap. Dark brown with a small white head. Nose is whiskey, malts, sweetness, and light hops. Taste of whiskey, some malts, sweetness, and upfront alcohol. Body is a bit thin.Taste lingers. Sort of one dimensional but tasty.
user_location: Seattle still not near Beersel., Washington, USA

text: UPDATED: MAR 15, 2010 12oz bottled on Nov 16, 2009.  Served in a Duvel tulip at cool room temperature.  Pours copper brown with a two finger beige head that reduces to a foamy ring and light cap, leaves some nice lacing.  Aroma is wow, big time vanilla and oak, bourbon/whiskey, alcohol, a bit of caramel and chocolate, wood is the centerpiece of the aroma, smells of a woodworking shop.  Flavor is rich caramel, chocolate, cherries, vanilla, oak, bourbon, mild alcohol but pretty smooth considering the bottles young age.  Some sweetness overall.  Mouthfeel is rich and smooth, very full, low carbonation.  Damn, this is a treat.  Im already a huge fan of Dirty Bastard and the bourbon barrel aging is blended so well in this one, particularly balanced in the flavor.  More, please!

UPDATED: NOV 3, 2010 Initial Rating 3/3/2010 from the 2009 batch

Pours deep mahogony.  Nice head fades to good lacing.  Nose is slightly fruity, with a nice quantity of oak, and a bit of malt.  Thicker mouthfeel, moderate carbonation, slightly oily, has a hit of alcohol but not as much as youd expect with the ABV.  Slight sweetness, moderately bitter, balanced flavor with that nice rich oak and bourbon backend.  The barrel character isnt overstated, though, its present without being dominant or distracting. Well-played, Founders.
8/5/8/5/16 - 4.2

2010 bottle, tasted moments after hitting 55F

Pours incredibly deep ruby, practically chocolate.  Highly active carbonation but only a moderate head, tons of gorgeous actively bubbling lacing though.  The nose is almost all bourbon, and a little hot, with the familiar notes of Dirty Bastard playing in the distant background.  Super-creamy, a little oily, solid hints of bitter in the back of the palate to counter-balance a lot of sweet bourbon and malt on the front.  Whisky burn is quite present on the finish.  Goddamn this stuff smells awesome.
9/5/8/4/18 - 4.4

  Im going to taste the 2009 and the 2010 side by side soon and give an adjusted grade at some point.  Right now Im averaging the grades of the 2009 as rated and the 2010 fresh.

this beer was really unexpected. It was almost like a lightly carbonated scotch or whiskey. That might not seem appealing, but it was excellent. Very enjoyable, definately dont want to have more than one or two, or else you might get into some trouble. Very pricey. Like $14.99 a 4pk. But worth trying

Pours a deep brown with small head.  Aroma was dominated by bourban, burnt oak, toffee with a hint of vanilla.  The bourban smell dominates, comes through potently in the taste.  Taste is slightly sweet with a dry finish. This is certainly a beer that grows on you.  Very nice.

This marks the 100th beer I have rated.  On tap at Capones.  Pours a dark chocolate brown color.  Has an aroma of grapefruit, caramel, vanilla, and toffee.  Toffee leads the way on taste as well.  The oak flavor is also powerful.  Has a whiskey feel.  Enjoyed it.

Bottle from a trade with phaleslu. Pours cloudy dark caramel color with light khaki head. Aroma of bourbon, vanilla and oak. Flavor is lots of bourbon, vanilla, chocolate, roasted malts and oak. Lots of earth and wood notes. Medium to full body with soft carbonation and a smooth, creamy mouthfeel. Very nice. Thanks Peter.

Deep red amber color with thin,big bubbled beige head that disappeared by the end of the drink.  The nose is all about the bourbon, with rich butterery wood notes.  Whatever beer they started with is pretty much subsumed by the barrel.  Bourbon, wood, fresh campfire smoke, and vanilla all float over whatever it was they but in this barrel.  If you do not like bourbon, dont get this.

Pours a rich amber color with an off-white head.  Nose full of trappist-style malts and woods, fruity vanilla, and some of those classic whiskey aromas.  THICK creamy bourbon heavy palette.  Smooth with real vanilla cream flavor on it.  Surprising and delicious!
Aroma is brown sugar. Pour is brown with tan head and clinging lace. Flavor is brown sugar, vanilla, dried fruit, cherry, abv. Full bodied with light carbonation. A very nice beer

Thanks to Exiled for sharing this bottle. 

The beer pours a dark brownish-red with a  small white head. The aroma is awesome, lots of cherry, vanilla and bourbon. The flavor is just as great, with the same cherry, vanilla and bourbon notes, with the vanilla being the most dominant flavor. There is very little detectable alcohol. The mouthfeel is medium and the carbonation is low.
Excellent Scoth ale.  The alcohol is remarkably well hidden.  A great beer to have with a book by a fire.  This beer warms the body and is quite enjoyable.

Draft at Capones; I hope you like bourbon (I do!); Aroma is of bourbon and vanilla; mouthfeel reminds you that this isnt for the weak of heart; chestnut-like color with no head; contrary to the commercial description, I didnt think it was a "sipper"; the faster I drank it, the smoother it got; I would definitely get it again under the right circumstances

On tap at Capones. Can you say whiskey? Aroma in the glass is of a nice sipping whiskey. Taste really shows it was stored in bourbon barrels. Interesting, but not what I wanted when I ordered a beer sampler.

Aroma is of bourbon and  oak, with some alcohol and malt.  Taste is a blend of bourbon and malted ale.  Smooth on the palate. Initially sweet and finishes earthy and boozy.  Overall this is a fantastic beer that expands the genre of scotch ales.
Cloudy as hell; heavy bourbon and rum liqueur aroma, cherries and oak. Barleywine country. Not for the weak.

A: Backwoods Bastard pours a cloudy, muddled amber/brown color with pretty much no foam.

S: This certainly smells like a fine liquor. A lot of bourbon and vanilla. There is also a very strong oak aroma.

T: The taste has many of the same characteristics of the nose. A lot of oak, vanilla, bourbon, and maybe a touch of chocolate. There is also a bitterness in there somewhere.

M: Very smooth, creamy, and full bodied. The carbonation is on the low side.

D: I was expecting to be blown away by booze, but it really was quite manageable. That said, you still feel it after enjoying a bottle.

Pours murky amber brown with an off white head.  Aroma is bourbon, vanilla, oak, caramel and a little bit of chocolate.  Flavor is a rich blend of caramel, oak, bourbon, and velvety vanilla.  This beer has a lot of bourbon character, but isnt too overpowering.  Pretty good.

Poured from a 12oz. bottle into a tulip glass.

Pours a dark mohogany color with slight burnt orange highlights.
Very small amount of head thats thin and disappears quickly leaving little to no lacing.

Smell has a very strong alcohol presence. Very much vanilla and chocolate liquor. I can smell the oak from the barreling and i can get some of the bourbon notes as well.

Theres a lot of complexities as far as flavor. I can taste, chocolate, figs, dates, molasses, bosc pear, sour apple, banana, oak, and a touch of vanilla. Alcohol is very noticable and not hidden at all. Very much bourbon like.

Mouthfeel is a bit heavy. Lots of alcohol on the tongue and on the swallow.

Drinkability is below average on this one. I doubt i could or would want to drink more then one of these backwoods bastards. Not that its a bad beer. Theres just a bit too much alcohol presence then i can enjoy.
I would recommend this to someone who enjoys scotch. This is definately a sipper.

#900. 12oz bottle from Binnys River Grove. Pours lightly hazed dark brown with small tan head that leaves a tan rings on the edges of my glass. Aromas of bourbon, vanilla, caramel, sweet malts, toffee, and some dark fruits. Flavors of  bourbon, vanilla, sweet malts, caramel, toffee, bit of smoke, some dark fruits, and a bit of booze. Finishes with some light smoke and alcohol. Mouthfeel is medium and has nice carbonation for a BA beer of this size. Really nice balance between bourbon barrel and the scotch ale flavors.  I liked regular bastard but this is taken to another level. Really good stuff.

Pours a dark brown with a darkened white head.  Aroma is a bit of the bourbon booze, but comes through with the sweet roasted malts one expects with a scotch ale.  That is to say that in the aroma the bourbon isnt overwhelming in the least.  Flavor is up front with the bourbon, but in the finish brings up some nice smoky notes.  Over all a full creamy texture to it and a solid finish.  Pretty good beer.

12oz bottle. Pours deep red with a small tan ring of lacing. Aroma is of bourbon, alcohol, vanilla, malt, caramel, and dark fruit. Taste starts off with a sharp alcohol bite and dark fruit. Underneath the strong raisin and alcohol taste is bourbon, vanilla, and caramel. Has a very malty backbone that is buried underneath all the alcohol until it warms. Lingering taste of wood and bourbon. Very nice warming alcohol effect. Its better with a little age to ease the booziness. Good beer though.

Pours a deep, dark red with a cream colored head that clings to the glass. Aromas of bourbon, alcohol, vanilla, caramel, oak, and tart cherries. Silky smooth on the palate. Initially sweet and finishes earthy and boozy. This is a fantastic bourbon-barrel aged scotch ale. A real sipper that is carnival for the senses.

big thanks to cavie for this bottle.  poured a deep amber with an off white head.  aroma was huge with caramel, bourbon, and malts.  flavor was bourbon, raisin, and caramel with a medium-full body with a bit of oak on the finish.

Bottle courtesy of drowland and RCL. Clear ruby red pour. Aroma is spicy bourbon with wood and candle perfume. Aroma is awesome. Taste is dry with sweet maple. Some bourbon and woody flavors. Not as great as the nose but it has lovely flavors. Spiced and nice.

Bottle that Adam brought to an impromptu tasting with some work friends.  Pours a clear ruby brown, with a touch of a thin beige head.  Bourbon, vanilla, wood, sweet maple.  Smooth vanilla and caramel malt.  Sweet on the finish with more vanilla.  Tasty stuff.

Bottle.  Clear dark maple syrup brown pour, medium carbonation and a very sweet, syrupy malt and bourbon.  Flavor was like Three Floyds Robert the Bruce on steroids, amped up sweet caramel, heavy malts, herbs and finished with very little heat and a nice bourbon aftertaste.  Very good, even though this style is generally hit or miss for me.

Draft at capones. Pours dark ruby with a thin lacy tan head. Aroma of bourbon, caramel, vanilla and oakiness. Flavor is nice and complex with sweet caramel, bourbon, oaky vanilla and had a bit of toffee with a creamy warming boozy finish.

12oz. bottle.  Sweet, malty, oaky and earthy aroma, plenty of brown sugar, bourbon and vanilla to be found, along with lighter notes of caramel, alcohol and peat.  Clear, dark red-brown color, head subsides to a fine, light tan ring around the edge of the snifter.  Flavor is absolutely rife with bourbon character, showing through at all times amidst the toasty, sweet, sticky malts, light cherry, charcoal and vanilla tones, light, spicy hop bitterness, and the warming, peppery alcohol presence, drying to an extent before the end.  Palate is thick, smooth and low in effervescence, body is quite substantial.  Some esters appearing very late.  Somehow manages to maintain balance and even a degree of drinkability that it just shouldnt have, being what it is.  Impressive, powerful and massively flavorful.
Pours ruby red with off white head, aroma full of malt with smoke, caramel, and roastedness.  Taste is sweet caramel, toffee, and dark fruit with some spiciness and a roasted finish.  Not bad!

Thanks Secret Santa!  Pours dark ruby red with a smallish khaki colored head that fades to a ring.  Aroma features a good amount of fruit, which surprised me.  After it evens out, theres wood, bourbon, drinking chocolate, sambuca, nuts, pears, and apple sauce.  Its a nice "light/dark" mix.  Flavor begins with the pears and cherries quickly followed up by caramel, wood, bourbon, light cocoa, and nuts.  Finishes drier with earth, leaves, wood, and a bourbon aftertaste.  Not too heavy on the palate, with a slick and fairly hot mouthfeel, and prickly carbonation.  Its very enjoyable, but shy of the best barrel-aged beers.

UPDATED: SEP 18, 2010 pours a tea brown with no head or sediment. nose is slightly alcoholic with strong malt aromas. taste very malty, creamy, and smooth. subtle candy flavors are noticeable, almost caramelly but not in the forefront. does have a decent amount of alcohol in the palate, but suits me fine. Very nicely surprised with this beer

Nice oak overtones with smoky, earthy notes. This is the last bottle of a 4-pack that I cannot get locally and it took me this long to figure out whether it is worth replacing in my beer cellar. The vanilla and Bourbon flavors on my last sip make it a thumbs up.

lightly cloudy brownish reddish pour w/ a tall firm small bubbled light tan head.  Palate is nice, smooth and creamy.  Nice aroma bourbon was my first smell then some caramel and a touch of vanilla a tiny hint of pepper and oak.  My only complaint is the aroma drops off w/ the head.  Very sweet taste lots and lots of caramel hints of bourbon and oak, a touch of cherries in the finish is quite nice with the bourbon.  A delicious beer.
Ugh.  Super sweet.  I cant say I encountered a whole lot of barrel or bourbon flavor.  Just a malt bomb.  I probably should have known.
Bottle shared by duffmansw. Poured a reddish color with a thin off white head. Aroma and taste was sweet oak, toffee, scotch whiskey. Very good brew.

12 oz bottle. Pours dark ruby with one-finger khaki head.  Bourbon hits the nose, then some earthy dirt smell, hint of cherry.  Great sweet caramel and vanilla and only a hint of bourbon up front.  Then just a hint of dry bitter coffee and a long caramel finish.  A bit boozy and the bourbon lingers in the back of the throat.  Medium body and pretty light carb.  The more I drink, it gets more and more boozy, but this is the only negative.

Overall, a fantastic beer.  I think it could use a bit more smokiness or peat, but i love this as a bourbon aged scotch.  Will definitely be seeking this out again.

Bottle shared by duffmansw.  Pours clear reddish copper with a thin off white head.  Aroma is oaky with some toasty caramel and dark fruits.  Flavor is sweet and bourbony with some buttery toffee, vanilla, and over ripe fruits.  Full bodied and sticky with moderate carbonation.

12oz bottle. Pours a cloudy, deep reddish amber colored body with a finger-width, creamy, tan head that dissipates slowly and leaves a nice lacing. Aroma is bursting with woody bourbon and vanilla. Once this starts warming up, medium sweet caramels and toffees come in. Some dark fruits as well. Flavor is similar and solid. Lots of vanilla and bourbon, but lots of balancing malts. Caramels and toffees, some fruit, and a light spicing before this finishes with a touch of chocolate and dries with a woody, earthy finish. The hops are somewhat muted by everything else going on, but they offer a light bitterness. Rich malts and plenty of vanilla-bourbon in a long aftertaste. Body is full and smooth with just a touch of soft carbonation. Overall, this was nice. Lots of bourbon and caramel with the vanilla adding a really pleasant sweetness. The woodiness doesnt dry this too much and leaves the body full and smooth. This is clearly dominated by the barrel aging, but it has other things going on that make it quite enjoyable. Good stuff.

Stay calm, okay? Lets not lose our heads. Its--Its a fine ID. Itll--Its gonna work. Its passable, okay? This isnt terrible. I mean, its up to you, Fogell. This guy is either gonna think "Heres another kid with a fake ID" or "Heres McLovin, a 25 year-old Hawaiian organ donor." Okay? So whats it gonna be?

Pours a slightly hazy amber color with a tan head. Aroma is caramel, 
oak, vanilla, bourbon, some rye, and alcohol. Flavor is caramel, 
bourbon, oak, vanilla, rye, spicy hops and a sweet alcoholic finish.

this may be my favorite sippin brew. i bought a four pack of 12 oz bottles from lighthouse beer and wine on jasons recommendation. i enjoyed two a few weeks back and finally got around to drinking the last one this evening. what happened to the third one you ask? my girlfriend crushed it one night. she likes blue moon. if you enjoy good beer. give this one a shot. it is certainly a tasty nightcap brew. quite rare, so buy a couple of four packs and hide them from your old lady.

Absolutely loved this beer. Clear dark amber with a big creamy tan head that stayed and laced the glass. Huge aroma of scotch whiskey, fruit, vanilla. Flavor is similar with with a nice balance, nothing over powering. Very creamy and warming finish. Excellent.

Aroma of molasses, scotch, vanilla, confectionery sugar. Appearance is murky brown with tan head. Flavor matches the nose, with an emphasis on the booze and oak. Palate is bubbly and creamy. A pleasure to drink.

Draft at Mad Mex South Hills. Murky brown with off white foam, great retention for style and decent lacing. Lots of vanilla and caramel in the nose. Flavor is bourbon, lots of heat, vanilla and oak covered in sugar and caramel. Hot, boozy and bitter finish.

12oz bottle.  clear brown under a small creamy tan head.  aroma is bourbon with occasional whiffs of sweet caramel and chocolate candy bars.  body seems light to medium.  alcohol is almost completely hidden.  the flavors rely heavily on the bourbon and oak but are balanced with some sweetness.  incredibly easy to drink considering the abv.  pretty nice....especially for bourbon fans.

Bottle from Bruisin. Lots of bourbon on this one but still works well. If you can stand heavy use of bourbon then I would recommend this. Its been a cold winter here and Ive been in a mood for whisky so this hits the spot. The aroma has all the wood and vanilla from a fine Kentucky bourbon whisky with a little malt, maybe. Its just really strong in the vanilla and oak. The palate is good, works well. Lots of additional oak and vanilla with a pleasing biscuity finish. This is a very drinkable beer for the winter but is nearly like drinking bourbon. Fine with me.

On tap.  Pours a clear walnut brown with a thin off white head.  Aroma is huge bourbon and oak, woodiness.  Vanilla and caramel are kind of hiding behind the bourbon, but bourbon is the front runner on this one.  Flavor is nice and complex with a lot of woodiness, vanilla, caramel, bourbon, toffee, dark fruit.  Really nice beer and probably one of the better scotch ales Ive had.

First off, you must like the smell of Bourbon to like this beer.  Pours a light brown with a light head.  Aroma is strong with Bourbon, with some caramel and hops.  Taste is pretty well balanced with malt, caramel, and floral hops to go with the bourbon.  Overall it is well put together and balanced, just a lot of them derive from the bourbon barrels.  Good winter night beer.

Bottle from TheCheeseMan, thanks! Dark brown color. Oak, malt, vennel and bourbon in the aroma. Malty flavor with oak and vanilla. Bourbon is clearly noticeable. Alcoholic, yet rounded and soft, and with a good complexity. Excellent sipper.

Bottle. Deep mahogany color with small tanish head. Aroma of cherries, bourbon and wood with notes leather and wet leaves. Taste is pretty sweet and ends lightly bitter. Medium to heavy bodied (more towards heavy) with oily and very dry finish.

Pour is a murky brown with a small tan head.  Aroma is deffinatly bourbon with some smoke in there plus a nice cherry.  Flavor is great!  Lots of bourbon-scotch with a mild alcohol burn on the tounge.  If i would not know any better i would think i was drinking a mild scotch rather than a beer.  deffinatly well crafted and something to slow sip on a cold winter night.

(Sample Date: 11/28/2009   Source:Once Apon a Vine - Northside)   Aged in oak Bourbon barrel. Bourbon dark fruitiness oak in aroma. Clear very dark amber with small lacy tan head. Bourbon vanilla toasty oak. Lightly astringent with some alcohol warming. Finish is dry and moderately bitter. Quite tasty.

Straight scotch, bourbon, and oaky tones burst on the dark, amber brown pour. Light, stony khaki head with a medium to heavy body. Very creamy smooth carbonation with a wonderful smoky caramel flavor with a light boozy bitter aftertaste.

Creamy carbonation

Awesome just even on the initial pour with a nice dark red color.  Strong and even more strong bourbon and oak on the nose.  I can also smell vanilla, caramel and cream in there as well.  Definitely a full bodied brew.  Smooth mouth feel.  I taste bourbon, slight oak, caramel, cream in there too.  Fantastic beer.  Small amount of head really but no big deal with this type of beer.

Bourbon nose. Brown with an amorphous collection of sediments, thin lacing head. Unabashed bourbon flavor but with a nice cherry cordial edge. Alcohol noxious. Too much bourbon for me, but uniquely done.

A dark red to brown pour with small off-white head.  The nose is slightly fruity with hints of cherries and grapes, but the dominant smell is the bourbon whiskey.  The taste packed with alcohol, but has a medium sweetness from the fruit notes.   The body is full flavored with an oily texture and soft feel.  The finish is long and smooth with a strong whiskey warmth.

Bottle on 11/28/2009 from Once Upon a Vine - North. Mostly clear deep amber body with ruby highlights and a medium creamy tan head. Sweet oak and caramel aroma with some vanilla hints. Sweet caramel, vanilla, oak, and light fruit flavor. Medium full body with moderately low carbonation.

12 oz bottle. Pours a lightly cloudy kind of dark cider color with a small off white head. Aroma is very oaky, very bourbon forward which I love. Lots of malts, very fruity with cherries and a nice vanilla character. Flavor is awesome, very very woody, bourbon, so woody, vanilla almond, cherries and other dark fruits. Finishes a tiny bit boozy which keeps it from a ten because it takes away a bit of the malt and fruits, but still, excellent all around flavor. Medium to full body and a soft carbonation. I really dig this beer

Pours a glimmering dark cherry stained brown with a frothy topping of small tan bubbles.  nose is sweet with vanilla , bourbon and oak as well as having sharp alcoholic edge with underlying chocolate and toffee.  After a while and strangely enough, the nose starts exhibiting a young garlic characteristic.  Flavors are soft, sweet, creamy, and painted with vanilla and essence of bourbon.  I get waves of those caramel candies with the soft sugary white centers and even big red chewing tobacco.  Hop levels seem vibrant but not over powering, yet possibly a little green.  Theres a touch of hotness in the mouth, but its not overly distracting.  Doesnt seem as refined as I was hoping..would think about aging one but i have a feeling  the body would thin out more than is desirable, but who knows.

strong bourbon aroma, cherry, vanilla, oak, 
Flavour carries on with the vanilla and cherry fruitiness, some caramel sweetness strong woody tones, and boozy bourbon finish.

Bottle from Styles - thanks much. Pours dark ruby with a little tan head that fell quickly. Aromas of wood, vanilla, roasted malt, and maybe cherry. Full bodied with mild carbonation. It is smooth. Earthy. And there is cherry. The wood is subtle. Only a touch of heat in the finish. It is sort of bourbon chocolate. Really great sipper.

UPDATED: NOV 14, 2011 Very happy that Founders is around these days in these parts.  Deep red, slight but lasting head.  Aroma is rich caramel, dark fruit, mostly cherry, and a hint of booze.  Flavor matches the nose.  Enjoyable stuff.  The barrel is present, but adds a vanilla complement as opposed to overwhelming.  Well done.  RERATE:  On draft at Mekong.  More raisin notes coming through now, but still fantastic.  I think this was a keg they had held for some time.  Excellent stuff.  No change to scores.

Mahogany pour with a slight cherry edge.  small offwhite head.  Aroma is vanilla, almond, hazelnut cream, some barrelled booze aroma, bourbon peat, caramel.  Flavor is Smooooth caramel, not overly sweet or aggressive.  Vanilla boozey wood with some creamy peaty notes as well.  Finish is Boozey warmth and more wood.  Incredibley smooth and complexly woody and boozey.

Reddish brown pour with not much head to speak of. Aroma is loaded with vanilla bourbon, caramel, maple syrup, peat, roast, almond-hazelnut, port wine, and subtle hints of dark fruit. Who knew bourbon could do such wondrous things to a scotch ale. Malt complexity is amazing in the nose. Flavor is bursting with caramel and further sweet malt incarnations, though the alcohol presence provides excellent balance to dispel any cloying nature. Bourbon is evident in the taste, but not as strongly as the aroma might suggest. This one is all about the malt... Palate is rich, oily, full, warming, and fine bubbled in its effervescence. Finish is warming and somewhat dry. I love this shit...

Pours a dark, clear brown with orange tints, small head. Aroma smells excellent; notes of bourbon, maple syrup, peat, honey, caramel, molasses, smoke, and some cashew and almond. Flavor isnt as aggressively sweet as I would have expected from the aroma. Notes of whiskey, wood, peat, smoke, caramel, and molassses are still prevalent, however. Palate is a bit disappointing; would have liked something more rich and silky sweet, but still not bad; the finish is somewhat of a redemption in that category. Still a damn tasty brew.

UPDATED: DEC 1, 2012 Bottle - Pours deep brown with a huge rosy tan head thats gone right away. Smells is graham crackers, butterscotch, and nice, sweet booze. Taste is caramelly sweetness with butterscotch and a nice boozy touch. Bitter finish--smooth and malty. Big and chewy with nice boozy warmth. Its not bourbon-forward like I was expecting, but thats okay. Its also not terribly complex, but a nice dessert beer that is pleasant to sip on for a half hour or so.

Re-rate (11/30/12) - Wow have my tastes changed. This was super sweet and pretty hard to finish. Lots of toffee, bourbon and sugar.

Bottle 355  ml  
Appearance:  pours as amber brown brew with mid plus creamy , slightly tanned top. Good lace presented.      Nose:  Creamy wrap on oak aged brew , quiet caskey.    Flavor/Palate :   mid , full bodied. Oak wood of barrel never lets you forget its presence, soft texture mellows things out. Alcohol is actually quiet dry here and considering other elements this is a good thing. Walls are laced with chewy caramel.  Interesting blend.

What a fine scotch ale this is!  Pours a deep, muddy reddish brown with a thin cream-colored head.  Aroma is pungent, and has a strong french oak tone, much like Glenlivet 15.  Vanilla and caramel sweetness also climb up your nostrils.  By this point, your tongue is well-prepared for the strong flavors of oak and whisky, and that powerful caramel malt sweetness that balances the alcohol.

Semi-creamy mouthfeel, just light enough to welcome the next sip.  Potent flavors and double-digit ABV dont overwhelm, as theyre somehow smoothed by other components.  Simply fantastic - better than Breakfast Stout, and right up there with CBS as my favorite offering from Founders.

Pours dark brown with a thick off-white head that settles quickly.  Aroma is of bourbon.  Taste is great strong tast of bourbon but not over whelming.  Warms as it goes down.  Usually you give up some taste with a 10.2% ABV but not with this one.  Very unique flavor.  Quite tasty.  Highly recommend.

UPDATED: DEC 27, 2009 The most unique Ale I have tasted to date. For the Bourbon lover in all of us. Would rate higher if it had a bigger, longer lasting head, but makes up with a long after taste. Would like to do a blind tasting with a real bourbon and see that happens!

Pours cloudy dark brown/ruby with almost no head. Strong scotch aroma, the alcohol is noticeable, also notes of caramel and spice. Nice smooth and full bodied palate, with a little bit of stickiness that helps the flavor linger. The scotch flavor sticks out the most, and you can taste a little bit of smoke from the bourbon barrels. The finish has a bit of the sweet caramel and some earthy spices. Excellent beer.

Woodsy deep brown in the glass, with a disappearing head.  Aromas of bourbon, oak, vanilla, and cherry.  Long, lush palate really shows off the bourbon flavors without indicating too much alcohol.  Slightly sweet at first, then a slight alcohol burn at the finish, but bright flavors throughout of oak, charcoal, cherry, white chocolate and leaves.

Bottle from Wine Warehouse in Charlottesville for $3.60. Pours muddy brown with a quarter of an inch of off-white head. Light, sweet bourbon in the nose - malts as well. Flavor is sweet chocolate bourbon, dark chocolate finish.

Bottle. Pours a dark amber with a brown head. Aroma is full of bourbon notes with an undertone of smoke and roasted malts. Flavor begins with sweet caramel and grain notes, but finishes with a smoky alcoholic kick.

12 oz bottle served in a tulip.  Pour was dark amber, like the color of whiskey actually, with a half inch of beige head that disappeared in the blink of an eye.  Nose is bourbon, scotch, vanilla, oak, and earth.  Taste is whiskey, vanilla, bourbon, and earth upfront.  This is followed by an odd, caramel sour cherry the pops up and flows into the finish.   This is a very unique brew that is quite enjoyable!  Though delicious, I dont know if I could drink more than one or two.  Also, the HIGH ABV is very well hidden!

12oz bottle (2009) into a goblet.  The pour is amber/red with a small off-white head and tons of lacing.  The aroma is mostly bourbon barrel - oak, tannins, and a solid dose of vanilla.  The flavor is a lot of bourbon barrel up front like the aroma but then fades into a sweet and smokey concoction paired with a numb alcohol feeling.  This is all a good combination!

12 oz. bottle, 2009 edition, from Ludlow Wines.  Pours a dark, cloudy brown color with a very thin beige head that leaves a little film on top and ring around the edge.  Aroma of vanilla, bourbon, wood, caramel malts, butterscotch, roast, dark fruits, and just a little smoke.  As I smell this more, Im also picking up on the Scotch- amazing, because I never expected to be able to distinguish both whiskeys in here.  Wow, I could smell this all day.  Nice, smooth, well-balanced flavor of sweet roasted malts, vanilla, butterscotch, wood, tea, and dark fruits.  A little warming alcohol shows up late, but overall well-hidden for a 10.2% ABV brew.  Smooth, with minimal carbonation and a buttery mouthfeel.  Great beer.

Tap.  Pours to a deep rusted brown body with a thin off-white head.  The aroma is lightly peated caramel toffees.  Light vanilla and sweet barley.  Touch of chocolate.  The flavor is sweet but not sugary.  Densely blended flavors of lightly peated barley, vanilla, chocolate ganache, oak, and a dash of bourbon.  The barrel aging is so balanced and provides mere highlights instead of that constant overpowering booze like others.  The palate is sweet but not sugary.  Velvety and medium bodied.  Very easy to drink this.  Peated malt works well throughout.  Chocolate provides balance and complexity.
Tap.  Vinous prune, barley malt and alcohol aroma.  Dark brown-red color with small head.  Sweet, smooth bourbon and barley malt flavor with a hint of cherry.  Superb blending.

Not my cup of tea (or bottle of beer). I could really taste the bourbon and it as a result I felt it similar to taking shots... Which is definitely not my thing. I can totally appreciate this beer for what it is. A dark, artistic oak aged piece of heaven for some. Not for me though, on the bright side, it pours dark brown with just a little bit of head, smells amazing... Just not my favorite on the palate. Gave it a 3 for its appearance and aroma.

Pours from the bottle a deep red-brown color, very viscous when poured from the bottle and small dense tan head that fades down very fast. Aroma has a strong oak, bourbon, vanilla, caramel, light smokey and very mild toasted malt note. Flavor starts off with a very smooth oak and bourbon note followed by a very rich caramel and toasted malt with a very late cherry, vanilla presence and a mild alcohol bite.  Moderate body (looks heavier than it is), very low carbonation with a slightly oily but smooth texture. Overall a complex brew that incorporates some of the better scotch ale properties with a bit of an American twist with the bourbon flavor present.
Thanks to alexsdad for this beer. This dark brown pour is a really nice combination of malt flavor, barrel aging and smoothness. Its very tasty.

Has an opaque dark brown almost black color with a lighter brown head.  Aroma is of bourbon, oak, vanilla, coconut, and malts.  Palate is between medium and full bodied.  Flavor consists bourbon, oak, slight coconut, spices, and some booze.  Has a nice sweeter aftertaste full of oak.  This is different.  This is special.

Pours a deep brown with no visible head. Aromas of chocolate, malt, bourbon, as well as some oak. Taste is swayed more towards the bourbon, but the malt, caramel, and chocolate flavors are also present. This didnt feel like a 10.2% beer, but it was a damn good beer! Nice balance of ABV

Bottle.  Bottled:  11/16/09.  Different label than that in the picture.  A murky mahogany pour with a thin khaki head on top.  An oaky aroma of scotch, sweet caramel maltiness, vanilla extract, prunes, and a touch of smokiness.  Full-bodied and kinda syrupy.  Almost creamy.  The flavor starts off with plenty of sweet caramel, Raisinets, prunes, and vanilla extract.  A roasted oaky/smokiness follows.  Earthy.  Quite boozy and warming throughout.  Not necessarily my taste, but I cant deny the quality.

I think very similar to New Holland Dragons Milk.  Delicious,  oaky bourbon barrels, smoke, sweet caramel, vanilla and roasted malts. A bit of earthy.   Pour a snifter, sit back and enjoy.  Great beer.

UPDATED: OCT 17, 2011 Sampled from 12 oz bottle. The beer pours a reddish amber color with a very small head. Aroma of oak, sweet fruit, caramel, malts. Flavor is sweet, with notes of oak, vanilla, malts, and touches of alcohol.
UPDATE (10/18/2011): Drank entire 12oz bottle. Everything about the same, just wanted to reiterate how enjoyable this one was. Very woody, smooth notes of vanilla. Alcohol is very mellow, surprised this one was 10.2%.

Pretty deep clear mahogany with an eggshell colored head. Caramel, toastiness and bourbon/oak in the nose  not too intense or alcohol-y. Flavor starts with brown sugar/molasses, toffee and then a prominent yet not over powering bourbon woodiness. Next comes earthy hop character for balance and some pipe tobacco. Pleasant sweetness level, which is very much appreciated. Not too boozy  nicely balanced. Medium bodied with a smooth texture and soft carbonation. Overall, very good stuff.

Location: 12 oz bottle from Wine and Beer Westpark, 12/14/09 


Aroma: The nose has a lot of bourbon and scotch, along with vanilla, oak, smoke, and caramel

Appearance: It pours a dark reddish-brown color with a creamy tan head, and some drippy lace on the glass

Flavor: Taste is somewhat sweet and boozy, it has a distinct sweet bourbon feel to it, and a slight touch of fruit

Palate: This one has a long duration, sticky mouthfeel, and soft carbonation, with almost no burn

Overall Impression: 
Overall, this beer is pretty good.  Definitely a top choice for anyone who likes to sip on a nice bourbon.  This is basically the beer equivalent of a wonderful scotch, a great sipper brew.  It has a wonderfully smooth flavor, this is the best scotch ale I can ever recall drinking.  Anyway, great beer, enjoy this one, I know I did.

Bottle. Pours a deep reddish brown color with a small head. Flavor is initially sweet and malty, followed by flavors of deep ripe fruit, chocolate cherries, bready yeast, caramel, earthy oak malts. Sweet and syrupy on the palate, medium bodied. Alcohol is amazingly well hidden. Finish is lingering and sweet. Well done and solid.

Dark amber color with a thin tan head. Aromas of bourbon, caramel, oak, brown sugar and cherries. Bourbon and brown sugar up front with a very complex fruity acohol finish. One of the most perfectly balanced bourbon barrel aged beers Ive ever tried.
UPDATED: APR 6, 2016 Bottle at Sheffields. Dark amber pour. Nose of oak, vanilla, bourbon, caramel. Same on taste. Creamy and not too carbonated. Killer.

Amazing beer! vanilla, oak, toffee, caramel. Smooth and a superb bourbon nose. With just a little more carbonation and this thing would be the top beer ever. Very well constructed. Like an easy-drinking bourbon or a nice cold port wine. Outstanding complexity.

12oz. bottle served in a snifter. Poured a dark amber with a finger of off white head. Amazing aroma of vanilla, bourbon, chocolate, and a little alcohol. Big, rich and smooth body. Toffee and more vanilla in the flavor. A fair amount of hop bitterness, but just to balance the malt. I wouldnt call this a hoppy beer though. Very long finish of vanilla, oak and bourbon. Might be a bit over the top with the bourbon, but in a good way! One of the best beers I have had this year.

Thanks for dropping this off, bro.  Pours  a cloudy caramel color with a thin off-white ring which leaves rainy streaks on the glass.  Aroma is vanilla, nutmeg, oak, and dark fruit.  Taste is much the same but way too brash and harsh.
Pours a hazy ruby red with a white head. Aroma is lots of wood, bourbon, dark fruits, and a bit of smoke. Flavor is oak,bourbon, toast, and a bit of alcohol shows through.

Pours a dark ruby-amber with a small beige head. The aroma is huge, lots of very woody, with more bourbon than scotch. Some alcohol to go with the whiskey, a little more wood, roast, vanilla, faint chocolate and dark fruit. The flavor is AMAZING!!!! Whiskey and wood bleed into chocolate, thick caramel, tart cherries, and finally, a bit of alcohol. Finish is slightly bitter, and quite woody. Huge body, comparable to a high gravity imperial stout. Light carbonation and a long, sweet, woody finish. Wish I had more of this.

THOUGHTS: Tons of whiskey, The alcohol was noticeable, but not too much for the high ABV. I didnt like the first bottle of this I had very much, but after having this second one at a very nice temperature, I love it. Had another bottle of this on thanksgiving night. A perfect nightcap.
TECHNICAL: Bottle Poured a dark red with bright red highlights and a huge, off-white head that mostly diminished, but kept a thick sheet and left excellent lacing. The aroma was heavy, caramel malt, lighter cereal; cherry, cask wood, vanilla and whiskey. The initial flavor was sweet and ever so slightly sour; while the finish was rather sweet, a little acidic and slightly bitter with a long duration. There was caramel malt, cherry, lots of vanilla, a little fruit, whiskey and wood. The light to medium body was slightly syrupy, but oily and then a little dry with soft carbonation and a dry and lightly alcoholic finish.

12oz bottle, 2009 edition, from grape & gourmet. pours a dark, hazy, caramel brown with a thin, whispy tan head and solid lacing. aroma is excellent with a strong, oakey wood, and bourbon notes up front that are tamed by slightly sweet notes of vanilla, caramel malts, and dark fruit notes of cherry and plum and a hint of smokey peat. flavor is wonderfully complex with sweet, lightly roasted malts and butterscotch up front blending with notes of dark cherry, licorice, vanilla, and ash with the smooth, oakey bourbon notes finishing out the sip and leaving a nice hit of warming alcohol. palate is on the full side of medium bodied with light carbonation and velvelty mouthfeel. overall, another great bourbon barrel brew from founders.

Im trying to be objective in my rating, as Im not a huge fan of Scotch Ales....this one has a monster flavor and aroma of Alcohol.  Pretty much hits the mark for that it should be....just not my bag baby!

Paid $15 for a 4 pack of bottles....if your a fan of the style then well worth it...will be a pass on the next set for me though...

Very oak forward.  Bourbon a little, but strong oak.  But done very well.  This does not resemble regular Founders Bastard Ale by any means.  Which is a good thing because I wasnt a huge fan of that beer as a scotch ale anyway.

Pours a rich brown color with medium light brown head.  Aroma is bourbon, alcohol, peat, and some malt.  The alcohol aroma really dominates once it warms up.  Taste is bourbon, vanilla, caramel malt, peat, and fusol alcohol.  Taste is pretty well balanced, but again, the alcohol is a bit sharp for my liking.  Overall, probably one of the better scotch ales out there.

Dark, dark carmel color with light tan head. Intense scotch ale aroma of overripe dark forest fruit and bourbon, with deep malt and moldy earth and the dust of a county road. Flavor was a bit of a let down, fairly simple carmel, vanilla and malt with some dry chocolate, butterscotch and a bit of sour. Maybe it is just a bit thin tasting, doesnt punch you in the mouth like it does in the nose. Nice dry finish.

On tap and snifter served at Brixies in Brookfield, IL. Poured a dark brown with ruby highlights showing through. The head was a bubbly, light tan foam with lasting, curtainy sheets of  lacing. The aroma was rich, roasty malt, cask wood and strong bourbon notes, with dark fruit and caramelly sweetness. Following these into the flavor was some moderate hop bitterness and hints of dark and dry bakers chocolate. Full bodied and a real treat on tap since many places in the area only offered bottles. A truly warming and tasty brew to sip and enjoy!

Bottle pours a cloudy dark copper body with a tiny beige head that leaves no lacing. Aroma is boozy bourbon, caramel, toffee, and vanilla. Almost full bodied with a lot of creaminess. Taste is complex. Bourbon, peat, vanilla, toffee, herbal hops, alcohol warmth, all work together nicely. Dangerously drinkable!

Yet again, another great beer by Founders. Pours very dark red. Didnt pick up much of the bourbon. Has a ting to the nostrils of roasted grains as well as the alcohol but is not unpleasant at all. Near perfect finish and great mouthfeel. Cant wait to try at from the tap at Founders.
I was worried this would not be my thing. Man was I wrong! Great taste and flavor. Booze is well hidden. Shame it is not available year round.

MMmmmm, baby, baby - cant get enough of your beer babe. Luxuriant. Poured with fine creamy, light tan head and good lace. Color is cured cherry wood. Aroma is vanilla, sweet cherries, malt, caramel, and brandy. Flavor is sweet, a hint of roastiness, Texture is velvety with fine carbonation. Some alcohol in the finish which is fairly long and sweet with a tinge of bitterness at the very end. Not a session beer although an excellent beer.
Pours the color of rootbeer with a tan head.  The first flavor that jumps out at you is butterscotch which is followed by a little wood and some caramel.  Overall a very tasty beer.

Pours a deep obsidian color with a slight head that quickly diminishes.  Aroma is bourbon, malt, vanilla, and molasses.  Taste is a good combination of vanilla, mollasses and bourbon. Finishes relatively smooth with an easy combination.
Bottle. Poured a darkish brownish color with a little white head. Aroma was caramel, malts and alcohol. Flavor was whisky, bread, and toffee. Very thick. Some bitter in the finish. Decent beer.

Pretty damn good. For as potent as this brew is, it is highly sessionable in the winter. Just ask me. 8 of these bad boys in one night.......hilarity ensued. Now, where can I get some more Kentucky Breakfast for a side by side comparo?

12 oz. bottle from Grape & Gourmet.  Hazy, muddy reddish-brown pour with a very thin off-white head.  Bourbon vanilla aroma, molasses, brown sugar, and booze.  Creamy and rich vanilla flavor upfront and very sweet malt in the back of the throat.  Moderate alcohol warming.  The oak is present as well.  This is really hardly a scotch ale given the oak bourbon barrel flavor that is so overpowering over anything that resembles a scotch ale.  It is, however, a damn fine beer.

aroma is boozy mix of whiskey and rotting wood. appearance is nearly opaque with bruised ruby edges. flavor is nearly foremost roast sweetness and some esters of black cherry, mixed berry, perhaps stone fruits as well. surprising given the huge nose...however those elements seep into the taste immediately thereafter with a blast of woody booze. damp chocolate comes to visit yet later. soft silky mouthfeel even long before it warms.

Bottle pored a hazy reddish brown with a lasting amber head. Aromas of bourbon, vanilla, carmel, oak, plum, figs and molasses. Palate was medium bodied and smooth with a dry warming finish. Flavors of bourbon, molasses, carmel, vanill, oak, plum and fig with a smooth dry warming lingering fruity bourbon finish. Very enjoyable beer, wish I could get this one regularly!

Pours a very attractive ruby brown color with a substantial head that dissipates quickly.  Aroma of bourbon, fruit, vanilla increasing as it warms, and some alcohol apparent.  In the mouth it is less impressive, giving off too much alcohol (not particularly warming) with a relatively blah malt foundation supplemented by the bourbon & wood dimensions.  It strikes me that this is a fairly "pure" exercise in taking a plain beer and giving it a dose of bourbon barrels, which isnt bad at all, but it is fairly plain or unidimensional.  Ten years ago this would have been a revolution; now it is just a beer some people might like, and others might find it a big crass.

Beautiful dark copper topped by a thin beige head. Slight notes of caramel and vanilla on the first nose. Big, full body with an intense, yet smooth,  attack of butterscotch, followed by sweet caramel, vanilla with just enough bitterness to balance the whole thing. Slight minerality in the aftertaste, almost salty. The bourbon does not overpower the beer in this one but rather blend all the taste together. Very well done beer.

PS: Went pretty well with a salty sheep cheese from the Pyrenees (Ostari)...

Bottle. Pours a murky, dark brown with a thick, foamy tan head. Aroma is bourbon, vanilla, smoky notes, caramel, oak and candy notes. Taste is more oak and bourbon with big vanilla, smoked malts, caramel, candy, light chocolate and light tart fruit. Body is medium with creamy carbonation and mild warmth. Ends with light spicy notes, vanilla, caramel, bourbon, oak, smoked malts and earthy notes. Some alcohol throughout the finish as well.

"Dark copper brown in color, thin bubbly tan head, slow carbonation, and surprisingly good lacing. Medium bodied with a great whiskey feel. Mildly sweet and slinky~silky smooth. Vanilla and peat aromas with a lush scent of bourbon on the rocks. Straight forward no nonsense flavor with a grand malt base that is lightly sweetened. Flashes of vanilla along with a woody flavor that is backed up by smooth bourbon and earthy peat. Nothing too elaborate with this brew, but this years batch is done just right for my liking."

Poured with a lovely 2 finger head that just swarmed with malt, caramel, and bourbon aromas.  I took a full minute to smell the beer because it was just that good.  The sweet caramel smells and roasty character followed through to the taste. Some cherry tastes in there which were a nice touch. Great scotch ale.  Much enjoyed after Thanksgiving dinner

Bottle. Pours a dark reddish brown color with a small off white head. Tiny bubbles meander slowly to the surface. sticky lacing clings to the side of the glass. Nose is vanilla, bourbon, sweet caramel malt. Palate is full with a light warming and some stingy carbonation. Flavors of bourbon, vanilla, caramel, sweet malt, but finishes dry and tingly with a warm mouth.

This is certainly an american interpretation of a scotch ale. Scent has a lot of sweet caramel mixed in with that bourbon barrell sweetness. Taste is quite sweet with a lot of roasted malt, caramel and most definitely cherries. On the aftertaste the caramel comes through especially strong. There is also a some bourbon barrel taste but not quite as prevalent as the other flavors already mentioned. This is certainly a beer with some attitude that hides the high alcohol and brings forth many interesting flavors.

UPDATED: NOV 19, 2013 Bottle.  Pour is dirty dark brown with a small tan head.  Aroma is brown sugar, caramel malt, bourbon, and very light cherry.  Flavor is rich toffee malt, a bit of a bourbon sting, vanilla, light wood, distinct smokiness, and a touch of cherry in the finish.  Mild darjeerling tea in the finish too. A sipper for sure.  Huge but not cloying. Update 11/9/13. Had the 2012 on tap at Rumpus Room in Milwaukee. Wow did a year do this some good! So rich and smooth with loads of maple, toffee, and vanilla. Really luscious and rich.  Fresh - 3.7. With one year on it - 4.4

Poured a hazy and very dark copper like a strong iced tea color with a thin tan head. The head disappeared rather quickly to just a film, but did leave a light lacing. The aroma was all about bourbon with a good scent of alcohol and a bit of vanilla. The texture of the beer was silky with the taste of bourbon and a good warmth of alcohol as well. There was a nice amount of a molasses like sweetness underneath before the bourbon flavor came on for a smooth finish. This was just like sipping a smooth bourbon. Excellent!!!!!!!

12oz bottle. Pours dark amber brown with a red hue, small off-white head which settles quickly.  Aroma is vanilla, oak, bourbon, sweet bready malt, caramel,even has a smoky quality to it.  Taste is sweet malt, heavy wood/oak, lots of bourbon.  Enjoyed this until the intensely bitter pill-like aftertaste set in - I had this on tap recently and loved it, but this aftertaste from the bottle is hard to bear.  Would rate much higher if I rated from tap version.

Bottle pours dark red to copper brown with a short lived small head and spot lace.  The aroma is scotch, peat, wood, and caramel.  The flavor is a bit hot, very scotchy, somewhat oak like, and some peat.  The palate is pretty substantial.  Overall, this is best at room temperature and approached like a single malt.  Pretty good for a strong sipper.

Pours a nice amber color with very little head. Has a smell of bourbon, and butterscotch. The taste is mainly bourbon. To much bourbon if you ask me. There is a little butterscotch in the taste as well

Excellent American interpretation of a Scottish ale.  Deep, smoky malt character in a dark, dark brown ale; aromas of malt, wood, bourbon, caramel; rich, earthy flavors, you could spend a night exploring them.  Sweet, but not overpowering; well-balanced, complex and delicious.  Had it on draft and in the bottle; draft is especially good; it has a delightfully round flavor that is somewhat clipped in the bottled version.  But I snap up both in a heartbeat when I find them.

Hoooolllyyy hell.  I didnt know anything about this before I picked it up and I as so floored by it when I finally tried it.  Gorgeous dark amber pour with almost off-white head.  The flavor and aroma are about the same -- you get some serious bourbon, which makes me curious as to how long they were aged in the bourbon barrels because its so very close to actual bourbon.  You get the nice warming affects of the 10.2% (another thing I didnt realize until I started drinking it).  This is a beaut, another great find in Founders.
Like an incredibly smooth single-malt whiskey candy. Unbelievably yummy. The 10-plus ABV is barely hidden but thats not a bad thing. Makes a fantastic sipper on a cold night.

UPDATED: JAN 22, 2010 12 oz bottle from the Four Firkins.  Dark caramel color, very little head.  Aroma is straight Kentucky bourbon... smells like Im drinking a glass of Knob Creek.  Flavor is more mellow than I expected, yet still pretty complex.  I definitely can taste the sweet caramel and the cherries.  The oaky bourbon flavor comes through also.  Finish is smooth and sweet.  I love this beer.
Pours ruby colored with a thin tan head. Notes of whiskey, oak, toffee, vanilla, spice, wood. Full to heavy bodied with soft carbonation.

Pours deep maple syrup/mahogany w/ thin but creamy head that dissipates to thin winter night cirrus clouds, great bourbon-y vanilla malt notes in aroma, juicy, fruity flavor laced with smoke, cherry, oak & toffee, all coated with a great malty alcohol petina that results in a very drinkable and dangerously smooth potent ale

Thick, creamy, and strong, with bourbony heat on the finish. The 12 oz bottle pours a dark amber without much foam. Aromas of bourbon, vanilla, and oak. Heavy malt flavors, apples, dark fruits, cherries;  but wrapped in thick Scotch whiskey on the tip and sides of the tongue. A really dry finish.

Bottle thanks to lufootball..Thanks John...Pours a murky dark brown with a off white head..Aroma is caramel, dark fruits, smoke and some wood..Starts off woody then finishes with a dark fruit sweetness.. Medium body and medium carbonation.. Tasty stuff!

Pours orange/brown with an orange head. Lots of sediment. Sweet barleywine like aroma, with plums, orange, chocolate, waterlogged wood, and caramel. The flavor is thick, sweaty, and very tasty with notes of chocolate, caramel, toffee, wood, vanilla, licorice, orange and spices. Very nice, but lacks the refinement of a truly great beer.
Dark ruby brown with a thin head.  Heavy corn, vanilla and a touch of oak char.  Caramel, butterscotch and bourbon flavors.  A bit of roasty astringency.  Light earthy hop.  Full bodied.

Nice! Pours a dark opaque brown with tan head. Aroma has notes of malted chocolate balls, and whoppers. Flavor is not overly sweet, and finishes clean. Lots of good chocolatey notes in this one, as well as some great tanins.

(bottle - 12 oz) Dark ruby pour with a creamy off-white head. Aroma is a ton of oak, smoke, and caramel malts. Flavor is much the same. Very sweet from the oak but balanced well with the smoky and roasted malts. Smooth and delicious and easy to drink. Loved it.

Pours a deep ruby amber. Smells of a blended bourbon and sugar. Big thick smooth mouthfeel with scotch,vanilla, caramel and finishing with some black cherrys. Smell and taste are night and day. What a treat. Well balanced and delicious. Will be picking up more for some snowy nights. Founders does it again.

The oak bourbon barrels dominated this beer. It looks delicious, but the taste disappoints. I plan to try this beer again after it has aged awhile in the bottle. It was bottled on 11/05/2009 and I drank it on the 13th. Overall I was not impressed!

bottle. Pours a deep reddish brown looks thick almost no head what head was there was creamy smooth. Aroma smells of vanilla brown sugar other flavors bourbon initial taste is malty sweet and smooth - too smooth. Bourbon finish overpowers any flavor the beer might have had. I expected a little more beer bite. overall good but doesnt knock me out at $15. a 4 pack. I thinks it tasted better upon initial pour after sitting a while is loose quite a bit of flavor

UPDATED: NOV 14, 2009 deep reddish brown, beautiful color. Aroma of vanilla, brown sugar,caramel,  toffee, soft bourbon. Flavor is malty sweet, complex mixture of aroma qualities, flavorful, but soft. mouthfeel is smooth bordering on too soft. Definite bourbon in the finish, a sipping beer, just a little too smooth, give me just a little more spice. The flavor is really unique, enjoyable, but it struggles to really excite my tastebuds. With this beer, alcohol %,  and oak bourbon barrel aging, it should be making my tastebuds dance. Overall - decent, but highly overpriced for the result.
Poured dark reddish brown, wood, malty, Bourbon, alcohol, caramel, little dark fruit, little bitter finish.

(bottle) Pours dark ruby with a thin light off-white head.  Without the head, this would look very much like a bourbon as well.  The aroma is strong of oak, bourbon, smoke, vanilla, cherries, glazed ham, and caramel.  Really nice mix of aromas, and they constantly shift upon smelling.  The taste follows suit with the aroma, showcasing a lot of bourbon, charred wood, vanilla, cherry, caramel, and smoke.
