Right before the finish theres a deceptive sensation, as it feels as if Im about to swallow a sip of bourbon.  I think this might be the alcohol burning through, but with this kind of beer it doesnt detract from the experience.  Mouthfeel is full and carbonation is smooth finishing with some smoke and oak which is very dry.  Really good stuff. (upon the hour or so Ive been drinking this, as it warms the beer begins to exhibit a dish soap finish which is really offensive, and I have to lower the score accordingly)

Poured from bottle into Snifter.

Cloudy dark reddish-brown with minimal head and spotty lacing. However, the thin head actually lasts; not often the case with high abv beers.

Aroma is a strong blast of oak, cherry, vanilla, peat and alcohol.

The taste is very similar to the smell but sweeter, with strong notes of vanilla, oak, cherry, peat, as well as toffee and dark fruit.

Low carbonation and quite warming. While certainly not light in body, it is lighter than expected.

Fits the mold of a barrel-aged beer more than a Wee Heavy. Either way, it is extremely good and a very easy sipper, belaying the fact that it is over 10% abv.

Note to self: Stop buying singles of Founders beers; every single time I regret it and wish I had bought the 4-pack.

12 oz, 2008.  Cloudy dark amber/orange pour.  Minimal cream head, disappears quickly, but sticks nicely.  Heavy aroma of charred oak.  Some malt and caramel/toffee and booze.  Taste is excellent and smooth and really comes out as it warms.  Oak and bourbon, vanilla, toffee, some charred peat, a little vanilla and just hints of vinuous fruits.  A warming sipper, good medium body.  Finishes a little ashy bitter, with some warming whishy barrel.  Pretty darn good wee heavy.
user_location: from Michigan now in Charlotte, North Carolina, USA

text: Bottle. Dangerously tasty with solid hints of bourbon, vanilla, and oak. Great twist on a Scottish Ale. I LOVE this stuff!

Bottle. Moderate notes of roasted, caramel and herbs for the malt and hops with background notes of brown sugar, bourbon, oak wood and date. Head is small, wispy, white with no lacing but good legs and is mostly diminishing. Color is clear copper. Flavor starts moderately sweet and lightly acidic, then finishes moderately acidic and bitter. Palate is on the fuller side of medium, oily with a lively carbonation and a dry finish. This Scotch Ale is noticably more tempered than its cousin despite the alcohol. Its smoother and better balanced  as well. Thanks Hopscotch.

bottle.... pours a deep deep red with slight highlights and an average off white head... big bourbon and vanilla notes on the nose as well as some apple, plum and raisin... absolutely wonderful aroma... I could smell this all night.  big round body with nice creamy sides and an aggressive front... sweet caramel, scotch and more fruit dominate the front of the mouth... with a twist of alcohol... the top is more mellow with cherries and sweet malts.  Excellent bourbon laced finish leaves you wanting more.  Solid.

bottle, pours dark brown, tall tan head.  Dark fruity aroma of strawberry, oak, sour apple, and light hops.  Wow, this is near perfect.  Sweet bourbon and again strawberry, I dont know why Im tasting it, but I am.  Apple skins, more oak and a strong whiskey undertone.  So good, creamy mouth with light carbonation.  This is what I want in a barrel aged beer.  So damn tasty.

12oz bottle thanks to Iowaherkeye. Pours a mahogany with a small khaki head. Nose is woody and fruity with a nice bourbon undercurrent. Its not bourbon heavy but you still know its there. Flavor is just amazing. Rich deeply complex malt with a strong vinuous fruity profile. Some mollasses and brown sugar and definite bourbon finish. Slight twinge of alcohol but all things considered its well hidden. Really outstanding.
dark caramel brown color little head tons of floaty stuff. Bourbon woody aroma. Nice malty bourbon woody flavor with some alcohol which isnt to bad. This was a 1 year old bottle mellowed a bit.
Bottle thanks to Devils Advocate from Fever.  Thanks!  Looks and tastes like bourbon.  A lot.  Really boozy taste and smell.  Its quite good though, reminds me of a nice bourbon.  I like it.

Pours chestnut brown, moderate yellow-cream head, speckled with yeast and whatever else is floating about. Earthy nose faintly reminiscent of Highland single malts with heavy caramel, some light smoke, and strong wood. Flavor isnt as sweet, more malt and wood, slightly alcoholic and medicinal. Rather short finish, moderate body, a little too watery. Pretty decent, but also somewhat forgettable.

Bottle [355ml] courtesy of tupalev. Pours a murky copper-brown with a fuckload of floaties (seriously, its like a crazy snowstorm in there!) and an average size somewhat-lasting creamy tan head. Slightly mild aroma of lightly smoky caramel malt, vanilla and oak. Delicious flavour of caramel malt, vanilla, oak, a hint of smoke and some alcohol. Some bitterness in the finish. Alcohols there but pretty well hidden for 10%. Medium bodied. A good example of a barrel-aged beer done right, its not overdone. I really enjoyed it.

UPDATED: SEP 14, 2009 Poured from the bottle to a hazy dark borwn-red with a strong aroma of bourbon, malty dark fruit and a hint of molasses, with the 10.2% alcohol entering the fray at mid-glass.  Mouthfeel is full, slightly chewy and a tad tingly, as the taste perfectly accentuates the scents of the nose. Rounds to a nice long warming finish.

Enjoyed with a nice cigar to round it all out.

This bottled brew from a bottle shop poured a extremely small sized head of medium sized clear colored bubbles that were and left behind a very hazy very softly carbonated and a oily lacing. The mild aroma was bourbon. The mouth feel was tingly and hoppy at the start and at the finish with a vinous aftertaste. The nice flavor contained notes of hops and soft bourbon ale. Delicious and one I would certainly buy again.

Bottle at home ...Big thanks to MikeTD for this ... deep brown ... big foam head ... big oaky toffee creamy malt nose ...sweet malt ... bourbon ... lots of toffee ... way to creamy (which is an odd description but the closest i can get)... little spice.
MMM... This beer has a great malt presence, a little boozy, but in a good way. Carmal and a nice alcohol warming on the finish.

Bottled. A deep red beer with a thin light tan head. The aroma has notes of malt, caramel, wood, and whiskey. The flavor is sweet with strong notes of bourbon as well as medium notes of caramel and wood, and a slightly burnt edge. Thanks Papsoe for sharing.

Pours a very dark chestnut brown, almost black color that is completely opaque with only the slightest of mahogany edges and a thin coffee colored head that slowly fades into a lasting ring.

Roasted malt aroma with an awesome oak presence that gives off a nice wooden aroma with sweet vanilla notes and a good dose of bourbon/whiskey. Hints of burnt toast, chocolate, toffee and oatmeal.

Full bodied with a nice roasted malt flavor that is kind of nutty with a big oak, vanilla and whiskey presence. Chocolate malt, caramel, toffee, burnt toast and oatmeal notes are also detectable. Kind of sweet up front with a silky malt backbone with a very nice touch of bourbon and a bitter dry finish.

Bottle that was very kindly passed onto me from Miketd via Craig, cheers Mike, consumed in a field at Towersey Festival, Oxon, 29-08-09   Pours dark brown with a tan head. The aroma is sweet and slightly alcohol with the bourbon aging clearly showing. Warming in the mouth, the alcohol is apparent but the barrel aging sends bourbon flavours flooding around. There is plenty of sweet maltiness, rich fruitiness, touch of vanilla and a dab of smokiness going on, lovely stuff.  A6 A4 F8 P4 Ov14   3.6

Bottle via trade.  Dark reddish brown color with a beige head.  Aroma is scotch whiskey, oak barrel, roast, spices, and smoke.  Flavor is malty with caramel and roasted malt, scotch and oak, spices, earth, and vanilla.  Body medium, palate smooth and creamy.  Pretty solid overall.
Bottle. Dark amber pour with almost no tan head.  Sweet flavors of roasted malts, chocolate, spices, bourbon and some dark fruit. Lots of flavors meld pretty well, nice beer.

Picked up in a trade with the Beer Sommelier. 12 oz. 2008 bottle. Nice dark brown with a nice thin off-white head. Best scotch ale I have seen to date! Aromatic bourbon and wood aroma; nice aroma! A nice sublte sweet, dare I say almost chocolate sweet, aroma. Smells like an fin smore! Very nice aroma I must say! Not overly pungent, but just so damn smooth of a nose. Nice vanilla-sweet flavor. Has a nice bourbon finish. PilsnerPeter below my rating said this had a graham cracker aroma, well I am tasting that in the flavor. This would be perfect with dessert, even though I dont care for matching beer with foods, I would rather just drink the damn beer! Nice sweet caramel flavor as well. This beer is very good, and very nuanced in terms of flavor and aroma. Not a VERY creamy beer, but this thing is pretty smooth. Alcohol is welll hideen, although there is a slight bite at the end. I am happy I traded for this, seeing that this beer is just a superiour scotch ale. Nice bourbon touches throughout the drinking experience, which I love.

Bottle: Pours a rubyish brown with a wispy tan head. Big and sweet aroma- caramelized brown sugar, graham cracker and plum. Slick body and richly malt flavor. Plummy, some mild honey, peat and toasted notes to balance. Theres also some toasted coconut, graham crackers, very mild smoke followed by a toasted lingering finish. Pretty nice example of the style. Big, yet drinkable.

Thanks to the RB crew in Queens! Pours a light maroon with minimal head. Wonderful oaky aroma with tons of caramel, malt, bourbon, vanilla, and a bit of spiced chai. Lots of vanilla and bourbon flavors. Surprisingly smooth. Light body with a vanilla finish. This is incredibly well-balanced.

Draught. I was told this was a barrel aged version but I surmise from the description that thats the norm. The body was dark brown almost ash colored with a decent tan head that produced nice lacing. Aroma was initially mellifluous, some vanilla, strong bourbon oak, caramel, a little dark chocolate or coffee roast, and a sweet spicy perhaps even slightly peaty finish alongside alcohol. The flavor was even better; chocolate syrup, caramel, bourbon oak, light vanilla, lightly rooty and spicy, and the wood and alcohol finished out strong. Palate was thick and smooth and slightly numbing.

08 sample thanks to Ben @ crown #6. Pours dark golden, scotch-like. Nose is slight roasted malt, bourbon, some vanilla. Taste is an excellent complexion, very good bourbon component that doesnt overpower, slightly sweet, smooth and a little caramel/nut. Finish is a bit sticky, and aftertaste is wonderful bourbon with a touch of alcohol, not too much in any way. Wonderful beer, glad I got to try!

UPDATED: AUG 1, 2013 11/15/2007:  Founders Backwoods Bastard has sweet caramel and chocolate in the arom with faint bourbon and quite a bit of vanilla in the aroma.  The beer has a clear, dark brown color topped with a thin layer of dissipating foam.  The flavor has heavily caramelized malt and chocolate, dry woody notes, bourbon, and plnty of vanilla.  There are traces of chocolate in the finish and the alcohol is reserved.  This beer is full-bodied, yet smooth and lightly creamy on the palate.  It does look quite thick though!  Overall this is a fantastic scotch ale and much better than the regular Dirty Bastard Scotch Ale.
12 fl. oz. bottle (Alc by Vol 8.7%).  Rating #364 for this beer.
. . . . . . . . . .
2007 Vintage
6/10/2010:  Founders Backwoods Bastard (Ale aged in oak bourbon barrels)...  Aroma:  Amazing blend of vanilla, boubon, sherry, syrupy malt, hint of barrel char.  Appearance:  Good pop when opening; orange/golden brown color; clean; beige crown that quickly gathers on the pour and the fades away to the edges...  Flavor:  Delicious, intense, smooth, rich, sugary caramel maltiness; vanilla; charred oak; dry bourbon with just a bit of bite and bitterness in the finish.  Palate:  Medium-bodied; quite smooth; slightly mellow mouthfeel with just the right tingle of carbonation.  Overall:  Still damn good; more dry (compared to when its fresh and young) with lots of bourbon coming through.
12 fl. oz. bottle (Alc By Vol. 8.7%) with twist-off cap. Score:  8/3/8/4/17 = 4.0
I had had the Dirty Bastard before trying this one.  My thought was "Well, I loved Dirty Bastard, so that aged in Bourbon Barrels can only mean its better."  Good thing I was totally right.

12 ounce bottle courtesy of daknole... I think. Pours a deep cranberry red color... thick and viscous looking with minute floating particles. Medium head with decent head retention and lacing. Big bourbony aroma with vanilla and toffee notes. Taste is bourbon, slight roast, caramel, toffee, vanilla, very light bitterness in the finish. Medium bodied. Overall a bit too much bourbon for me but still pretty good.

Bottle. Poors thin with minimal carbonation. Nice bourbon nose with a pleasant woodiness in the background. Taste of strong Bourbon, Oak, and dark fruit. Much more bourbon taste than I got from the nose. Overall a great BA beer.

12oz bottle. Was a gift from Nate. Ive always been fascinated with the label on this bottle. The old man with his axe. Now on to the review! Pours a cloudy brown color with almost no head. Aroma of sweet and roasted malts, some hint to fruit as well, although i cant determine which. Taste of bourbon, with some spice. The malt comes through roasted and quite nice. Slight bitter aftertaste but not bad in the least. I will be buying some of these the next time I get a chance.
bottle.  Pours a dark brown with a thin tan head.  Nose is of bourbon, vanilla and dark fruit.  Taste is of bourbon, vanilla, spice and bready malt.  Mouthfeel is medium with some alcohol.

12oz bottle.  thick heavy pour with finger of tan head.  color was deep copper-brown.  aroma of bourbon, alcohol, caramel malt and hint of apple.  tastes of earthy oak, cherry, light vanilla, brown sugar and a bready quality.  definitely a lot going on.  full slick texture.  dry, tingly and alcohol in the finish.

Draft pour. Sweet and bourbony big nose. 
Very vibrant flavors combine interestingly. Lots going on with vanilla notes, some sweet and spicy notes, scotch and malts. Interesting and good

Bottle courtesy of thecheesman.  Pours brown with an off white head.  Smells of sweet malt, molasses, bourbon, oak, raidins.  Tastes bitter with some nice spicy compliments, oak, bourbon, some smoke.  Nice balance here.  The Bourbon barrels really compliment this one.

Mahogany with suspended particulates and a large slowly dissolving tan head that leaves some splotchy lace.  Aroma of toffee, bourbon, sweet malt and alcohol.  Taste of bourbon, toffee, scotch, bready malt and alcohol.  Pretty full mouth feel with some warming going on the backend.

Pours murky dark amber-tinted brown with a 3 finger creamy yellow tan head that has awesome retention and leaves nice lacing. Aroma is caramel, bourbon, smoke, vanilla, hints of overripe red apples, oak, toasted nuts, hints of leather, rich grainy malts, a little licorice, roast and rich toffee. Flavor is caramel apple, a hint of citrus and toast up front, soon the rich bourbon and vanilla, fresh cut oak, gooey fresh caramel, honey roasted nuts, lots of earthy notes, smokey malts, a touch of roast, sweet toffee and herbal hops. Finish is has herbal, bourbon and woordy characteristics while retaining a fantastic smoky, toasty, nutty rich caramel backbone. Fantastic beer, everything really comes together amazingly. Palate is medium to thick body with a failry slick and sticky feel most of the way through and a soft, but active carbonation.

Bottle.  Brown sugar brown red color.  Hazy and clumpy.  Uber-malty, apple hints, vanilla, cherries.  Deceptive.  I expected a sugar flavoring but instead got more subtle sweet/sharp play off one another from the initial flavoring and a creamy vanilla and lavender finish.  Nice.  Tricky.

(Bottle via trade with pantanap, thanks Kan!) Pours muddy brown-amber with a stout finger or so of light amberish-biege head. Aroma of toffee, caramel, cola and licorice. Mouthfeel fairly smooth, medium-heft, just a touch sticky on the back end. Light, weepy rings of lacing. Flavor of toffee, birch beer, caramel, licorice and hints of peat. A bitter snap in the finish. ABV well-hidden. Pretty tasty.

UPDATED: DEC 16, 2009 12oz bottle.  Thick orange brown color, opaque.  Wow.  This walks the like between Scotch Ale and Barleywine, always careful to stay in Scotch Ale territory.  Excellently rich and malty, with a dark fruit toffee sweetness.  Some smoke as well.  There is a slight cherry edge to the aftertaste.  The bourbon is pleasantly balanced, not dominating in the least.  This is craft brew at its best.

This beer was surely better before it went into the bourbon barrel.  I dont taste any of the cherry.  There is some dirt and medium sweet malt.  Bourbon is in the aroma and the flavor, but in this beer, I dont think it helps, but only covers the other flavors.

12oz bottle at our KW group tasting, thanks to kmallet, thanks Kyle. This one went over really well and with good reason. Pours a hazy orangy-amber with a small off-white head. The aroma is just awesome, piney, minty, hoppy, super malty, boozy, Earthy to the max. Flavour matches up well, same as above, with a really good full-mouthfeel, and a touch of maple which wasnt present in the aroma. Absolutely delicious. Astringency balances out the ample sweetness, and the booze is well in check and not at all cloying. Thanks again Kyle!

On tap at the Hopcat in Grand Rapids. Bourbon dominates the nose. Nice creamy head. I usually look for subtle bourbon but the bourbon dominates this. I got very little nose or flavor other than bourbon and for me that isnt good.
UPDATED: JUN 26, 2009 pours a dark amber with a light tan head.  notes of alcohol, syrup, and, in addition to the alchol, i also thought their were notes of bourbon.  idiot.
a little different from nov. still nose of cream soda floats persists, bourbon cinnamon oatmeal and proofing coffee role. smooth cream oak and vanilla. light pin carbonation.
Bottle. Aroma of oak and mostly whiskey. Clear amber with a thin bubbly head. Bourbon and oak flavors, clean and subdued. Thin and slightly flat. A bit on the bland side.

12 oz. bottle.  Pours cloudy, but somewhat translucent reddish-brown, with a small white head.  Aroma is very scotchy - peat, oak, and some smoke and sweet malts, molasses as it warms. Flavor is again peaty and scotchy, but with a nice sweet malty backbone and some spice and fruit. Medium body, moderate carbonation, smooth. Interesting, enjoyable beer.

Pours with a clear red body topped by a thin to medium thick head with some lacing.  ITs slightly sweet and malty with  notes of vanilla, oak and alcohol as well as caramel and molasses.  Full bodied, wamring and a touch dry.
Cloudy amber, thick tan head. Wood and butter aroma. Creamy smooth taste, an excellent barrel beer. Sweet and smooth.
Pours a murky brown. Boozey, sweet caramel, some smoke in the nose. Flavor is alcoholic, warm, spicy and earthy. Medium body. Good sipper.

Sampled from 12-oz bottle supplied by joebrew. Pours a semi-clear copper amber colored brew with a nice off-white head that slowly dissipates to a thin white ring. Aroma of caramel malt, a hint of vanilla, some dark pitted fruit and a touch of bourbon. Taste is medium bodied, with flavors of caramel malt, vanilla, some flowery hops, bourbon and a touch of smoked oak. Finish is semi-sweet with a light vanilla and alcohol warmth aftertaste.

Bottle. Pours a hazy dark bronze with a a small white head. Strong aroma of bourbon with a hint of vanilla and smoke. Flavor is heavy on the bourbon and vanilla. This one doesnt impress me... comes across too bourbony, and the flavors dont mix well with the style of beer.
Butters cellar blowout tasting. Nice nose of bourbony goodness. Butter, bacon and bourbon barrel on the nose. Buttered biscuity texture. Thats an awesome beer. Wow
Butters Big Blowout - Pours a murky sweet tea color. Aroma of malt, caramel, dark fruit, bourbon, smoke. Similar taste.

Bottle at Butters Big Cellar Blowout.  Pours a beige head with a copper body.  Smells of vanilla, oak, and some malt and fresh hops.  Flavor is vanilla, oak, caramel, and bourbon.  Finish is slightly bitter and bourbon.  Old moonshiner man bottle label is awesome.

This poured a a dark red to brown color with an off white head. aroma was lots of caramel, coffee, some dark fruits and maybe some bourbon too. Flavor was really sweet, some tobacco, sweet malts dark fruits and some chocolate as well maybe. This was a pretty good beer.!

12 ounce bottle. This beer seemed to pour very thick. I am not sure if it is how I poured it or if it is a characteristic of the beer. It had a very deep amber color with a one finger width tan head that stuck around for a good while. The aroma consists of a lot of caramel malt, a lot of bourbon and alcohol, and some light smoke in the background. As the beer warmed, I could smell some dried fruit also. My first sip of this beer had a huge alcohol warming. It also consisted of caramel and roasted malts, light bourbon, and some dark dried fruit. Overall, this was a very good scotch ale but I would prefer Dirty Bastard to this one...

12 oz bottle courtesy of TheEpeeist. Wonderful. Pours a thicker brownish rusty amber, with small tannish head that laces some and sticks around. Aromas are similar to the original, pushing caramel and vanilla over light roast, toffee and biscuits, with light peat and moving to some nice oak that accentuates these flavors well, pushing more oak and vanilla and bourbon. Exciting. Initial is full bodied, picking up more oak and bourbon up front, trailing into vanilla and caramel with toffee and biscuits, light peat and smoke. A bit of warmth, but pretty smooth overall. A bit of bitterness on the backend balances, and oak and vanilla with caramel and bourbon seem to leave an impressive aftertaste with that touch of warmth. Good body, strong. Cheers!

Bottle, courtesy of my in-laws.  Very dark brown, good sized tan head.  Great aroma - lots of bourbon, tons of alcohol, but smokey woody sweet scotch ale lingers underneath as well.  First sip is almost overwhelming - huge alcohol and huge bourbon.  But the Scotch Ale shines through again - this is why you need a big solid beer when you do this bourbon stuff - great smokey and woody notes, huge alcohol and by the end the huge bourbon is balanced really well.  I was really impressed with this one.

[Tap]  Very deep red with tan head.   Aroma was smokey with some sweet caramel sneaking through.  Taste was roasted and smokey.  Sweet caramel and bourban accents.  Somewhat thick and very smooth.   Fantastic beer, one of my favorites overall.

Rich and complex.  Has a strong bourbon flavor with lots of caramel and some cherry and oak flavor.  Head dissipates pretty quickly.  Smell has caramel bourbon vanilla and oak.  This is some really nice bourbon aged beer.
I dont know what it was, but for some reason, the flavors in this one just did not meld well at all.  I had a lot of trouble just finishing it.  :(
on tap @Caponespours a thin retaining white head and amber color.  Aroma is oak, medium malt-peat, bourbon.  Taste is oak, medium malt-peat, bourbon/boozy, some earthy hops.  Mild carbonation.

UPDATED: JUL 26, 2009 Easy to like and easy to enjoy, but not a good idea to study it too hard.  Backwoods bastards wouldnt anyway.  A simple enough brown ale, I think, but who can tell, really?  The bourbon barrel, vanilla and tannins from the oak dominate everything.  Thats not unpleasant.  Its nice, actually, in a sweet and uncomplicated way.  Average mouth, average appearance, hazy brown, small head.  I liked it more than the numbers show.  Hell, you could drink this instead of macro beer forever.  But it would get boring fast.// OK, bump the rating up a bit.  It is enjoyable.

12 oz bottle:  Thin, short lived head with a murky chestnut brown body.  Alcohol cut the water in the glass immediately upon the pour.  Yeast was poured with the rest of the beer.  The aroma starts with a freshly crushed pale malt and roasty (roasted malt), light bourbon and wood aromas (oddly cherry).  Slight alcohol;  Vanilla and spicy (alcohol).  Hints of smokiness.  Toasty malt as it warms.  Flavor is well balanced, slightly sweet in the finish and aftertaste, but to be expected from a "wee heavy".  Caramel, toasty malt, again freshly crushed pale malt, clean flavor.  Light bourbony character.  Very light vanilla flavor.  Aftertaste is light bourbon, vanilla, and toasty malt.  Lighter medium CO2, fuller body, but lightly dry in the mouth. Relatively well hidden alcohol. There are a few beer styles that work well with barrel aging IMHO, and this is one of them!  I was expecting a beer with a sweeter finish, but maybe the barrel aging has helped to dry it out  a bit?
aroma is tons of whiskey and spice. some vanilla and oaky sweetness come through. drank fairly fresh and was still hot at 10.2abv. great drink with a nice warming following. pick one up

330 mL from the AEPi inaugural tasting. Pours a deep mahogany with a small, yellow head. Is this a barleywine? Aroma is 100% Johnny Walker Black Label. Nothing else. Taste is watered down Johnny Walker with some caramel malt struggling to come through. Aftertaste is charred oak. This is bourbon barrel aged but is just too much for me. I would rather take a shot of bourbon than suffer all night trying to finish this.

bottle.
Bottle art alone is worth the price on this one.
Pours a dark opaque brown with some deep amber highlights around the edges.  little to no head.
Smells mostly of boozy bourbon wood, without much else going on in the nose.
Flavor tends towards being a bit one-dimensional, but not bad.  Flavor is dominated by the wood and bourbon notes.  Booze is contained, but the woody notes run wild in the flavor.  Beneath that, some notes of tart apples and belgian quad-ish dark fruits.
Decent on the palate/finish- nothing especially impressive, good or bad.
Holy smoke was this good.  Great caramel, smoke and bourbon flavors throughout.  Pours deep amber-brown with very little head.  Would drink again.

On tap at Capones.  Deep dark brown color with no head.  Aroma of bourbon, caramel and roasted malts.  Tip the glass to the palate and the caramel, roasted malts, and smoke pleases with an ever-present bourbon undertone.  Really enjoyed this one!

Amber-brown in colour with a thin but very long lasting tan head, some light lacing.  The aroma is very sweet, some bourbon, alcohol, chocolate and oak.  The flavour is warming and lightly alcoholic, chocolate and toffee sweetness, very woody and the bourbon doesnt make any attempt to hide.  Hot mouthfeel, medium body, medium carbonation.  Finish lingering and is quite warm.
The hit in the face alcohol punch was a surprise considering the initial balance that this had.
355ml bottle obtained in a trade with TheCheeseMan, thanks Dan.
Opened on June 30, 2008.
No date.
Thanks DrHomolka!  Hazed dark amber.  Soft aroma of smoked wood.  Mellow bourbon really stands out over the caramel malt, very tasty and satisfying.

Bottle via bonus from oobawa. Pours a hazy mahogany with a medium sized pale brown head. Nose is raw bourbon/scotch at first blush then mellows and nice vanilla and caramel come through.  Bourbon/scotch and alcohol are heavy on the tongue. It eases at it drinks to bring out the vanilla and oak tones. Very smooth mouth. If you are in the mood for a stiff drink this is a good and relaxing drink to wind down the day.

Thin head which dissipates quickly.  Slight sheen of foam lingering on top.  Strong bourbon aroma with loads of sweet caramel, maple syrup and some smoke.  Bourbon dominates all other aromas though.  Color is a dark crimson mahagony.  Nice color.  Thiner body than expected.  Bourbon is a bit less intense in the flavor.  Lots of butter, sweet malts, wood and some smoked grains.  Decent bitterness late swallow.  Strong alcohol presence that stings and warms.  Finishes buttery smooth and creamy with a lingering sharp bitterness.  Not sure if this is a scotch ale but it is still pretty tasty.  Bourbon may be a little bit strong but not totally overpowering.
Poured brown with small bubbly off white head. Aroma of candy and bourbon. Very solid bourbon flavor with some sweetness. Finished harsh. Got worse as it warmed.

Bottle at BA tasting in Nashville. Pours mahogany with a thin head. Medium bodied with a slight sticky texture. Aroma of maple and smoke. Flavor of dark caramel and vanilla- rather simple. Some alcohol on the finish, but not in a detrimental way. I dont get a ton of barrel characteristics on this one.

A nice little scotch, gotten in trade.  Pours medium with good lasting white head, tons of lace.Aroma is decent bourbon. Mouthfeel is easy, average and smooth, good bourbon taste not in-your-face that is well integrated and woody.  Very drinkable.

Pours a deep brown with a tan head - aroma is pure bourbon - couldnt smell anything beyond that.  The taste was reminiscent of drinking a shot of Jack Daniels with a little beer splashed in it.  Very different from any beer I have tried before.  This is definitely a sipping beer.  I have a neighbor who loves bourbon and loves beer that will love this stuff.  A solid brew but not one I could drink regularly.

Wawaweewah!  This is overpowering.  Looks great with a deep red and brown pour and a lasting thin tan head.  The aroma is pure scotch.  That is all I can find because it is so strong.  The flavor is straight up scotch.  A little vanilla and coffee shows up if you really look hard, but you have to look hard.  I dont know what to say.  It warms me up, but the complexity is totally sacrificed to the whiskey.  Try it, because it is completely original, but dont buy a six pack unless you know what you are getting yourself into.

Bottle.  Very cool label, looks like my Grandpa....haha ((bottle I got was different than the one pictured).  Pours a very deep brown with a one finger beige head.  Nose was big on bourbon, with some vanilla, oak, caramel and a touch of booze.  Flavor was sweet and woody with a good alcohol kick......good stuff.
Taste 3/1 Bottle. Looks: Deep opaque brown with a tone finger head. Aroma: Vanilla, bourbon alcohol and molasses. Taste: Vanilla, molasses, chocolate, oak and bourbon. Quite good.

UPDATED: FEB 8, 2011 Poured bronze and cloudy with floaters the head was very small and light tan aromas abound off roasted heavy malts and a slight bourbon and alcohol,taste was of heavy malts,oak and bourbon this was a very nice but mild bourbon cask adventure the bourbon by no means overpowers the maltiness of this wee heavy with a 10.2 ABV the flavor of alcohol is not just boubon infused

12oz bottle: Ruby red pour with a brownish core and skinny tan cap. Lots of yeasties floating throughout the body. A decent mix of oak and caramel malt meet the nose, but nothing special. The body expands the relationship, with more oak depth, some vanilla and butterscotch. Finishes really bitter and slightly chalky. Eh, the combo is okay, but doesnt sing for me. I think the barrel wins out eventually and it is just too much oak and grassy bitterness that dont mesh. Still a nice beer, maybe some time in the cellar with help things come to together a bit more smoothly.

Bottle shared.  Poured dark brown with a small tan head.  Aroma of bourbon, oak, vanilla, dark fruit, caramel.  Taste is very heavy on the vanilla, with some of the oak and bourbon coming in as well.  Very malty, almost no hop presence.  Body is full and carbonation is very light.  Overall, a nice oak aged scotch ale.

355ml bottle, bourbon barrel aged, dark mahogany color, with a small tan-colored head, sweet toasty, boubonish oaky nose, with some nice vanilla, fruity, raisiny, coconut grated accents, with some caramel, toffe notes in the aroma follows through on a full-bodied palate, with a sweet toasted, biscuity malt, cookie dough, fruitcake character, with some warmth bourbon oaky, woody, vanilla, raisiny, plummy flavors, with a faint chocolatey, kind of grated coconut note, and a hint of flowery hop citrus leafiness, leading towards a fruity, bourbon oaky, warming, lingering hop biterness finish.

Malty caramel and alcoholic raisins dominate the smell. This is a cloudy beer. Its a bit drier than I expected. The good thing is the bourbon aroma and flavor from the barrel aging is not overwhelming.

Apperance:  A dark auburn that lets almost no light through. Atop is a 1/2 inch tight knit head.

Aroma: Bourbon, vanilla, and chocolate.

Taste:  Vanilla, chocolate, and a nice bit of oak.

Mouthfeel: A bit on the thin side and perfectly carbonated.

Overall:  A wonderful beer, that may go down too quick because of how easy it is to drink.

Bottle at Sunset Grill.  Solid.  Almost like a Christmas beer on steroids for its woody, piney, bright flavor that is super balanced.  Very thick texture that is quite smooth at the same time.  Oak notes, light bourbon.  The smoothest peat flavor I have ever contacted, with light earth notes as well.

UPDATED: FEB 28, 2009 Beautiful appearance, dark mahogany reddish color; this wispy head. Bourbonish nose, wood. Bourbonish flavor, rubber, barrel, medium sweetness, actually reminds me of some sherried single malt scotches. A lot of body without feeling too thick, slight alcohol warmth, perfectly carbonated. Just rough enough around the edges to keep me interested. Actually its this semi-bitter earthy core that holds this beer together. Not terribly complex but tasty, well made, and interesting. Its official, Founders is my favorite American brewery. I wish I was a better writer / beer drinker so that I could do this beer justice. I say that to myself after every great beer that I cant describe. Damn, this really hit the spot. I would totally drink another one if I didnt know this is (likely) my only 4 pack for the rest of the year and that its $4 a bottle.

Edit: Okay I ended up drinking a second bottle. This is such an easy drinker I could have gone for a third, but that would be my last bottle for the year, so Im saving it for another time. A few hours later, no headache, no stomachache, this beer just made me doze off to sleep for an evening nap and I woke up feeling great. What a great beer. I cant wait to get some more next year.

Bottle.  Pours red/brown with rimming white head.  Nose of bourbon, oak, caramel and brown sugar.  Taste is bourbon and caramel with brown sugar and a good dose of alcohol.  Burning and lingering a bit, but tasty nonetheless.  Tasty tasty.

Pours very dark brown burnt sugar color.  Has a small frothy beige head.  Aroma smells like caramel covered smoked oak.  Huge caramel bourbon character.  A bit of sweetness and a decent alcohol flavor.  Nice vanilla character as well.  Thick and rich body.  Thanks for this, Juart.

Murky reddish-brown with no head.  Very whiskeyish aroma with chewy earthiness underneath.  Lots of vanilla and bourbon.  Light caramel notes as well.  Its burly, but Im not sure what they are trying to do.  The base beer and the barrel dont really ever find common ground here and it comes across the palate a muddled mess.

Muddy copper-brown and totally opaque. Hot aroma. Then, loads of pears and apples after the alcohol burns off. Retains a lot of the apple and pear pits and the cores throughout the aroma and body. Low carbonation. Flavors also include vanilla as if it were added. Unimpressive.

12 oz. bottle. Deep, clear ruby with a small beige head and sliding, spotty lace. Unmistakeable bourbon and oak aroma, vanilla, roasted nuts, and hints of dark fruit. Medium to full body with a rich and silky mouthfeel. Lots of brown sugar with a tangy bitterness that slowly develops inot a lasting dryness. Alcohol is well hidden.

Aging a SCOTCH ale in WHISKY barrels?  Who would have thought.  This magnificent bastard Bastard was the perfect pick for the whisky treatment, IMO.  Smooth as can be, and one tasty bastard.  Highly rec.
Bottle thanks to Mar.   The smell is bourbon, malts, caramel, wood, and sweetness.  The look is reddish in color and clear.  The taste is sweet, malty, wood, bourbon, vanilla, and some toffee.

2008 Bottle - Thanks tjthresh! - Pours a deep brown with a tiny off white head...aroma is bourbon oak, dry fruit and a bit of peat...flavour is similar, sweet and boozy...I get a ton of barrel and not much else...decent beer...!
From the tap poured dark brown/black with a small head.  Nice malty flavor, a little syrupy with a lasting finish.

On tap at Founders,served in a snifter. A ruby/purple color with a thin white cap that fades quickly and leaves some nice lacing. Aroma is vanilla, oak,alcohol(Burbon)and maybe even some dry barly grain. Flavor is very earthy peaty,lots of burbon notes oak,vanilla,alcohol,rye bread,brown sugar,very complex.Full mouthfeel,medium carbonation,dry boozy finish. Very good brew if you like burbon but not something that I would drink more than one of at a sitting.

Pours a slightly vigorous head to cover the beer for a half second, what is there is a amber tinged tan color. The beer is a dark plum / dark amber color that shows a lightly hazy, cranberry red hue when held up to the light. At the first, the aroma is a nice mix between rich malt notes and oak aromatics.  However the flavour is slightly more complex than the aroma, with a dry astringency in addition to the sweet vanilla Bourbon. Sweet butterscotch, oak, and bakers chocolate as well. Slightly thin feel, with some harsh boozy fire midway through.  This is not a bad brew, but the bourbon character is a bit much, especially as the beer warms up a bit.  An ok beer, and really not my style, but drinkable enough though.
user_location: The Crystal Coast, North Carolina, USA

text: Bottle thanks to Mar. Pours a reddish brown, murky, with beige head. Aroma of citrus, floral, tangy, some wild yeast. Flavor is sweet, fruit, hops, some bitter. Mouthfeel is medium body with med-high carbonation. Overall, great stuff!

Bottle thanks to Mar. New bottle art that is much better. Pours a Burnt caramel color with only a light tan ring for a head. No lacing. Notes of cherry, vanilla, toffee, bourbon, and new hardwood floors. Medium sweet body and medium to long finish.

bottle poured a muddy brown color and has a quickly diminishing off white head. aroma has sweet bourbon, vanilla, custard, dark malt, and some chocolate. mouth feel is medium but coats well.,flavor has a healthy sweetness, nice bourbon, light barrel wood, vanilla, and some dark malt. very desert like but not overly sweet. barrel wood level is just right without any biting roast to cover up the juicy bourbon.

From bottle courtesy of dpjuart. Awesome oaky aroma with bourbon and vanilla. Caramel, licorice. Smooth and light hops - phenomenal aroma. Ruby coppery amber clear, dark, with foamy off-white lacing head. Medium heavy body with medium carbonation. Huge bourbon flavor, woody with light smoke. Mild bitter hop character. Like a weak bourbon drink - just terrific.

Cakey, bread pudding, vanilla, light bourbon, and a carraway seed yeastiness, holy moses!  This reminds me of what a a great quad should taste like without the carbonation of course.  Aroma and Flavor are everything above but lighter in the aroma and heavier on the flavor.  Mouthfeel is excuisite!!  Milky and substantial.  This could be dessert or this could be the meal.  Not for hop lovers at all, definitely for the malty balls set.  The head on this beer has more flavor and aroma than most other beers overall.  Right up there with the Curmudgeon. 2008 12 oz.  Thank You Founders.  God Bless Michigan.

12 oz bottle purchased from Chucks Liquor in Bowling Green.  Poured a dark brown color with red highlights and a two finger creamy tan head.  The aroma was vanilla, oak and bourbon.  The flavor was overwhelming.  Think Jack Daniels Lite.  This was heavy with bourbon and vanilla in the flavor.  I couldnt actually taste the scotch ale part of the beer.  Now, I like bourbon bombs, so this wasnt all together a disappointment, but it wasnt a well conceived beer.

deep murky brown color with a creamy light tan head.  aroma is sweet with notes of vanilla, fig, mild oak, and bourbon.  flavor reminds me of a sweet stout up front (kinda like bells double cream) and follows up very smoothly with dark fruits and roasty vanilla bourbon.  mouthfeel is outstanding...creamy and just enough warming at the finish to cut the sweetness.  great beer!

So, Ive had several of Founders offerings, and Im definitely proud to call them a favorite home state brewer, but I think they really out did themselves on this one. It literally smells like a vintage chardonnay, and tastes like a good aged bourbon, but with perfectly balanced sweetness and carbonation. I would say this beer is near perfection, and I say bravo to the genius behind this fantastic brew. Cheers!
Lovely bourbon aroma hits you as you go for a drink. Dark body with little head. Vey tasty.
I think Founders should stay away from the Scotch Ale category.....they just cant seem to get it right. I didnt like anything about this beer.....blah.

Deep garnet-tinted brown beer.  Thin to non-existent head.  Aroma is really nice and lovely.  Sweet rich toffee and butterscotch over a rich deep malt character.  A light sweet peaty note that just kisses the deeper caramel and heavily toasted malts.  Very rich and malty smokiness with an intense nuttiness.  Loads of what seems like kettle caramelization.  Rich and sweet flavour but there is also loads of peppery ethanolic heat on the back of the palate.  Its plenty tasty in small doses, but even 10 oz seems like a little bit too much for one serving.  Intensely sweet.  Light vanilla and peat through the middle and warming up seems to smooth it out a little bit.  Its quite nice.

bottle says 10.2% and is a completely different label from what is shown.  deep ruby color thats almost black with no head at all.  vanilla, malts, peat and bourbon.  thick on the palate with a big peaty flavor with a touch of bourbon and vanilla in the finish to fix you just right.
Dark amber with a decent head. Aroma of sweet, earthy malt. Flavor is much the same: rich and tangy. Highly enjoyable.

bottle at Ft Wayne locals tasting courtesy of bdigi66 - Well I noted that this dark amber beer smells like bourbon.  Duh.  Theres some malt in there too but the bourbon aroma is dominant.  The flavor is more balanced.  Theres still lots of bourbon there, but sweet roast malt and even some light hops are present too.  Its full bodied yet very drinkable.  Excellent.

Thick red tinted brown pour with a thin white head. Creamy oak bourbon aroma with hints of licorice.  Tastes pretty much like smooth light bourbon.  Malty with a hoppy finish.  But mostly a bourbon sans the burning.  I like bourbon  but Im basically a pussy when it comes to the burning sensation it induces, so this stuff is perfect for me and I really enjoyed it.

Trade with noncaloric. Moderate head. Red amber beer. Alcohol (bourbon?) and molasses in the aroma. First sip is alcohol body, used chewing tobacco, molasses, an alcohol shiver and long caramel-molasses-toffee notes. An entire pint of flavour in each sip. A rollercoaster for your palate. Second taste is brandy and chocolate. Another is sweet licorice toffee. A bottle full of surprises.

UPDATED: NOV 21, 2010 Had to re rate this, it is really a fine beer.  Pours a dark rust color with a thin tan head with nice lacing.  Oak and bourbon are the prominent aromas, touches of smoke and sweet caramel.  Starts out with exactly what it smells like, bourbon and oak, but then dramatically changes to a smokey sweet flavor, almost like a mellow bbq sauce, and finishes out with dark ripe frutis, ash, and a very faint touch of hops that linger.  Thick and rich, definitely a sipper.  Outstanding, complex but balanced.

Aroma is sweet, bourbon, caramel.  Deep red body, thin ring of head around the edges, it looks a little hazy.  Rich and intense flavors of boubon, vanilla, chocolate, caramel, citrusy hops.  Prior batch was 9.2%, this bottle (2008) says 10.2% - either way, this is not one for your beer bong.

20090121  12oz bottle  Muddy brown with small, fleeting beige head.  Aroma is rich with dates, old wood, cellar stairs, tobacco, and last nights red wine residue crusted in the bottom of a glass.  Fairly light bodied and quite bitter, more than expected, with a woody astringency that is both anticipated and not very welcome.  Lingering metallic notes, quartz, and strong vinous notes throughout meld smoothly with the theme but do not thrill.

Draft at Capones Nov 08:  Poured a dark dark red color with not much head.  The aroma was a strong bourbon.  The flavor was over powered by the bourbon with some oak and vanilla present  An Interesting beer.

UPDATED: NOV 12, 2009 Ruby red with a tan head.  Very bourbon forward aroma overwhelms caramelized scotch ale notes.  Taste has the same balance with serious oak tannins with a lot of vanillin and a slightly tangy, rather bitter finish.  I very much enjoyed it, but feel like it could have a bit less oak for my liking. $6/13oz
RERATE from 3.6 total score.  Much more civil bourbon character in the bottle this time with incredible coconut notes.  Reminds me a bit of Weyerbacher Insanity.

Bottle.  Very strong bourbon aroma.  Opaque reddish brown body, almost no head.  Flavor is overwhelmingly bourbon whiskey, very foreign to my conception of beer.  Certainly tasty, but MUCH too far in the direction of bourbon in my opinion.

12 oz bottle. Pours a dark brown with a light-tan small head that dissipated quickly. Smells of roasted nut, some typical scotch smells, and A LOT of bourbon. Smell kind of reminds me of GIs Bourbon Co. stout.  Tastes of roasted flavors, malt, and only a little bourbon (surprisingly little compared to the smell). Very smooth to swallow though, and has a very nice feel in the mouth afterwards. Aftertaste has some vanilla too.

Bottle from Daniel.  Pours out a brown color with not much of a head at all.  Smell is instantly full of bourbon notes and some roasted malts.  Taste is overly malty without much hop flavor at all.  Full of bourbon notes, woody, very oaky as well.  Interesting beer, lots of alcohol burn too.  Interesting beer, but not near the quality of the wee heavy alesmith.  Not much to say for this one..

pours out a darker brown color with a small beige head.  aroma was that of your typical scotch ale with a hefty dose of bourbon.  flavor was great, but a bit raw with the bourbon.  i had difficulty at first tasting anything but bourbon

Dark amber red pour with not much head. Smells like whiskey. Flavors were exciting. Chocolate, caramel, vanilla, some smOAKiness. Light drying citrus hop. Lingering spirit taste with dripppy lacing and medium heavy mouth. Nice carb. Little coffee or chocolate smell on a swirl. Still an element of watered down drink here, but intricate and overall, a winner.

the 1st time I had this was at champanes at a founders tasting in Nov. and loved it . got  a 4 pack a couple of days ago. aroma big hit of bourbon, alcohol, chocolate, coffee dark fruits. flavor, bourbon, malts, chocolate, alcohol some vanilla, plums. This is going to go down to naples fl. to share with flemdawg to toast the birth of his son.

UPDATED: FEB 7, 2010 In short: A woody strong ale.  Very drinkable but very simple.
How: Bottle 12oz, probably about 6 months old.  Graciosity of kmweaver, thanks a lot Ken!
The look: Cloudy brow body with some red highlight topped by a very small beige head.
In long: Shy nose of molasses and some dark fruits.  Taste has a lot of wood/barrel but not much of the advertised bourbon (which imho is a good thing).  Rather dry despite the initially sweet attack.  Overall rather simplistic taste of wood/barrel with notes of dark caramel, alcohol and dark grapes.  Nice beer but about as complex as complex as a cheap Dinner napkin puzzle.

Pours very cloudy dark copper with thick lacing from tan dense head. Chocolate and plum notes in the nose.  Rich chocolate flavor is quickly replaced with alcoholic/whiskey notes.  Vanilla undertones add to this very intriguing and complex beer.

Bottle, courtesy SeaBass. Pours a murky brownish red, thin lacing, white head. Aroma is hot, licorice, some apricot, mostly alcohol. Flavor is nice bourbon with some chocolate, peanut butter, some smooth licorice. Smooth, soft, chewable, very tasty.

Sampled at tronraners Xmas Eve^3 tasting.  Hazy brownish amber pour with a huge boozy nose.  Flavor is massively earthy and bourbon.  This could be a pretty enjoyable brew if you are looking to get drunk.
Dark amber pour with a light amber head.  Aroma heavy with bourbon, vanilla and sweet roasted malt.  Taste mirrors aroma.  Strong heady brew with taste that speaks of more alcohol than 9.2%.

Bottle picked up at Brawley’s in Charlotte.  Clear dark mahogony color with a tan head.  Bourbon, oak, and boozy aroma.  Woody, vanilla, more bourbon, and a nice caramel scotch ale backbone.  Velvety mouthfeel with a slightly hot finish.  Nice barrel aged beer!!
Awesome Brew. Great Bourbon flavor with a nice hint of smoke and hops. Really good.

bottle from secret santa.  somewhat cloudy brown pour, light tan head.   Aroma has bourbon, vanilla, wood, molasses, hops and syrup.  Flavor has understated bourbon notes with a great hop balance.  Sweet honey notes, wood and vanilla are present.  Very nice beer.  Thanks santa!!!

Courtesy of kiefdog. Pours brown with tan head. The aroma is bold and yummy with wood, vanilla, molasses and sweet booze. The taste is similar with wood, vanilla and sweet bourbon followed by sludgy molasses and stewed sugary cherries. Yum. It is smooth and silky.

Nice oak aging here that keeps its cool and stays really smooth. Aromas of vanilla and wood. Flavor is roughly the same with a hint of sweetness on the finish. Pour is a dark copper color with a ton of sediment. Under the vanilla and oak you have a bit of red fruit flavors, plum, and some molasses.  Pretty tasty.

courtesy of kiefdog.
Hard to go wrong with any of Founders Bourbon beers. Just pure goodness.
Pours amber with beige head.
Aroma has really good notes of Bourbon and vanilla.
Taste is extremely smooth, with presence of the Bourbon barrel and oak. Finish is lightly hoppy.
This bottle had actual abv of 10.2
Excellent, too bad it is hard to come by.

Bottle from Crown Liquors (Indianapolis, IN). Pours a dark brown cola color with thin tan head. Aroma is decidedly malt and bourbon with notes of maple syrup, sweet dark chocolate, ripe dark fruit, some hints of oak and vanilla. Flavor is also sweet and malty with candy sugar, bourbon, ripe dark fruit, chocolate, and caramel overtones. Generally syrupy mouthfeel with a pleasing phenol note on finish.

UPDATED: DEC 27, 2011 Thank kiefdog for the share. Wow. Pours a red-brown with a nose of smoke, maple, brown sugar, molasses, and sweet malty vanilla. Flavor is same with bourbon and lingering sugary maple. Awesome beer that sticks me in the nose- I do not want to stop smelling this beer, and the flavor does not disappoint either. Excellent Scotch Ale/ Wee Heavy.

Bottle courtesy of kiefdog. Pours a clear amber with a one finger off-white head that leaves good lacing. Aroma is earthy with notes of caramel, sweet malt, oak, bourbon, and vanilla. Taste is the same as aroma but more prominent. Medium mouthfeel with a moderate amount of bitterness and very well hidden alcohol. This beer is freakin delicious.
bottle, muddy almond color, slight head, aroma of malty scotch whiskey, flavor is quite different with celery seed, parsley, butterscotch and raw oak, finish is strong but not overpowering

12oz bottle from WLV Liquours.  Pours a muddy ruby brown with a creamy soapy beige head.  Dark fruits, licorice, and bourbon are abundant and delicious in the nose.  More dark fruits, and bourbon flavors, the licorice flavor takes on a charred note, with vanilla, oak, and a bitter licorice finish.  If you like scotch ales this is one extreme, but great example of it.  Tasty stuff.

Bottle...medium cloudy brown with a tan head...drippy lacing forming...sweet malt aroma with bourbon aroma...strong bourbon...strong alcohol presence and more bourbon...damn holy alcohol!....its like a shot of bourbon with a beer chaser...creamy heavy body...so bourbon fufilled its hard to taste much else...sweet finish...bitter chocolate...minor....Frank tastes moleasses and apricots through the napkin influence

12 oz. bottle - big thanks to eclectic for this killer bonus brew; pours with a thin tan head and mostly flat, clear dark brown; minor floaties; aromas of bourbon, vanilla, chocolate, candy and alcohol; drinks very sweet and strong; not too much of a bite, but you can feel the high ABV going down; had a great chocolaty smoothness to it going down; vanilla, oak, dank fruit and sugar; almost a BW in texture and aromas; more memorable than the regular Dirty Bastard

Pours a darkened reddish brown.  Big frothy tan head with a little stickiness.  Heavy sugary nose.  Caramel, vanilla, bourbon, and a crazy likeness to spiced coconut rum.  Flavor is laden with bourbon and smoky peat.  Heavy alcohol, caramel, vanilla and brown sugar.  Not too sweet though.  Kinda a like a bourbon barrel barley wine.  Finishes sweet with a little sharpness.  Body is medium thick.  I am not a big fan of bourbon and this is by far the most bourbon influenced brew I have had to date.  I overlooked that though and feel that while it is not my personal favorite it is nonetheless a high quality Scotch.

12 oz bottle.  Pours a red-tinged brown with a small light tan head.  Amazing, smooth aroma of bourbon, caramel, vanilla, and oak, slightly sweet, with hints of dark fruits and earthy tones.  Flavor is earthy peated malts, caramel, oak, a bit of vanilla.  Bourbon and oak finish.  A pleasure to drink.

UPDATED: JAN 12, 2011 Bottle. Pours hazy red with a beige head. The aroma has cheap bourbon, peat, and vegetables. The flavor is cheap bourbon, cheddar cheese, and butterscotch. Pretty bad. Poured half my glass down the drain. Assuming I got a bad bottle, I have another Ill let hang out in the cellar for awhile and see if anything changes.. 5/3/2/2/5 = 1.7 
Bottle. Same age sampled two years later. Pours brownish red with a beige head. Light bourbon aroma with a light malty sweetness and some earthy hints. The flavor is smooth and really well balanced. Bourbon, toast, earthy notes, some woody hints. Well something has changed, either the my tastes or the beer, or maybe the last bottle was just a bad bottle. Either way, this was really good. 8/4/8/4/16 = 4.0

tronraners Xmas Eve Eve Eve Tasting. Sample from a bottle thanks to Suttree.  Cloudy light brown with a thin light whitish head.  Big peat and alcohol aroma, taste is peaty, scotch with a nice smokiness and vanilla.

Black, with a thin tan head. Nice aroma of smoke, bourbon and a hint of vanilla. Nice mixed bag of flavors - smoke, bourbon, coffee, peat, vanilla, coffee. Woodsy, dry finish. Nicely made and very tasty.

Bottle. 2008. Dark copper body with suspended floaties. Off-white head that diminishes. The aroma is dominated by bourbon and oak. Behind that are notes of overripe fruit , caramel and alcohol. The flavor is moderately to heavily sweet, but not cloyingly so, lightly bitter and lightly bitter. It has flavors of vanilla, sugar, peat, bourbon, roasted malts. It finishes with alcohol and moderate sweetness, light bitterness. Medium to full body, velvety texture, minimal carbonation. Easy drinking despite the heavy sweet flavor.

Bottle from BlackForestCO.  Thanks!  Pours a nice amber sap with an aroma of sweet candy syrup and coconut.  Flavor is bourbon infused coconut butter with a hint of oak in the finish.  Nice mouthfeel.  I want more.
user_location: Ugly, Hot, and Humid Spring, Texas, USA

text: Bottle: Poured a lightly cloudy deep amber color ale with a small foamy head with average retention and minimal lacing. Aroma of bourbon and sweet malt dominates. Taste is a fine mix betwen some bourbon notes with some deep sweet marley with some light dry fruit notes. Full body with average carbonation and no alcohol ester where noticeable.  Bourbon might be slightly too present and somewhat overshadows the malt but still very solid beer from this fine brewery.

From a twelve ounce bottle purchased for me in Fairfield , Ohio at Jungle Jims International Market by my girlfriend Nancy - This one pours a golden brew witn a tall white head of foam and an oaky-vanilla scent. The taste was interesting, but too sweet and simple for my choice.

On tap at Barleys Smokehouse.  Pours  darkest brown with a minimal head.  Stout like aroma due to the roasted maltiness, but still has the unmistakable sweetness of a scotch ale.  Some bourbon in the nose as well.  Flavor is boozy and chocolatey with some added sweetness.  Very good stuff.

12 oz bottle from Monaghans. Pours a deep reddish mahognay with a small creamy light beige head. Aroma of loads of buttery oak from the bourbon, alcohol from the bourbon, burnt caramel. and some underlying burnt caramel and brown sugar sweetness. Smooth creamy body, noticable alcohol warming and average carbonation, suprisingly smooth overall. Flavors of bourbon, vanilla, oak, fermenting dark fruit and alcohol. Once again Founders does it right.

Bottle (2008 batch): pours a cloudy reddish-brown with some yeasty floaties and a thin tan head, lots of bourbon in the nose with some dark fruits and malt, taste is malty, caramel, bourbon (but not overpowering) chocolate, none of these flavors are overpowering, everything blends together extremely well, very smooth finish.  I like this quite a bit.

UPDATED: DEC 27, 2008 12 oz. 10.2% abv. Translucent ruby-brown with a small lasting disc of cream leaving frosty webs of lacing. Sniffs of oak and whiskey amongst semi-sweet chocolate. Flavor is chocolate with a sizable dollop of caramel and vanilla, balanced well by touches of peat smoke and lightly peppery oak and whiskey. Medium-heavy body is lightly tingly and finishes well-dry despite all the yummy malt flavor. Dangerously good.

2008 batch, new label. Pours a reddish orange amber with a small white lace. Nose is surprisingly toned down from what I expected, which in my mind is definitely a good thing. Notes of dark fruit, caramel, rye, wood, hops,mild bourbon. Flavor lays down a thick layer of alcohol and caramel, also tasted, some toffee, vanilla, brown sugar, and some more alcohol.  Because of extra alcohol here, I would expect this to be more cloying and sweet but it is not.  A dry, peaty finish which I can respect.  Most scotch ales finish way too sweet for me. Nonetheless, this is way too much heat going on here, especially as this beer breathes and warms up a bit. Drinkable, but only a shot at a time.

This has a dark ruby pour with dark brown edges and lots of floaties, produced a small off-white to tan head, leaves some lacing on the sides of the glass, lots of malt aroma, dark fruit of raisins and dates, faint bourbon fragrance, brown sugar sweetness, real faint alcohol fragrance that emerges more as the ale warms, fragrances of dark bread, I found some hoar hound candy fragrance in this drink, faint earthy and peat aromas in the background but it appears this is overshadowed by the bourbon, flavor of bourbon alcohol along with dark candy sweetness, some bite of bitterness at the finish from the alcohol, has flavor of raisin and dates with dark malt, mouth feel is full, some creaminess on the palate, touch of alcohol burn and warmth in the mouth, drink tingles my nostrils with each sip.  
This years bottle list the alcohol at 10.2%, I think 9.2% would be better, a bit too much of alcohol that seems to take away from the enjoyment of the drink, I think less bourbon alcohol flavor would help me enjoy the Scotch part of this drink, I found a variance in the alcohol aroma and flavor between the four bottles in the single four pack I bought, I liked the bottle with the least bit of bourbon influence, if you like bourbon infused alcohol Scotch Ale then you will like this, a bit too much bourbon alcohol aroma and flavor for me to really enjoy the drink.

Poured from a 12oz bottle (2008 vintage with the new artwork) and served in a snifter. This beer poured a dark, murky mahogany brown with a thin head that lingered for a bit, leaving behind some decent lacing. The aroma consisted of slightly vinous, boozy dark fruits, burnt caramel, brown sugar, and maybe a hint of maple syrup. The flavor was like a piece of hard caramel candy soaked in bourbon. The flavors work really well together. Rich, malty caramel and brown sugar with a mellow, boozy bourbon note. The mouthfeel was thick, full-bodied and had very mild carbonation. Just a bit sticky. A really tasty sipper!

12 oz bottle.  Deep amber/brown in color with a small off white head.  Aroma is big, of bourbon, dark malts, chocolate, vanilla, some oak and figs.  Taste is very malty, but is smooth with dark specialty malt, chocolate, bourbon, raisins, vanilla and some oak.  Nice full body, coating on the palate.  Finishes with lingering vanilla, smooth bourbon, and malt.  Excellent barrel aged beer.

UPDATED: NOV 30, 2009 Reddish brown pour.  Old geezer on label.  Rich aroma of caramel, bourbon, and fruit.    The taste is sweet and full.  Vanilla beans, butter, bourbon, brown sugar, butter (diacetyl?), and tobacco flavors.   This is the best beer that I had in the Thanksgiving 2009 season, so I would like to give thanks to Founders for another excellent brew.

I love the aroma the best since the vanilla, oak, caramel and bourbon seems to come out more while the palate is rather wet despite having all the flavors I sense in the aroma. There is some smokiness that comes afterwards in the flavor. It grows on me as it warms.

Pours a semi cloudy copper with a very small beige head. Aroma is medium sweet with grapefruit, bourbon, smoky and caramelization. Flavor is grapefruit, orange, caramel and smoky with some alcohol detected. Medium to full body, sticky texture. Finishes somewhat hot, low carbonation.

Bottle. Pours copper, light brown with tan head. Aroma is bourbon with hints of oak and vanilla. Flavor is dominated by bourbon with notes of vanilla, dark fruits, and slight alcohol sting in the finish. Bourbon flavor stays dominant throughout.
Complete bourbon. Rich. Taste of a Kentucky drink fest. Vanilla. Oak. Excellent.

Pours dark mahogany into a Thistle. Light smoke and bourbon aromas.  Upfront strong bourbon, turning full with fruit and smoked malts.  Lasting smoked oak and bourbon finish.  Why did not I buy the 4-pack?

Pours a nice copper color with a tan head.  Plenty of bourbon on the aroma with a hint of oak, caramel malts, dark fruit, and some vanilla.  Taste is also strong on the bourbon with more oak then it would seem from the nose.  Some sugar, dark fruits,  and caramel malts in the background with a decent warming on the finish.  Decent blend of flavors on the finish with the bourbon being stronger at the beginning rather then the finish.

UPDATED: DEC 13, 2008 12 oz bottle, pours a nice mahogany with a ruby tinge.  Small head and leaves a light layer of small bubbled lacing on the sides of the glass.  Aroma is bourbon, of course, but not as strong as Goose Island Bourbon County Stout.  Also aroma of wood, brown sugar, vanilla, and malt.  Taste of dark fruit and bourbon, with an alcohol burn finish.  Relatively light-bodied and smooth, with a nice amount of carbonation.  Very good beer!

Once I got over the boozy aspect of this beer, I really enjoyed it.  Woody, with a heavy bourbon finish, and vanilla to boot.  I would love to see what the cellar would do for this one.  Very very tasty.

Deep ruby/mahogany pour with a frothy, tan, off-white head.  Lots of vanilla and caramel aroma with a background of smoke, figs, and faint chocolate.  Dark fruit and smoke flavor upfront with lingering vanilla and a bourbon kick.  Creamy medium body.

pours a medium dark amber with a good aroma of bourbon and malt. has some nut in the background finishing with the burn of a mix of scotch and bourbon...the scotch flavor being the peat in the background.
good.

Pours very dark with a thin tan head. The aroma is a nice caramel, malt, and some bourbon. The taste is different, with the bourbon coming forward along with vanilla, oak, and strong nuttiness. Quite thick and complex. Very nice.

UPDATED: MAR 9, 2009 Aroma of fresh oak sawdust with a little caramel hiding behind.  Pours a deep clear mahogany, a finger of head even in a broad glass, but it dissipates quickly into spots of lace.  Like the aroma, flavor is dominated by resinous oaky flavors, very aromatic and penetrating.  Caramel and nutty malts, a bit of peat smoke, and a tart fruit (somewhere between cherry and orange peel) slip through the oak before it fades into a long bitter finish of aged woods.  Palate is smooth, finishing with tannic astringency.

pours clear deep red with no head at all.  aroma is all bourbon, as is the flavor.  there is no beer flavor to this at all, it only tastes like bourbon.  slightly flat, mildly syrupy beer.  not my favorite founders beer by far...

Appearance: Pours a clear, dark reddish-brown body with a rather small, fleeting, off-white head.

Smell: A sturdy, sweet-scented caramel maltiness with a hint of maple. Oh, and with a rich, distinct bourbon barrel aroma, but you already knew that, right?

Taste: Sweet, sugary caramel maltiness with an added dose of maple syrup. Small touch of fruit. Full, punchy bourbon barrel tastes of vanilla and toasted oak wood. Light tannic astringency. Earthy hops with a medium amount of bitterness. Pleasingly sweet, bourbony finish.

Mouthfeel: Medium-plus body. Medium carbonation. Lightly sticky mouthfeel.

Drinkability: Oh, it’s quite good. Potent, sure, but good! If ever anyone has some extra bottles of Backwoods Bastard they’re looking to get rid of count me in.

Bottle from Canal’s in Lawrenceville, NJ.  Pours a lightly hazy dark mahogany with a thin brown head.  Sweet, smokey aroma.  Woody, earthy notes envelope the flavors which include vanilla, sweet malt, fig, caramel and bittersweet chocolate.  Texture tended to the thin side.  Rich, long finish.

This beer is a dark brown and cloudy.  It pours almost like mud, and god is that attractive.  The flavor of this one is very earthy.  Heavy wood notes with a slight sweetness and a mild chocolaty finish.  The palate is torn right from a smooth beer into a smoother barrel aged version.  As this goes on the wood blends more and more into the chocolate flavors.  Any hop character has pretty much been smoothed over  Top notch, mellowed, stuff.

Bottle (with an absolutely great label... the new one, that is.)  Pours a fairly dark brown with a little bit of reddish light coming through the edges.  Head is small and tan... almost a film by now.  Aromas are heavy with dark fruit and a touch of whisky or peat or smoke.  Flavor is big... real big.  Peat and smoke mix with dark fruit flavors (although there seems to be a bit of pear nectar or something that I’m picking up in addition to the dark fruits.)  Malt comes through as sweet and almost a little chocolaty, but more like a brownie than anything else.  This is really good stuff.
user_location: The Wet Side of a Dry Town, Pennsylvania, USA

text: (11.24.08) 12 oz. bottle: Pours a clear dark mahogany with a small, tan head. You can smell the oaky bourbon barrels right off. Vanilla and sweet caramel malts are there, along with some peat smoke. Flavor is bourbon and malt. Body is dense, with a dry warming finish.

A cloudy brown tea looking brew with a minimal tan head that soon becomes a ring.  Aroma is dark fruit with yeast, whiskey (Jack Daniels), with more whiskey.  It is almost a Jack and Coke nose.  Flavor is more complex but still is full of whiskey.  Throw in some bitter dark chocolate, strong coffee, vanilla, licorice, brown sugar, and wood.  Like the aroma, the beer is whiskey dominated throughout but the chocolate grows along with the temperature.  Feel is creamy but just a bit thin.  It also provides some zing on the tongue and whiskey can be felt, especially in the back of the tongue.  Whiskey lovers will enjoy this beer because that is what dominates both aroma and flavor.  There are other aspects that make it interesting and it is definitely flavorful.

12 oz. bottle.  2008 vintage.  First rating back after Hack Attack 2008.  Pours a muddy brown.  Thin, off white head.  Aroma of bourbon, vanilla, and woody notes.  Flavor is nice and smooth, with a strong bourbon backbone.  Some touches of toffee, bready malt, caramel.  Finish is boozy with a touch of chocolate.  Nice beer.

Bottle pours dark brown color with off white head.  Head dissipates almost instantly.  Aroma is strong bourbon, vanilla, and oak.  Has a medium body.  Flavor is bourbon, vanilla, oak, malt sweetness, and toffee.  Overall this is a wonderful brew.  I’d have this on hand all the time if I could.

Bottle, pours a dark coffee brown with a small tan head.  Very boozy smelling, like an empty bottle of whiskey that’s been left in your trunk for a few months. with notes of sweet toffee and caramel.  The mouthfeel is very odd.  Lots of thin soaking alcohol in the tongue but with a sticky sugary feel in the cheeks.  The first thing I got out of the flavor was a surprising amount of coffee.  Lots of burnt caramel and LOTS of bourbon.  About half a glass in, I kinda felt a little sick from the sweet/alcohol flavor mix, however the roasty malts and depth of flavors kept me wanting more.  Really a unique brew.

Bottle with newer label. Deep dark pour... reddish brown, but looks almost black.  Bright light yellow/orange head, almost the color of sherbet.  Looks delicious.  I tend to be a sucker for strong scotch ales, and this is no exception. Bourbon, vanilla, oak, toasty biscuity malts, and some hop presence.  Definitely some chocolate.  It’s sweet, but I didn’t find it cloying.  Sugars almost make the bourbon taste like rum at times.  Think I’ll pick up a few more of these. ***Note: RB has this listed as 9.2% and the newer label says 10.2%.

12 oz, thanks CMUbeerman.  Deep mahogany pour with a tan head.  Caramel, malt, and toffee, spicy notes - clove, cinnamon, vanilla.  Surprisingly chocolaty.  Awesome flavor - milk chocolate, bourbon, vanilla, dessert and apple pie spices.  Toffee and excellent balancing bitterness.  Much hoppier than I expected at the end.  Silky smooth in the mouth.  I wish there was just a tad more sweetness in the finish.  Really excellent, a great example of one of my favorite styles.

Sampled from bottle: Pours a dark mahogany colour with a thin tan head. Little carbonation. Aroma is incredible, bourbon, toffee, caramel chocolate and cofee notes. Taste is rich with dark roasted malts, soft whisky, caramel and pineapple. Awesome beer, one of the best ive had in a while.

Bottle courtesy of ncvbc poured into a snifter.

Pours a murky dark caramel brown with a very short-lived tan head that receded to a ring quickly leaving bits of lacing.

The aroma is heavy with bourbon and vanilla with the underlying scotch ale coming through a little with roasted caramel malts. There is also a definite brown sugar sweetness as well.

The taste follows the aroma fairly closely with the exception of a very slight hop presence up front before giving way to the massive bourbon and caramel malt backbone. There is plenty of vanilla as well and the oak really comes out in the finish and lingers for a while between sips.

The mouthfeel is almost syrupy with very little carbonation and an alcohol burn.

This is a decent scotch ale and one that bourbon lovers will especially enjoy. It’s definitely a sipper and makes a great nightcap.
This is a tough drink for me.  I’ll call it well made but instead of having some bourbon flavor it is just overpowering.
Bottle from West Lakeview. Nose is all bourbon, vanilla and caramel. Dark brown with off beige head. Thick body, but cloyingly sweet and vanilla. I’d take dirty bastard over this any day. Meh...

On draught at Barleys Smokehouse. Pours a dark copper color with a medium beige head that recedes slowly. Patches of lacing on the glass. Lots of malt and caramel in the nose along with bourbon. Rich body with flavors of malt, dark fruit, bourbon and vanilla. The finish is full and sweet with a caramel malt and chocolate aftertaste. Alcohol is well-masked throughout. Pretty good all around, and I liked it quite a bit more than the Dirty Bastard.

Pours a dark ruby color with a light brown head that fades, but sticks around.  Aroma is caramel, toasted malt, maple and chocolate-covered cherry candies. Taste is both vinous and whiskey-like along with chocolate, coffee, vanilla and buttery maple.  Some alcohol evident after the swallow.  Really damn good!

Bottle 12fl.oz.Alc. 8.7%. Clear medium to dark red amber color with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, beige head. Aroma is moderate to light heavy malty, caramel, milk cholate notes, light whisky, alcohol. Flavor is moderate to heavy sweet and moderate bitter with a long to average duration. Body is medium to full, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. (220808)
From bottle.  Brown pour with thin head.  Sweet malt aroma.  Not much bourbon flavor - maybe I’m too influenced by BCS - I expected more.  Pretty sweet - ABV is well hidden.  Overall impressive brew.

Crushed with Honkeybra.  Yum.  Founder’s has figured out the perfect barrel aging time.  Very complex beer, with a noticeable bourbon body, but not overly powerful which reminds you just how awesome Dirty Bastard was, plus.  Awesome brew.

UPDATED: NOV 30, 2008 From a 12oz bottle - Pours a reddish/brown color with small caramel colored head.  Almost no carbonation.  Smells of sweet bourbon and not much else.   First sip is smooth and mellow the scotch dominating but still balanced with the malts.  Oak and vanilla notes are also presence. Very nice and drinkable.  Not much carbonation here thanks to the barrel conditioning.  Very nice and tasty.

pours dark brown/amber with nice yellow head.  Aroma is sweet bourban maltness - mouthfeel is carbonated and thick with strong bourbon flavor - Awesome sweet bourbon flavor - very nice - I am glad I picked up 4 of these.  I will have to try some after they age a while

2008 bottle. Pours a brownish color with a tint of purple when put up to light. Initial aroma doesn’t overpower with bourbon, but gives off subtle hints and even allows some faint caramel malt tones to come through. The taste is very well balanced, and again the bourbon isn’t overpowering. Some vanilla, caramel, and bourbon provide the bulk of the flavor. Bitterness seems really low given that this is supposed to be 50 IBU’s. Overall, this is my favorite beer from Founders and a damn good scotch ale.

12 oz bottle.  Pours a dark reddish amber with a small beige head that vanished to a slight wispy partial covering.  The nose is big boozy bourbon with deep fruity figgy malt.  Alcohol, chocolate, raisin, and a good bit of residual sugars.  The bourbon is certainly in the forefront, big and heavy.  Some charred oak, dark fruits, boozy alcohol, chocolate, and light coffee.  Not complex and subtle though, just big and brash.  Mouthfeel is full and heavy but not especially sticky or cloying.  Nice soft carbonation, long boozy charred oak finish.  Overall, this just wasn’t one that I cared for too much.

Nice strong aroma of bourbon, oak, light peated malt, caramel, toffee, vanilla. Complex and pleasant. Pours hazy brownish red with a thin bubbly head. Strong initial flavors of bourbon and booze. This is followed by some sweet malt, caramel, toffee. Vanilla and oak come through in the finish and linger. Very enjoyable.

This poured a nearly opaque copper in color ith a moderate khaki head of fine bubbles.  The nose gave off aromas of vanilla and bourbon from the barrel aging along with caramel and spice.  In the mouth it was medium-bodied with a rich yet soft mouthfeel that showed just a hint of bitterness on the finish.  This was well-balanced and round that was quite engaging.  While it did show the barrel-aging it was an enjoyable addition to me as oppossed to overwhelming.  I think this will continue to integrate and improve with 6 - 12+ months aging.

Bottle at Jerrys. Caramel-mahogany with decent, creamy beige head / Big, sweet, bourbon caramel nose / Full bodied, sweet, with big malts and long, semi-dry finish / Winey flavors of bourbon, oak, butterscotch, semi-sweet chocolate, and vanilla /  Spectacular.

Bottle: Bourbony color, light head and lacing. Nose of vanilla and bourbon, sweet oak and honey. Smooth. The flavor is floral and vanilla accented with a cream oak tail, smooth. Nice fruitiness. Thanks Sam!

Pours a deep and murky red. Vanilla, bourbon aroma with some spice notes. Flavor is subtley spicey, with wax, oak, vanilla and maple notes. Then the bourbon hits you square in the face. Scotchy, dirty, maybe some chocolate, with a boozy, bitter finish.

UPDATED: NOV 21, 2009 [2008 Bottle 10.2% with a new label]  Pours a murky orange tinted medium brown with basically no head.  Spicy malty aroma, similar to curmudgeon,  vanilla and lots of bourbon.   Flavor is kind of dull and waxy, from the barrel no doubt,  with lots of bourbon upfront.  Not near as spicy or buttery as curmudgeon, however the bourbon is much more straight forward.   The malt tastes a bit darker and lightly peaty which brings to mind some grassy scotch notes.   Medium/full body, lightly buttery, with light sizzling carbonation.   Im not sure if aging will bring out anymore flavors, its pretty mellow as is.    7.4.8.4.15 . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .[2009 bottle rated 11.21.09 with upside down label]  Wow, I can already tell Im going to like this more than last years.  Pours a creamy chocolate color with a thick tall foamy light tan frothy head, looks fantastic.  Aroma is the typical Founders vanilla/bourbon barrel but seems  to be smoothed out just a bit, still spicy, the bourbon and vanilla seem to let some of the other pleasant woody notes come through this time instead of completely over powering the, sweet brown sugar, hint of coconut.  Flavor is much better than last year, not just a sticky sweet syrupy mess anymore, some nice chocolate and malt flour notes, same thing with the aroma in the flavor, the vanilla isnt totally overpowering this time, still quite strong, not a whole ton of depth, finishes quick and really thin for what it could be, some lingering root-beer and just a hint of watered down scotch in the aftertaste.  Medium bodied with fizzy soda carbonation that detracts a bit from the sipper it was last year... I prefer this years flavor with last years body hehe.  8.4.8.4.15  The third best Scotch Ale Ive had this week... the two better were both homebrews ;)

Bottle.  The first time i had this i thought wow this is the shit.  But then i realized on a few less drunk occasions that its a beautiful explosion of flavors of sugary treats.  Maple, chocolate, vanilla, cream, bourbon, smoke and spices.   Good beer.
