UPDATED: JUL 13, 2011 (Bottle, thanks to hopscotch) Pours beautiful deep red with some brownish hints and almost no head. The aroma is of sweet caramelly malt, buttery bourbon oak/wood shop, citric/resiny hops and a sweet fruitiness. Undertones of smoke, earth, vanilla, mild spices, maple syrup and cucumber. The flavour is of buttery bourbon oak/wood shop and sticky caramel/maple syrup up front with resiny orange-like hops. Undertones of dark fruits, earth and a light tannin bite. The mouthfeel is soft and sticky. Numbing hop and alcohol finish. Medium to heavily sweet and medium bitter. Medium to full bodied.

(Bottle 35,5 cl) Courtesy of pepsican. Pours a slightly hazy reddish amber with tiny floating impurities and a small, creamy yellowish head. Distinct sweet bourbon aroma. Medium-bodied with sweet caramel and fruit, a little spicy with the bourbon notes really shining through leading to a somewhat boozy finish. A little low in carbonation. Very pleasant. 220808

Bottle thanks to zathrus13. Wow, this stuff is good! Pours with a largish, brown head with hazey red tinged, deep brown body. Aromas of bourbon, vanilla, dark fruits, peet, and some toffee. Flavors of toffee, fruit, vanilla, oak, raisins, bourbon, and a lot of alcohol. As a whiskey drinker, this stuff is great, and the bourbon character reminds me alot of Goose Island IS and Kentucky Breakfast (and maybe BB Angels Share). Syrupy mouthfeel with light bubbles, Great stuff to sip on!

Semi clear mahogany with a thin prsistant tan head.   Big delicious vanilla bourbon aroma.  Light and dry palattte but a nice mild woodu flavor with plenty of vanilla and oak.
Ver nice.

Small tan head with fair retention and lace. Deep brown color, clear. Lotsa whisky in the nose along with vanilla and a light woodiness. Body is med/full, Slick and coating, light carbonation. Whisky flavors are prominent, vanilla, faint chocolate and maybe some roast buried under there, some fruit and vinous notes slunkin around in there also. Fairly dry boozy finish. Props to eaglefan for sharing. It werent that bad Brian! Sheesh!

Bottle from Styles, shared at State Line. The pour was dark mahoganey brown with a decent initial head that thinned to a full but thin covering. The aroma was all bourbon, vanilla, very faint oak. Did I mention the bourbon? Roasty and smoke notes fill in slightly on the flavor, but this was pretty hot and full of bourbon (even some maple) to the point that it wasn’t pleasant combined with an astringency that was unwelcomed. A fun experience indeed, but not a solid beer in my book. Thanks, Chris, for this one along with those other gems you sent!
(Draught)  Pours a clear amber body with a small beige head.  Aroma of caramel, brown sugar, vinous, and vanilla.  Flavor of hops (orange, grapefruit), caramel malt, dark fruits, and toffee.

Bottle, shared by papsoe. Pours a nice, clear reddish dark golden body with a small creamy beige head. Beefstock, malty sweetness, some alcohol and spirits in the aroma. Some bourbon, sugary maltyness and a pleasant fruity hoppyness and bitterness in the mouth. Warming, full-bodied and slightly sticky. Lasting finish with a pleasant warmth and sweetness. A quite challenging beer, maybe too focused on the bourbon, but it is really pleasant and gets better as you drink it. (080822)
UPDATED: APR 8, 2010 Pours a burnt caramel color with no head. The nose and flavor are rich with vanilla, oak, bourbon and a touch of coconut. Medium to creamy palate.

12 fl oz bottle. Pours cloudy golden amber with a lacing tan head. Wineous and barley dense aroma. Flavour is sweet and dense malty. Smooth chocolate and vanilla flavours nicely balance the dense barley and alcohol notes. Lingering chocolate and vanilla finish.

12-oz. bottle provided graciously by Secret Santa July 2008.  Pours hazy brown with an average, rocky, light brown head, somewhat lasting with good lacing.  Aroma is heavy malt (nutty, cookie, caramel, toffee), light hops (herbs), average yeast (leather, dough) with notes of alcohol, wood, and apples.  Full bodied, alcoholic texture, average carbonation, and a bitter finish.  Long duration, moderate sweetness, acidity, and bitterness.
On tap at the brewery: Pours brown with almost no head.  Strong aroma of sugar, bourbon and caramel.  Flavor of same.  Very good.

UPDATED: FEB 16, 2009 Pours a rich mahogony from the bottle with a trim straw-colored head.  Permeates brown sugar and bourbon that carry into the flavor along with notes of toasted coconut, caramel, vanilla, and apple.  Medium-bodied with a hot alcohol finish.  Its kind of like a liquid apple cobbler--amazing!

On tap at brewery.  Aroma of caramel, bourbon, dark dried fruits, and a little alcohol.  Very deep ruby almost black hue with a little off-white head that almost completely diminished and left little lace.  Flavor is caramel, bourbon, and sherry tones with a little nutty vanilla.  Palate is full bodied and oily flat.  Much better than the regular bastard and the bourbon was fantastic.  A very good sipper.

12oz bottle thanks to my Secret Santa.  Pours a translucent copper color with a thin, beige head, a hazy cloud and some tight, small bubbles.  Aroma is fairly mild, grain, grass, earthy with some biscuit.  Flavor is really delicious, buttery, nutty, sweet with caramel, butterscotch, toast, buttery biscuits, vanilla and a little scotch whisky.  Finish is sweet and slightly thick with almost no heat from the alcohol.  Looks like a standard brown or scotch ale, but the flavor backs a wicked punch.  Almost too drinkable, smooth enough to be a session beer even at 9% abv.

Brown color with a full forming head that lasts well.  Fairly nice nose that shows hints of vanilla and whiskey, with also some nice notes of the original beer (a little toastiness.)  Flavor is of a very sweet beer that is mainly dominated by oak, a touch of coconut and whiskey notes.  I like it, but it is not a complex beer.  The original beer should really have a lot more character and is missing malt depth.

Bottle:  Pours a ruby brown, with small bubbles.  A bit thin on the mouthfeel, the flavor is big.  Sweet malts and bourbon swirl the palate with undertones of vanilla and wood.  A tad spicy, but mostly overwhelming with bourbon.
user_location: I F&ckin hate those guys from, Ohio, USA

text: MBG Summer Fest ’08.  Poured a ruddy dark brown with a thin beige head.  Aroma was dominated by whiskey (all you can drink!), but some smokey oak and caramel comes through as well.  Pour was initially fairly chilled, so the initial flavor was in line with Dirty Bastard - dark roasted malt, molasses, touch of hop bitterness - but with a slight bourbon kick in the finish.  As it warmed, bourbon totally dominated making the last swallow akin to doing a  shot of Makers.  (This is not a bad thing.)  Medium body that coated the mouth, with low to medium carbonation.

7-11-08 bottle shared with lb4lb thanks to ford9719 
Thick dark brown pour with a decent ivory head.  Smell is berries and bourbon with some bold vanilla in there.  Flavor is nice bourbon with a nice finish of ... well... more bourbon.  Low carbonation but thick and almost creamy.  Drinkable but not too much more to it than big bourbon.

Dark brown beer with very little head. Sweet toffee, some noticeable wood, a hint of dates, and obvious alcohol is what I smell. I taste Oak first and foremost with just a bit of bourbon and a whole lot of caramel and toffee sweetness. Maybe some dark fruitiness at the end. Solid.

Bottle in trade from ford9719. Thanks dude!
Pours a nice solid very dark reddish brown with a smallish beige head.  Smell is very nice bourbony, vanilla maltiness with maybe a touch of peatiness, but not even sure on that.  Taste is bourbony, with dark fruits and sticky malts with vanilla and oak in the finish.  Mouthfeel is medium with light to moderate carbonation.  Ever so slightly warming as it goes down, but with no burn.  I liked this a lot more than I expected to.  Pretty good beer.

Bottle:  Ruby mahoghany poour with a modest sandy colored head.  Oak and bourbon permeate the nose with a little dark fruit and some malty sweetness.  Mostly bourbon...  Flavor is big with bourbon, malty, cookie dough, and bits of prunes/vinous fruits.  Light citrus hops.  Smooth and enjoyable, but a little overdone on the barrel notes.  Thanks Ughsmash.

8.7% abv bottle by way of bgburdman9... pours a slightly hazed reddish brown with a cafe au lait head. small webs of lacing are left on the retreat. smells like brown sugar sweetened bourbon... oak, toffee, bitter and a mild sourness. moderate sweetness on the palate. the bourbon element is not hot at all, more of the pure flavor mixed with milk chocolate, caramel, golden raisins, soft vanilla oakiness, spice and a bit of alcohol (from the beer not the bourbon) on the finish. the medium body  leaves a bit of stickiness on the lips but a rather watery mouth feel.

Crimson red edges surround a brown center.  A small cashew-colored head sits on top of the beer but leaves little lacing in its wake.  Nice syrupy nose with hints of molasses, caramel, vanilla and oak.  Flavor includes both raisin and fig, along with toffee and alcohol. Not a bad beer but not on par with some of their other offerings.

UPDATED: NOV 30, 2010 i do not get it, to me this is really not beer, an ale, a scotch ale even like it. it is bourbon (really tasting more like cognac) and seltzer or something of the like. the usual comments regarding beer flavor just do not apply here as the aformentioned flavor completely takes charge. perhaps a bit clever but overall a redundant drink as cognac has been invented already. smooth and buttery with a touch of vanilla. over the top alcohol and acidy eehhh. on the re-rate done during the holidays uuuhh this is pretty good cognac flavors cherry alcohol abit syrupy...change of season, change of thought.

12 oz bottle. Pours a murky ruby brown coor with a creamy khaki colored head. Nose of vanilla, butter cream, bourbon, caramel and dark fruits. Mouthfeel is soft and velvety. Initial taste of vanilla and bourbon which dominate the mouth. Mid palate of caramel and nuts. Finishing with continuing bourbon, strong oakiness warming alcohol, and balancing bitter hops. Although the flavor was not very complex it was well rounded and robust making it very enjoyable. Palate duration is above average. Medium body. Good head retention and spot lacing of the glass.

Bottle:  Dark mahogany pour with no head.  Strong caramel malts, vanilla, oak/bourbon nose...some dark fruity esters.  Medium-light body with a slight creaminess on the finish...flavors of dark malts, caramel, light brown sugar and a very mild, sweet bourbon oak tone.  Pretty good.
Bottle sampled with Mad_indian. Pours copper/brown with a small off-white head. Aroma of bourbon and roasted malts. the flavor is sweet, vanilla, oak, bourbon, and a nice alcohol burn to boot.

Bottle. Bourbon, you say? Really? You dont say. There is some scotch ale here, sure, and though the bourbon is dominant its not gross or overwhelming. But this beer is all whiskey. It works fairly well, and is surprisingly drinkable. It has a nice malt body as well. But I could do with less bourbon.

12 oz bottle courtesy of kmweaver. Pours a dark red brown with a small off-white head that holds at 1/4 inch. The aroma is rich with roasted malts, peat and whiskey. The flavor is loaded with more bourbon whiskey notes, with lightly toasted malts, vanilla and butter rounding out the sides. The mouthfeel was smooth and creamy. The finish is long and buttery with linger biter walnuts. Overall: A very bold bourbon flavored concoction, I love it.

Bottle, thanks to wetherel. Pours a cloudy brown-orange with thin beige head. The aroma is malt, vanilla, raisin, mild oak and alcohol. The flavor is smooth bourbon and bitter chocolate at first, followed by quite a bit of raisin and burnt caramel. Oak really comes out toward the finish, with some more bitter chocolate notes. This goes down smooth... I like it.

Bottle courtesy of kmweaver. Pours burgundy with a wispy, thin beige skin and oily lace. The nose is of modest, sweet bourbon, cherries, and vanilla over a dark, fruity, malt backbone. Medium-bodied and silky-slick with a dry and lightly boozy finish. The palate thins a bit over time. Sweet, fruity malt, vanilla, and light bourbon with a lightly smoky and woody finish. Bourbon and vanilla lingers in the aftertaste. This is a tasty beer, but I think that I might prefer the original Dirty Bastard just a hair. Perhaps Ill have to snag another bottle for a side-by-side. Thanks again for sending this my way, Ken!

UPDATED: JUN 28, 2012 12oz bottle, generously supplied by HimerMan and ucusty - thanks, guys!!! My bottle says 8.5% abv, but close enough. Very strong bourbon smell as the russet beer - slightly cloudy, with minimal carbonation (a couple of beads and very mild retention) - pours. My initial impression is that the beer isnt substantial enough to handle the boozy qualities of the barrel-aging, and Im not sure that aging will settle it down or make it more astringent. Its an enjoyable brew, but right now its too one-dimensional for me.

12 oz. bottle generously shared by Gregis.  Pour is cordovan, slightly hazed with an off white head.  Some decent lacing on the glass.  Aroma of caramel biscuit malt, with some cherry fruit sweetness.  Bourbon woodiness in there as well.  Taste is big Bourbon woodiness with a very drying caramel maltiness.  Really boozy in the mouth despite a lower ABV.

12 ounce bottle shared by Greg.  Pours dark red to brown with a light brown head.  Clings to the sides of the glass nicely.  Caramel sweet in the nose with  some smoke and a strong shot of bourbon.  An interesting fruitiness as well.  Caramel and toffee flavors with some chocolate, but a bit over the top boozy.  Medium body.  Medium carbonation.  Warm dry finish.  Not bad.  Not great.

Big thanks from hoppymeal for this bottle. Pours a fuzzy garnet color with tan head that lingers for a bit. Wonderful nose of bourbon, oak, vanilla, cranberries and sweet maple flavored malts. Taste is just as good with peat flavors and a smooth finish that makes is a fantastic beer. hoppymeal, you rock.

Bottle courtesy of JB175.   Pours a cloudy dark caramel color with a one finger beige head.  You can really smell the bourbon in this one and it dominates the nose with just a hint of malt around the edges.  Palate is bourbon upfront with some oaky vanilla and sweet sugary malt in the finish before the alcohol burn hits your over the head.  Looked thin on the pour but its pretty creamy mouth feel.  This is an interesting brew.  I like it, not sure Id trade for more, but I like it enough that Id buy a few if they were sold here.  Definitely warming with that 9% abv.  Thanks for hooking me up with this Jason.

bottle: pours a very dark brown with hardly any ligth tan head. aroam is oak, whiskey, and caramel malts. alot of bourbon some vanilla. small hints of chocolate. get some good amount of raisin type dried fruit. very good. flavour is bourbon and oak that seems to over power the caramelly malt, some touches of chocoalte. finishes a good bitter,

UPDATED: DEC 15, 2015 Bottle thanks to Eric. Pours a light red/brown with a thin white head. The aroma is mostly heavy alcohol and peat. The taste is like a fairly dry and smooth scotch, with some smoky malts and some sweet brown sugar. Really quite nice. Its not a style I love, but this is really well made. Seven years later I re-rate! Wow. 2008 I had it at 3.7. I like it more now. Massive bourbon. Heat. Berries. Nice. Upped to 3.9. 4 would be fair as well.

Pours a dark brownish red with a almost non existent off white head.  Aroma is very strong with vanilla and wood.  Flavor is vanilla,  bourbon,  caramel,  butter,  maple wood.  Finishes slightly sweet,  alcohol is apparent.  Very interesting.  Thanks to secret santa,  styles,  and TheCheeseMan for all hooking me up with bottles of this at different times.  I finally got around to cracking one!  Thanks guys.

Bottle, thanks to after4ever. Pours clear mahogany with a lacy off-white head. Aroma of brown sugar, spice and smoke. Caramel biscuit taste. Sort of like Cinnabons without the cinnamon. Dry smoky finish.

12-oz. Thanks, KMWeaver! Dark brown with caramel highlights and a very small tan head. Caramel, peat, and biscuit on the nose. Nice clean medium body with very soft carb. Peat, caramel, biscuit, and forward fruit notes on the mid-palate...delectable. Tobacco notes and leaves and earth on the finish. Great stuff.
Medium brown, a little smoke on the nose, a lot of caramel, a touch of hops, nicely complex, no one flavor dominates, full and satisfying texture, overall quite satisfying and well balanced.
Poured deep nutty brown with no head what so ever. Aromas of rasins and alcohol. Taste is terrible! Alcohol and old beer taste is all I had. One sip and I couldnt take anymore.
user_location: back in NJ!, New Jersey, USA

text: Thanks to Adam for this.  I dont know if this was a bad bottle so I need to try another one.  If it wasnt a bad bottle then the aging process is killing this beer.  Ive heard good things about this beer, but man I was really disappointed.  Poured like murky lake water, with almost no head.  No carbonation in it, just a very boring flat beer.  Aroma has hints of caramel and  alcohol.  Tastes like charred wood with an alcohol burned finish.  Not a pleasant beer to drink.  I am not a fan of pouring beer down the drain, but had to with this one.  This shouldnt be in the 90th percent tile.  Ill rerate this beer again just to make sure it wasnt a bad bottle.

Thanks to Derek for this one.  Dark caramel brown, no head forms but a tan mist relaxes on the top.  Caramel, vanilla, and bourbon aromas.  Flavors of vanilla, bourbon, burned bitter caramel, a warming alcohol, and dark chocolate accompanied by a dry finish.  Smooth body.  Better than expected.

Thanks to Padrefan98.  Pours a light brown with a faint amber hue, no head.  Aroma of a nice Scotch ale with soem vanilla, bourbon ,and wood.  Flavors were very good, bourbon, wood, vanilla, sweet malt, and some dark fruit.

12oz bottle from kmweaver. Im really am beginning to like this brewery. Except for the Breakfast Stouts (overrated). More along the lines of a BA BW on the nose. Definite wood and alcohol presence. Sweet toffee malt. Creme brulee and alcohol on the nose. Pours thick and dense brown with a nice sized dark tan head. The barrel aging really rears its head on the tongue. Not sweet, but plenty of BA characteristics. Wood tannin, toasted caramel, maple syrup... wow. Lots of Bourbon flavors. Not too heavy or cloying on the palate. For those who are not on the Bourbon Barrel bandwagon... stay away.

UPDATED: JAN 14, 2009 12oz Bottle. Thanks Sean! Heavy bourbon and vanilla nose. Creamy sweet fudge, light molasses and waves of black cherries soaked in bourbon. Fresh. Bright, but not hot or overly alcoholic. A bit of soap and oak. Thats nice. Pours an evenly toned ruddy brown, 40% opaque. Silky, long lace of pale khaki film. Flavor is a dense, sweetened cream mingled with bourbon straight from the glass. Carbonation parses out some caramels, oak tannins, and maple-like residuals. Surprisingly light and not densely sweet, but the alcohol from the bourbon really dominates the profile. Not unlike that more abominable Imperial Stout. Theres a nice leafy hop backdrop to the beer that settles the alcohols. Malt complexity is average and I would have expected more caramel density, but I appreciate that lack of cloying sweetness. And interesting bourbon rendition. I think this would be more interesting blended back with the straight Bastard, around 40%. Refined and mature. Filtration cuts into the potential complexity of this beer, in my opinion.
12 oz bottle thanks to nolankowal. I really liked the smoke and wood smells in this one. Awesome flavors of some bourbon and some sweet vanilla.

12 oz bottle shared with Padrefan98.  Aromas were a lot of sweet wood and bourbon.  Actually, I think it was a lot of wood and sweet bourbon.  But I cant be sure.  The aroma led me to believe this would be really hot.  But it was quite smooth and vanilla with touches of dark dried fruit.  Pretty darn good stuff.

From dankman38 via trade.  Thanks again!  The pour was a very attractive clear mahogany that had nice depth and produced a scant, off-white head that hung around only for a moment before collapsing into a galaxy swirl.  Spotty bits of lacing.  The aroma was vanilla, malt, oakiness and some bourbon/alcohol goodness.  The flavor was sticky sweet malts soaked in vanilla and finished in a bourbon barrel.  The bourbon does assert itself, but hardly in a negative way.  Better as it approached room temperature and was allowed to breathe.  The mouthfeel was medium to full and very nice.  More please!

A slightly vigorous pour produces only enough head to cover the beer for a half second, what is there is a amber tinged tan color.  The beer is a dark plum / dark amber color that shows a lightly hazy, cranberry red hue when held up to the light.  At the first, the aroma is a nice mix between rich malt notes and oak aromatics.  Deeper inspection yields much the same with competing aromas of ripe, bright, concentrated berry notes, some spicy bourbon, soft butterscotch, a touch of molasses, deeply caramelized malt, lightly toasted grain and browned biscuits.

Somewhat sweet, though this beer drinks much richer than the sweetness would suggest.  The body of this beer is downright chewy, viscous and mouth-coating.  Flavors of berries, hugely caramelized grain and a rich malt character slowly yield to spicy, oak and Bourbon influenced flavors that linger on in the finish.  The buttery notes from the oak and Bourbon character really shows through in the finish and it adds a nice compliment to the up front malt focus of this beer.  Peppery oak and a bit of hot boozy Bourbon notes provides a sharpness, almost harshness as the beer warms up a bit.

I really like that the malt character plays a slightly bigger role in the flavor profile than the bourbon barrel does; this keeps the integrity of the rich, Scotch ale style, but with an offsetting bourbon component that helps to offset / balance the thick malt character of this brew.  Having said that, bourbon barrel aged beers seem to be a bit hard for me to get behind; there is something about the Bourbon notes that add a harshness the beers aged in the barrels that just doesnt quite work for me.  As the beer warms up from its initial 50°F / 10°C it picks up more of the sharp, hot, Bourbon flavors which pull this away from being balanced.  This is not a bad brew, but the Bourbon character is a bit much, especially as the beer warms up a bit.

Bottle poured into a tulip glass produced a fingers worth of tan head that goes to lace sitting on top of a dark brown body

Alcohol, malt and bourbon aromas fill your nose

Tastes of sweet malt, bourbon, you get the barrel flavors as well 

Medium smooth mouthfeel
 
Very big beer, good drinkablity will drink this one again. one per sitting though

Bottle (12oz).  Shared with garthicus.  Cloudy copper pour, small froth of head.  Smooth, oddly light aroma - vanilla/oak, alcoholic caramel malt  - what it is, solid big scotch ale mellowed by oaky bourbon.  The taste follows, strong but not overwhelming sweet bourbon, really softens the alcohol, has a nice christmas cookie sweet finish.  Sugary, alcoholic mouthfeel, nicely ear-warming, ever-so faint bitterness in the linger.  Lovely beer.
Thanks for sharing Harry! Copper body, slight slight head. Aroma; Carrots, suntan lotion, brandy! With a marzipan-alcohol flavour, but not overpowering at all, excellent.

Pours a dark brown,with a small brown head.  Big, big bourbon smell that almost mask the vanilla.  Flavor is much the same.  The first thing that hits is the woody bourbon taste followed by vanilla extract.  Then a little sweetness that lends itself to the bitter hoppy finish.  Thanks to ogglethorp for this fine bottle.
Thanks artusory. Reddish brown, moderate to small head, decent lacing and retention. Aroma is vanilla, bourbon, caramel, hints of roast and smoke. Medium bodied, velvety sweet mouthfeel. Nice.

Pours a murky, muddy amber brown color. Starts off with a thin tan head ~1/2 inch thick. No lacing. Heavenly aroma of sweet vanilla Bourbon, chocolate, smoky peat, and rounded out with dry acidic oak. Its definitely a boozy aroma. The flavor is slightly more complex than the aroma, with a dry astringency in addition to the sweet vanilla Bourbon. Sweet butterscotch, oak, and bakers chocolate as well. Slightly thin feel, with some harsh boozy fire midway through.

One of the least shy Bourbon barrel aged beers Ive ever tried. A wonder beer to smell and sip, but can be a bit challenging to finish at times.
Bottle courtesy of styles.  Beautiful pour.  Excellent bourbon, vanilla, and cream nose.  Light, yet full bodied.  Bourbon presence is well defined, yet not overpowering.  Very nice.

UPDATED: APR 8, 2009 Aroma of vanilla, oak, caramel and brown sugar. Like and English Toffee Garden. Taste is about the same. Very rich body and a lot of bourbon flavor. Faint hops and is pretty smooth to drink. Nice overall flavor and not too hot for the alcohol taste.

12 oz bottle, 2007.  Semi-hazy mahogany pour.  The aroma is rich with oak, sweet malt, peat and just plane old inviting goodness.  The flavor has just enough sweetness and does not push that aspect on you.  Lightly smoky, peaty, dryish fruit (prune and date), and wood infused maltiness.  Quite tasty.  Full round body and mouth feel.  A very nice brew.  This was one of Johns favorites in recent memory.

Courtesy hopscotch. This one poured a reddish brown color with a thin white head. The aroma was of sweet malts, a small amount of bourbon, vanilla, caramel, and a hint of hops. The flavor was similar with the bourbon blended in with some cherry, vanilla, oak, caramel, and malts. The bourbon was present all the way through, but it didnt overpower at all. The flavor on this one was great, and just really well balanced. It has a medium body with a creamy mouthfeel that followed with a smooth bourbony finish. I wish i could get more of this stuff, it was really good.

Pours dark copper with a faint head. Aroma is tart bourbon, malts, vanilla, sugars, oak. Im usually not into
bourbon barrel beers but this one is quite nice. Nothing is overdone. Flavor is mild bourbon, maybe some cherry,
vanilla, malts and woody hints. I wish I would have bought more now. Oh well. Nicely done.

12oz Bottle Pours out like a hazy brown syrup topped with a very small off white head. WOW a great aroma of sweet caramel and wood. Tast is great more sweetness and some of that bourbon. This is a very good brew.

Bottles thanks to a couple fine folks!  Poured deep, plummy caramel.. a little on the thicker side, with a nice, but short-lived cap of yellowy-beige head.  The aroma was quite delightful, with hefty doses of barrel influence, but somewhat repressed Scotch Ale.. vanilla and sweet bourbon sugars first and foremost with warm drawn caramel and dark fruits accented by smoke behind.. really enjoyed it!  The flavor had the same caramel and vanilla from the barrel on the sweet core, with rougher oak graininess and sweet bourbon all around the edges.. very sweet overall with good, but not great balance.. sharper bourbon and more vanilla leave quite an impression on the finish.  Medium-bodied or a little thicker on the palate with moderate carbonation.. a little too much barrel influence, and a touch too sharp for my liking on the back.  Overall a very good beer.
12 oz bottle from Styles! Nose of vanilla. caramel, dark fruit, and oak! claer copper with a small beige head; flavor of bourbon, oak caramel, and alcohol. too much bourbon to be really good!

(thanks to irishboy for holding on to this fir me.)nice copper color with no head.mild aroma of brown sugar,oak,bourbon,vanilla,and dark fruit.the flavor is much of the same but the barrel aging comes out a bit more.tasty stuff.

Pours out a nice hazy light to medium brown with a small tan head. Aroma is packed with vanilla, bourbon and oak. Nice mouthfeel with vanilla, bourbon, toasted malt with some earthy notes going on in the background. Finish is of some alcohol and bourbon. Very solid.

Pours caramelly brown colored with a thin yellowish head that dissipates quickly. Smells faintly of vanilla, bourbon and a bit of malt. This is about the "hottest" tasting barrel aged beer that Ive tried. Tons of bourbon, and just plain booze, hit me up front. But as you swallow the flavor of the base brew really comes through. Malty and sweet with that Scotch Ale/Wee Heavy funky, malty, alcohol kick. Palate is good, very good. Nice thick brew with good carbonation. Not a bad beer. Not one of my favorite BA brews but definitely worth a try.

Poured a hazy brown color with a golden tint an almost no head.  Sweet aroma with lots of vanilla, caramel and bourbon.  The flavor is of bourbon and wood.  Some caramel and a touch of vanilla.  Touch of coconut in the aroma.  Medium-full body and smooth mouthfeel.  Some warmth.

12oz. bottle, with thanks to yjb for this excellent bonus!  Pours a clear ruby tinted cola brown, with a moderate choppy tan head, good lacing.  Aroma is charred oak, caramel, toffee and some candied dark fruits, as well as a slight bourbon presence.  Flavor is more of the same, with a gentle sweetness and a bit more bourbon than on the nose.  Overall it was milder than I was expecting, but tasty.  Thanks again Yaniv!

Brown/dark amber with a small, off white head. Nose of rich, burnt caramel, oak, and vanilla. Same flavors with a little bourbon. Not vey complex, expected more. Medium/full body, just smoother than balanced, a bit light for what it is. Good, not great.

12oz - Aroma of bourbon, vanilla and oak.  Pours very dark brown with a small head and decent lacing.  Flavor is primarily bourbon with vanilla, and oak.  The soft chocolate, caramel and toffee from the base brew does come out and rescue this from becoming just another bourbon barrel beer.  Palate is sticky.  Not being a huge fan of bourbon, I was worried at the aroma but happy with the flavor.

Tasted 12/27/07.  12oz bottle.  Murky with a brown hue.  Webbed head.  Woody aromas with notes of raisins and sugary yeast.  Big beer!  Big palate!  Noticeable alcohol.  Full bodied with a woody vanilla oaky flavor.  Sticky sweet with caramel and toffee malt flavors.  Nice burn.  Mild hop finish.  Bitter and sticky.  The barrel aging is good but not overt.  Lingering finish.  Raisin flavors.  Touch bourbon without the burn.  Just enough wood without being obnoxious.  Solid!

UPDATED: JAN 25, 2008 Slightly opaque brownish color with almost no head. Tons of sediment is noticeable when held to light. Aroma is wood, vanilla, and a fair amount of alcohol. Taste up front is also dominated by alcohol and a sweet, almost candi sugar-like sweetness. There is a sort of coca-cola taste going on here it seems also. Oak, nuts,  roasted malt, and then some warming alcohol finish this off. The bourbon really makes it hard to determine what else is going on here at first, but underneath it is a solid stiff beer.

Bottle from Santa.  Poured a deep dark copper color with a short-lived head.  The aroma is bourbon-dominated, with some background malty character and vanilla as well.  The taste is mostly bourbon again atop the heavy maltiness one expects from a Scotch Ale.  A good deal of a nice oakiness in the finish along with some heat.  Melikes the Scotch ale for its simple and earthy display of subtle tastes like malt and peat, and here, these qualities are overpowered by bourbon.  The bourbon flavors mask the Scotch character and therefore the whole point.

Courtesy hopscotch.  Pours a dark caramel brown color.  A small off-white head settles to a wispy film, leaving thin snakes of lacing behind.  The aroma is malty, as a Scotch should be, with a big bourbon overtone, woodsy vanilla, cola and root beer scents.  Im not picking up any of the peat that I expected, but thats no big deal, really.  Wood flavors play a big role here, as the oak bourbon barrels have certainly made their contribution to this brew.  Vanilla plays a big role, as do the massive dark caramel malts.  Not much hop character to this one, but that is expected.  Medium-full, smooth body.  I love bourbon, and I love this beer.  Very solid.  I want more!

Bottle: Brown with ruby accents, moderate light beige head, foamy, a few rings of lacing. &nbsp Strong nose of Bourbon, slightly 

malty, some oak and vanilla. &nbsp Hard to discern much through the Bourbon as it is quite heavy. &nbsp Straight up malty Bourbon on the 

tongue. &nbsp Perhaps very slight campfire or peated malt. &nbsp Everything is overshadowed by the Bourbon. &nbsp Other than it being a 

fairly malt worthy beer, its hard to tell as to what beer it is. &nbsp A bit over the top as far as barrel aging goes. &nbsp Good, as I do 

enjoy Bourbon, but when it dominates the beer its hard to appreciate or even detect the other layers. &nbsp Body and mouthfeel in this case 

are fairly moderate. &nbsp Bourbon and vanilla at the finish, warming, with hints of oak. &nbsp Would be better if I could tell what the 

underlying beer was. &nbsp Thanks for the bottle Chris!

Bottle from Styles yesterday.  I love scotch.  Scotchy scotch scotch.  Poured very cold with little head.  Deep amber color. Sweet buttery malty aroma from the use of melanoiding malts
I presume.  Alcohol just starting to show itself, but difficult to notice, except for maybe a little burn going down.  Low bitterness and blends in with the other flavors.
Thanx to Hopscotch for sharing this.Pours a nice copper color.Yhe nose is sweet, malty with some alcohol.Flavors of wood, caramel,vanilla and slightly sweet.The finish was slightly warming.

Bottle This beer rocks! Mostly clear, deep, dark, ruby ale with a small, creamy, tan head. Decent retention. The rich, decadent aroma is a blend of bourbon, white oak, decadent caramel and chocolate malts with a light waft of smoke and a drop of vanilla. Full-bodied with a slick, oily mouthfeel and lively carbonation. Moderate malt sweetness is well-balanced by sufficient alcohol and hop bitterness. Lots of boozy bourbon with undertones of vanilla, chocolate and light, tangy acidity. Lengthy, moderately bitter and boozy finish. Very warming! Kudos to kmweaver for shipping this beer to me!

Courtesy hopscotch.  Pours a clear copper/amber color, with a light of white head.  Smells of bready yeast, light bourbon, dark malts, and very subtle caramel and vanilla.  The flavor seemed really well balanced.  The bourbon is there, but not overpowering.  very malty, with some light fruit compliments.  Very tasty and well crafted brew.  Balance and flavor were quite nice.
Very nice aroma,tons of vanilla, but I find the flavor to be a bit disjointed and rough around the edges.  The drying, woody aftertaste is my main complaint.

12oz Stubby
$10.00 4-Pack
Sicilianos, Grand Rapids

Backwoods Bastard pours a fairly clear burnt caramel that glows ruby when backlit. There are some tiny suspended particles of protein. A one-plus ecru head rose as I poured and eventually faded to a creamy crown leaving some big sticky patches as I drink.

Sweet caramel and toffee come through nicely in the aroma. Smooth notes of vanilla and oak glide through flawlessly. While there is a touch of smokey bourbon its in the background and only works to compliment the other aromas. This stuff smells exceptional!

Flavor walks right along with the aroma. All the flavors meld seamlessly to create an excellent Wee heavy. Caramel and toffee are the base of this beer but the real highlight is the vanilla and oak from the barrel aging. There is a hint of alcohol in the flavor that wasnt there in the aroma. This knocks down the score a notch.

The body is on the heavier side of medium although feels thick and creamy on the tongue. Velvety smooth as it glides along. Id venture to guess the barrel aging makes the body as velvety as it is.

This beer is very easy to sip. Its cold outside, theres football on tv and this is the beer Id most like to be drinking right now. Hits the spot.

I dont think this needs to be said but this is another great beer from Founders. Theyve really opened things up this year with all the new bottled releases. A great beer from one of the best breweries in the country.

12/16/07
Bottle. Pours reddish brown with a tight head. Taste is cocoa and caramel with a warming alcohol burn. Nice and sweet without being smoky.

12 oz Bottle:  Plum, roasted malt, bourbon, oak. vanilla, and some sugar notes consists the aroma of this brew.  Appearance is an almost opaque dark brown to black with a little light creeping through the actual brew.  Taste is Bourbon big time with later the sweet malt and woody, oak, vanilla, and roast textures peaking through.  Finishes with an almost vanilla ice cream/ shot of whiskey like taste.  Overall, I love this brew. Great tasting and very complex.  Thumbs up to Founders!

Mahogany pour, almost no carbonation. Aroma is bourbon all the way, sweet and vanilla. Flavor is bourbon, oak, vanilla, slight chocolate with some dark fruits also. Big caramel sweetness but not a lot going on other than another barrel-aged beer.

Bottle from iowaherkeye (thanks!).  Pours dark brown with miniscule head.  Aroma of bourbon, vanilla, toffee, maple syrup.  Taste is very malty indeed, with caramel, toffee, and bourbon playing together nicely.  Palate is slightly thick and sticky.  Finishes sweet and slightly alcoholic.  A very well done beer.

12oz bottle. Hazy mahogany with a small head. Aroma was strong bourbon, oak and vanilla with toffee and  brown sugar. Taste was very sweet; just a hint of dried cherries. A bit of warmth. If you like big bourbon beers, its made for you.

12oz bottle, thanks eclectic!  Dark copper, creamy white head.  Rich smoked vanilla nose sits on undercurrents of bourbon, oak, and toffee.  Boozy caramel and vanilla balance on hints of cherry and wood.  Full bodied, soft carbonation, warming, lightly sweet finish.  Founders rarely does wrong.

12oz bottle from BrianK.  Ive been looking forward to this for a while now.  Love Founders, love Scotch Ales.  Cant complain about the correlation of the two.  Pours dark molasses brown with a thin islandy tan head.  The nose is malty and sweet, and has a touch of bourbon and molasses there as well.  Taste is sweet, rich, thick and full of a big bourbony malty feeling.  Overall nice but has a bit of thinness after a while.  Could use a bigger backbone.

Thanks dra19!  The color was deep amber/brown.  The head was thin, off-white, and fizzy.  The aroma was alcohol, brourbon, and sweet malt.  The flavor bourbon, alcohol, sweet malt, and some spice.  The palate was thick-bodied.  The finish was warm and long-lasting.

UPDATED: DEC 14, 2008 Thanks dra19! Excited to get to try this one. Pours a nice ruby brown with no head. Sweet aroma, malty, alcohol, sweet bourbon. The flavor is rich, sweet, alcohol, nice bourbon flavor, obviously present but subdued, malty. Dry warm palate. Nice lasting finish.

12oz. Bottle (SAYS 8.7%ABV):  Malty aroma of smoke, alcohol, bourbon, oak, and coconut.  Poured chestnut brown in color with a tiny beige head that diminished immediately.  Cloudy.  Lots of floating particles of different sizes.  Medium sweet flavor.  Tastes of alcohol, bourbon, chocolate, smoke, tobacco, and copper.  Light to medium body.  Thin, lightly stick texture.  Average carbonation.  Malty, tobacco finish.

UPDATED: FEB 18, 2008 Bottle from Capones, sampled with Stegosaurus. Wow Odd. Amber/brown pour with a spice bourbon aroma.A sweet oak and vanilla flavor was present with a lot more going on. Really good.

12 oz. bottle via trade with DocLock - Pours a reddish-brown color with a half finger thick light tan head.  Faint spotty lacing.  Aroma is bourbon/oak and sweet malt.  Flavor is oak/bourbon, vanilla, and sweet toasted malt.  Alcohol is noticeable but not over bearing.  Medium body.  Smooth with no lingering aftertaste.  An excellent beer.  Thanks Jeff.

Auburnish color pour with small off white head.   Nose big on oak, vanilla, bourbon, brown sugar, syrupy.  Flavors similar with an even bigger vanilla presence.  Very nice bottle, a little sweet but not overly done.

12 oz. bottle.  Big thank you to ogglethorp for sending me this one off my Want list.  Pours a deep, mostly clear, reddish brown with a thin but dense biscuit colored head.  The head faded to a thin film within a couple of minutes.  Very aromatic with oak, bourbon, vanilla and alcohol all noted.  The beer was incredibly flavorful with caramel malt up front follwed by bourbon and vanilla with some hazelnut towards the finish.  Absolutely delicious.  Nice warming alcohol presence at the finish which in no way interferes with the flavor.  Really, really good!

UPDATED: NOV 18, 2013 12oz bottle. Poured a deep reddish brown color with a smaller sized off white head. Aromas of oak, bourbon, vanilla, caramel, light smoke, and some dark fruits. Tastes of wood/oak, caramel, bourbon, some dark fruits, earthy, and vanilla. Definitely woody with some bourbon. Light to medium alcohol fnish.
UPDATED: JAN 19, 2011 Caramel.aroma and taste.  On tap at the iron Abbey for founders beer dinner.  Bourbony aftertaste.

(12oz bottle, thanks eclectic) Small beige head with clear copper body.  Aroma is moderately sweet, grapefruit, Bourbon, smoke, some caramel.  Taste is moderately sweet, grapefruit/orange, caramel, smoke, some alcohol (light burn).  Sticky medium-full body.
This is a fantastic Scotch Ale.  Really reminds you of sipping on either a Scotch or a Bourbon.  I wouldnt hesitate to try this again!  Recommended.

Poured brown with a small creamy tan head that didnt last. Aroma of bourbon, fruit, caramel, and chocolate. Very complex brew with fruit, bourbon, and chocolate. Started off sweet with fruit and some sweet malt. Began to get harsh of bourbon. Finished sweet with some chocolate and caramel hints dancing on your tongue. I would like to see how this brew ages if the alcohol calms down a little bit. Overall really good with the potential of being great.

12oz bottle courtesy of Pailhead: Pours to clear reddish-brown colored body that actually has the color of cola, with a small tan colored head that quickly fades.  The aroma shows some plums, dark fruit, and some light bourbon notes along with some mild charred wood.  Taste shows some bourbon alongside a nice sweetness that seems to come from the malt but shows some vinous ripe grape notes, plums, charred maple, and some earthy, roasted malt notes.  The alcohol comes through along with some bitter fruity hops.  Medium bodied, medium carbonation, Im not always a fan of bourbon-barrel aged beers but the blend of flavors is nice in this one.
very good beer.  IF you like bourbon....even better.  I perfer my bourbon in a shot glass.  thus I wont rate this as high as others might.  But it does have some flavor.

cant believe i forgot to rate this last sat.
on tap at new Founders.  Initial scent was great, smelled of old bourbon and tasted similar.  taste of burned bourbon soaked wood with brown sugar and a little alcohol.  easy sipper, wouldnt want to down it.  nice sticky thick palate.  After the draft I bought the last bottle on tap, and i need to find more :)
LOVED it!

Bottle from Capones - First off, Im a big fan of Bourbon Barrel aging, but not everyone does it right.  Founders gets it - this is one smooth, sweet and delicious BA beer.  Darker reddish-brown color with a light head.  Sweet aroma that has a nice subtle bourbon-woody, vanilla, brown sugar.  Flavor is at the perfect level of bourbon woodiness.  Sugary sweet (mostly brown sugar), vanilla, and a slight bourbony finish.  Tingly mouthfeel that is amazing.  Wow - I was thinking of trading one or two of these, but I will do nothing of the kind.  Really good BA beer that I am so ecstatic to have from a bottle!  Thank you founders for getting this to my local bottle shop!

12 oz bottle shared by BrianK.  Had this also at EBF last year, and I think the bottle is even smoother and better!  Pours a moslty clear medium amber with some woodey hints and a thin off white head.  Aroma is lots of smooth bourbon with vanilla notes, earth, and some tar with lots of smooth malt sweetness- toasty and lightly bready.  Full sweet malt mouthfeel and flavor with a balanced bourbon tone with wood, earth and vanilla to mix in with the full malt sweetness.  No alcohol burn.  Smooth and nice.  Ill seek out more of this next time in PA.

Bottle. Poured a nice ruby red body with thin head. Aroma is oak, vanilla, candied fruit, sweet malt. Flavor had all of the above with a nice smooth sweet malty body. The barrel aging did wonders. I wasnt sure what to expect with when I grabbed this bottle but Founders has hit a homerun with this one.
pours a dark caramel brown, vanilla whisky sweet aroma, smooth and complex palate, very nutty oaky and sticky, very good and smooth, fun to drink.

Bottle. Dark dark ruby brown pour with small tan head. Aroma is very sweet with hints of brown sugar and scotch. Flavor is bourbon, caramel, with hints of butterscotch. Mouthfeel is substantial and very very smooth with subtle carbonation. A truly well-crafted brew.

12oz bottle from Capones (Norristown, PA). poured deep brown with some ruby highlights, with a thin tan head. Aroma of bourbon, brown sugar, malt, wood  and alcohol. Flavor is peat, brown sugar, malt, and bourbon. The barrel aging adds a lot to this beer and compliments the flavors of the original beer. Smooth and delicious, even better than I expected.

Poured from a 12 oz.  Very dark but transparent reddish oak appearance.  Mexican chocolate imbued with cayenne and cinnamon, melted, layers over plum sugar and brighter red fruits in an aroma both lively and dark; hints of graham cracker crust powdering the edges.  Taste reveals lots of charred oak and oceanic scotch malt tones; rich vanilla and caramel in thick milk chocolate mousse.  Fruit flavors in dark cherry pit and currant syrup; nothing too cloying or too crisp.  Pleasantly smooth, erudite, and stunningly composed thickness of palate; while all its dark sweetness could render it either abrasively sugary or slick with alcoholic spirit imitation, it does neither.  Rather it presents itself quietly, and softly, with ease.  Spicy, warming finish with a pulse of bourbon, and a cooling sensation of mint.  Well made.  Thanks for sharing, Ken!

Pours dark bronze with a rich tan head.  The aroma has dark toffee, rich malt, vanilla, bourbon, raisins, dates, oak and caramel.  Medium / full slick body that has a velvety smooth body with lots of soft carbonation.  The flavor starts with heavily toasted dark caramel malt, lush vanilla, bourbon (thankfully not overpowering) and some dark fruits.  The finish adds a bit of spice.  Im not a fan of bourbon barrel beer in general, but this one is done incredibly well.  This is very smooth and easily drinkable.  Big  thumbs up  for this well crafted scotch ale.

Bottle: Pours a transparent dark copper mahogany with a spotty-lacing light tan head.  Aroma of big oaky bourbon with some vanilla and sweet dark caramel malts and a touch of smoky, salty peat.  Body starts dense and sweet with a nice caramel maltiness and earthy peaty character along with bourbon oak and a touch of butterscotch toward a slightly drier warming finish. A pretty good barrel-aged Scotch ale.

Had 12oz bottle Vintage Estates. Pours a brilliant brown. Massive bourbon on the nose with sweet malt and oak. Bourbon taste is massive with peat malt and vanilla oak. Finish has nice oak taste with a slighty sweet smokey back bone. Very nice.

Bottle. Red-brown pour with a short tan head. Aroma of bready caramel malt that is covered in somewhat hot bourbon, some vanilla, light raisin, a bit of wood. Flavors of bourbon, oak, vanilla, dry malt, and a bit of earthy bitterness, dark fruits and a tinge of coconut. Medium/thick body...subdued yet sharp carbonation...boozey/bittersweet/sticky with a boozey/dry/nutty finish. Not bad stuff, but the bourbon really knocks the scotch characteristics to the back of the overall picture. Wouldve like to have had more caramel malt presence and less hot booze.
Tap at Brewery. Poured a very dark wih a redish orange hint to it. Aroma is of bourbon and some scotch. Taste is very in your face with scotch with a chocolate finish.
UPDATED: APR 9, 2008 dark amber with thin white head.  slight spotty lacing.  Big bourbon nose. Sweet malts up front, vanilla and bourbon on the finish.  Thanks to the dankman for this!

Pours a dark maple amber with a medium beige head.  Aroma of bourbon and vanilla.  Taste is dominated by sweet bourbon and vanilla with hints of dark fruit, candied malts and wood.  Another gem from Founders.

12 oz bottle, acquired via trade.  At first, i didnt really care for this.  However, it got exponentially better once it warmed up a bit. Flavor was nice, although I found the oak and bourbon flavors to be rather light. Was kind of surprised to learn that this is a scotch ale, as much of the roasty smokiness I have come to expect from scotch ales seems to be devoid in this beer.  Still, pretty good.   Alcohol was fairly noticeable as well.  My bottle says 8.5%.

12 oz bottle.  Dark purple brown with a thin beige rime.  For some reason the aroma reminded me of a Chunky bar.  Sweet chocolate, peat and bourbon.  Mild carb, medium body.  Hot in the end.  Chocolate covered caramels, dark cherries, but then the bourbon kicks in.  Good beer but i rarely find the bourbon touches to be worthwhile.  and i like bourbon but bourbon+beer?

This was a very overpowering and unbalanced beer in my opinion. I knew this would rate a lot higher than I would. Aroma was strong as death. Smelled just like bourbon. In a blind taste test I would have guessed this was just a glass of bourbon. Pour was a flat murky brown, like sewer water. Tatse was just like carbonated bourbon with hints of wood, dark fruits and a bit of malt. I like bourbon/wood aged beers where there is a hint of it that adds to the beer. This beer is too one dimensional IMO.
user_location: Moon Twp, suburb of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA

text: I was surprised about how good this beer drinks.  I was expecting your standard overpowering oak burbon barrel beer, but the alcohol just seems to be about right.  I downgraded the beer in appearance because it seemed to pour flat.  I felt the aroma was spotty and not as complex as I would like, but that is really where the negatives end for me.  This beer drank smoothly and had a mouthfeel that was thick and creamy.  Slight burbon taste but not overpowering as you can still catch dark fruity notes with wood and dark malt.  I would like a little more of this flavor to offset the burbon a little more but I would still have to say this is the best oak burbon beer Ive ever had.  Good job Founders.  Thanks to Vinnys beer store who gave me this 12oz beauty on the house, check him out in Cleveland.  Pretty solid selection.
Pours brown, with a smallish tan head. Aroma is wood, brown sugar, bourbon, and some dark fruit. Flavor is bourbon, wood, malt, and brown sugar. Very nice, but I think aging will help.

Bottle from Capones.  Deep clear ruby/brownish pour with 1-finger tan head.  Aroma is oaky bourbon, brown sugar, cabernet notes, and some single malt scotchy wafts...very spirity aroma.  Tastes very spirity, with a huge hit of oaky bourbon/scotch, plus some dark malt, hops, and brown sugary notes.  Stays rather hot throughout, and maintains a solid complexity for a beer of this recipe.

I was a little toasted when I drank this, but all i remembered was this--it reminded me of coconut and suntan lotion.  It was interesting enough, but something weird that just bothered me.  Body was creamy, I dont like scotch ales, but I might try this one again and rerate.

DAMN! This was awesome.  Chestnut body under a small tan head.  The Bourbon was first to hit my nose and then the charred wood, toffee, vanilla, chawin tobacci, and sweet malt.  Velvety smooth and rich in the moutn.  The Bourbon dominated the flavor in a wonderful way but was enhanced by the other elements.  Well blended, well crafted beer from one of my favorite breweries.  Only able to get two bottles.  In the words of Oliver, "Please, sir, may I have some more?" And more, and more.

UPDATED: NOV 1, 2008 Poured a lightly hazy, brown amber color with a small, light tan film a top the beer, light lacing on the glass.  Aroma of bourbon, vanilla, roasted malts, and caramel.  Taste of vanilla, toffee, caramel malts, roast, light peat smoke, tobacco, oak, and bourbon in the finish.
UPDATED: FEB 28, 2008 I enjoyed, but tasted nothing but Bourbon---not Scotch. Dark brown color with medium head. Alcohol well hidden.

12 oz stubby bottle.  Pours a dark reddish brown color with a little bit of a tan head.  Aroma is smoke, caramel, brown sugar, bourbon, oak... complex and wonderful.  Taste is also sweet and carmel-y.  Surprisingly little alcohol burn... which really makes it unique among the other bourbon barrel-aged stuff because it has that bourbon flavor but is not reminiscent of drinking actual bourbon. (Nice.)  A little watery in the finish, but still nice, definitely worthwhile.

12oz bottle from a 4-pack.  Pours a muddy, very dark red/brown with a tiny off white head.  Aroma is a very pleasant mix between bourbon, toffee, molasses and carmel. Some alcohol too but Im not turned off. Bourbon is strong yet fits right in and is pretty perfectly integrated I think.  Tastes the same as it smells with some fruitiness, raisins.  Some wood and alcohol.  Mouthfeel is medium, maybe a tiny bit thin.  I like Dirty Bastard but this is on a different level.  Way better than I expected.

Pours a ruby brown in color with no head.  Smell is exactly what youd think, a scotch ale with bourbon, oak, and rum notes.  They must have used the same barrels as for their curmudgeon, this has many of the same characteristics.  Taste is bourbon, oak, and some fig.  The mouthfeel is medium and very smooth/creamy.  This is an easy drinker, but you get a hit of the alcohol warmth in the aftertaste.

UPDATED: MAR 7, 2009 I shouldnt even have to say it anymore, because everyone knows: bottle thanks to miketd.  Poured a deep brown color with a thin, light tan head.  Aroma of bourbon, oak, and even hints of fruit in the aroma.  Very smooth and creamy.  Sweet Caramel malts open the flavor and lead into a slight bourbon hit with undertones of toffee and fruits, with a nice drying oak finish.  Nice beer that I really enjoyed.  Thanks Mike.
Nice beer but it has taken on a little too much of the bourbon barrel essence.  Sweetness and booze dont seem to find a perfect balance with this beer but its not too bad at all.
Good aroma of oak and bourbon.  Pours a very dark red/brown with very little head.  Smooth beer, with just a hint of bourbon that isnt over powering.  Solid brew.

A very nice Scots Ale (and thanks to the fine folks at Crown #15, Fishers, Indiana, for seeking out this stock!).  Pours a very dark, reddish brown, with thin head.  Aroma is malt and spice.  Flavor is the same, but very rich.  Has an almost barley wine quality to it, with noticeable alcohol, but not unpleasantly so.  A very good beer!

Chestnut color with a garnet hue when held to the light. Diminished taupe head with a thin lid adrift atop. Strong aromas of bourbon oak, earthy vanilla, peat, milk chocolate, butterscotch and a hint of alcohol. Very strong bourbon flavors, nearly to the point of shuttering (the shake you get after slamming a shot of bad whiskey). Sweet and fruity in the start, with black cherries and and plums. Middle is full frontal bourbon including the burn that follows. Some hints of toffee on the finish, but my guts are really starting to burn. The bourbon is really overpowering in this one. While I like bourbon, I like beer more and this one is doused with too much booze.

UPDATED: JAN 27, 2008 12oz bottle, no date.  My bottle claims 8.7%.  Clear copper brown with a small beige head, fading to a ring before long.  Nose has plenty of bourbon, vanilla, wood, and brown sugar.  There is some smoky peated malt and toffee as well as some light alcohol.  Flavor is much the same--no surprises.  Lotsa toffee, almost buttery.  Full smooth body, low carbonation.  Very good.  This doesnt quite taste like what I remember at the Great Taste--if I can find my notes, at the Great Taste it was less peaty and I didnt pick up on any bourbon--maybe they gave me the wrong beer.  Notes from GTMW 8/11/07.  Clear reddish brown with a small beige head.  Aroma of light bourbon, light peated malt, and caramel malts.  Flavor was the same with a little bourbon and no peated malt.  Medium body with moderate carbonation.  Good, but not enough peat.-----I dont know if this was the same beer or not, but there is definitely a difference between my two different samples. 7-3-7-3-14--3.4
user_location: Ocean Beach, San Diego, California, USA

text: Bottle.  Sweet aroma, slightly smoky with strong overtones of whiskey [more bourbon, really], a bit of caramel and wood.   Some vanilla.  Richly malty.  Muddled mahogany body with a tanned bubbly head.   Very sweet and lightly bitter taste, faint smoke and bread, slight woody [oaken] smoke carrying through the aftertaste.  Vanilla, faint cherry, blended dark fruits, butterscotch, toasted toffee.  Lots of complex malt here, but also has some alcohol fumes from the whiskey.  Medium body a bit lighter than liked at times, but still to style, and the taste is extremely robust.  Creamy smooth  feel.  Complex and satisfying, well-integrated alcohol but still definitely a sipper.  Really, really good - but can be better!

An almost still, dark brown beer, this has a profoundly oaky nose, with the tannic and uric notes I associate with oak barrel aging over a rather sweet, cookie-like nose. The flavor is quite sweet and a bit chocolatey, almost like a tootsie role. There is certainly a good dose of oak there, but its not offensively tannic, and there are a number of pleasant hints in there as well of tobacco, almonds, and cherry wood smoke. Fantastic.

oaky and vanilla aroma.... slightly bourbon aroma.  Very nice malty aroma... but not overly, just enough to smell yummy.
Taste is initially a creamy bourbon followed by a smooth oak flavor and a slight vanilla extract.  
VERY GOOD.
Very well done.
Fuck.

UPDATED: NOV 2, 2007 12oz, recently bottled. pours clear dense mahogany with small fizzy tan head around the rim. nose is big with vanilla, oak, bourbon, not much else, lots of vanilla. flavor has loads of sweet caramel and bourbon, lots of vanilla here, licorice, slight hint of chocolate. alcohol is well hidden but some sips are harsh and others just warming the throat. the nose and taste leads me to believe it is going to burn but it finishes quite smooth. body is a bit watery, carbonation is surprisingly low, as it looks fizzy at first. in the end the flavor just isnt that complex for a BA beer sort of leaving the palate with a huh, is that it? feeling. tasty though.
This was a good scotch ale but a little overwhelming in the bourbon area.I  like my BA beers but this was a little to bourbany for me.CHEERS!

12oz bottle poured in a shaker.  FBB pours ruby mahogany with little to no head.  It is neither atractive nor ugly.  The nose is mostly bourbon, wood, molasses and an unfortuate reminesce of a bad camping trip involving too much Southern Comfort.  Im not a bourbon fan by any means.  It tastes like bourbon, and thus is not my cup of tea.  I cant fairly rate this beer due to my dislike of bourbon.  The beer seems a bit flat.  Maybe some more hops would be good.  Putting the bourbon aside there is a definite butterscotch taste as well.

UPDATED: DEC 31, 2012 
Date: February 09, 2007
Mode: Draft
Source: Brewfest, Extreme Beer
Vintage: 2007
Appearance: muddy brown
Aroma: rich woody malt aroma
Overall: rich sweet whiskey covers up most everything else, still a bit of the rich malt left to fight through, woody bitterness in the finish

Score: 3.4 to 3.6
Appearance: clear dark ruby red, fine tan head, drippy lace
Aroma: sweet bourbon and vanilla aroma balanced by oak with a hint of the underlying dark caramel malt
Flavor: rich caramel malt flavor with lots of bourbon character, nice vanilla sweetness, earthyness blended with the oaky character, the oak continues to grow and offers lots of balance to the sweet caramel and vanilla

Aroma: sweet dark caramel aroma with lots of oaky earthyness
Flavor: caramel and bourbon sweetness in the flavor is well tempered by the earthyness and oak
Overall: much drier and earthier than the 2008 in a side by side comparision

Flavor: lots of sweet caramel and bourbon flavor, vanilla adds to the sweetness
Overall: much sweeter than the 2007 in a side by side comparision

Translucent with a mahogany amber color and a sudsy tan head thats pocked on top. Pencil shavings and rubber erasures reach the nose shaft first, followed more enthusiastically by bourbon, talc and a chocolate toffee powder composite. Flavor livens up to the bourbon delivery and leaves a fair share to the imagination. Rye and toffee get infused with graham crackers to produce a scotchy substance. Toasted rye flakes, butterscotch and candied pecan pie are spritsed with a little bourbon. Medium-to-fuller bodied and balanced, with a traditionally enjoyable finish of bourbon, butterscotch and rye.

GTMW. My one and only Scotch Ale of the festival, and my this was a treat. My second beer of the day, and only at the Great Taste do you know that even when starting with a beer of this quality, things can only get better for the rest of the festival. Notes of toffee on the nose lead into cinnamon, clove, English toffee, hazelnut, and a touch of orange and chipolte lead into a lasting finish. Excellent stuff, poured by Mr. Stevens himself.

GTMW 07. Poured a slightly hazy, dark orange color. Head was soapy and light tan. Smelled of oak, vanilla, toffee, and a good dash of alcohol. Sweet and very thick on the tongue. Delicious oak, vanilla, and caramel drown out any peated malt flavor that might be hiding in there. Yum.

Great Taste on tap.  Brownish color.  Smell of vanillia, bourbon, coco, malt, hops, nuts, wood and caramel.  Taste of bourbon, oak, vanillia, wood, hops, malt, chcolate, caramel/toffee, nuts, minor smoke and minor fruit.  Very nice and smooth.

MiBGF 07: A beautiful ruby highlight copper hue with a small lasting head.  The aroma has notes of apricot, plum, hazelnut, vanilla, wood, earthy and tobacco esters, and some grassy hops (dry-hopped?). WOW, do I find hops in here? Completely unexpected yet I am digging it! Balanced with a heavy layer of fruity and malty goodness with lots of caramel coming forth. The finish has a bit of a nutty and earthy tone. The mouth feel is smooth and warming with a slight bite upon the finish. This is really a solid brew and different than the basic Bastard, MIKEY LIKEY!

UPDATED: DEC 1, 2007 On tap:  Fruity aroma with some caramel, vanilla, and faint chocolate.  However, Im also getting some piney hops which really seems strange considering the base beer isnt hoppy at all.  Its a transparent orangish-brown with a minimal thin off-white ring for a head.  The flavor starts with moderate caramel and faint chocolate.  Very mild vanilla and bourbon notes in the background.  Again Im getting some unexpected pine notes in the finish.  Medium bodied with a somewhat sticky mouthfeel. 8-3-7-4-14
Bottle:  The aroma consists of caramel, fruit, vanilla, and bourbon.  It pours a transparent reddish-brown with a small beige head.  The flavor starts with moderate caramel and light fruit and finishes with a big bourbon and buttery vanilla finish.  Medium bodied with light carbonation. 7-4-7-4-15

Had many beers at the Indy Micro brew Fest in Broadripple..All I can say is  FOUNDERS,FOUNDERS,FOUNDERS, The chant went up the draft handle tilted open and this delicious treat poured out into my glass..it was the marquee treat from this awesome brewer..The Breakfast stout was equally impressive but this beer was creamy,vanilla,malty,and just made my palate scream for another glass! the bourbon aging which seems to be a great twist with brewers as of late is the  final note that sends this over the top. If you can get it dont hesitate..youll never be the same! effin metal!!!!!!!

Perhaps the 7th or so beer I tried at Indy Brewers Guild Fest.   (palate not burnt out)    Clear reddish amber with a thin tan head.  Just about looks the same as the Dirty Bastard, though perhaps less head retention.  Big sweet caramelly malt over huge vanilla with some oaky goodness. Balanced and lacking any sort of off aromas  (my memory tells me there was some diacetyl present in the nose of the Dirty Bastard).  Smooth creamy feel, a bit viscous, quite nise.  Some alcohol warming and quite sticky (nice combo).    Creamy sweet vanilla.  Oaky malt.  Deep caramel balances the alcohol.  Cherry in the oak makes this a bit fruity which is something the original could use.  A long oaky to vanilla bourbon finish.  I guess you can put any style in a bourbon barrel and get a winner!  (though Ive definitely drank many awful bourbon barrel beers!)
Tried it a few times.  Pretty impressive, never could stand a full pint.  Chocolate bourbon, bitter, smooth.

On tap at Founders.  Dark amber-brown color with quickly dissolving off-white head.  Strong aroma of bourbon, smoke and vanilla. Strong bourbon and alcohol taste.  Great beer once again from Founders!

Rating #1043, on tap at Radio Maria in Champaign while at the Chicago Area May Gathering held in Champaign (Road Trip). Very murky hazy ruby - brown with a thin tan rim of head that is quickly discipating. Looks flat. Nose is super strong of alcohol, sugar, hints of maple and some smoke. Chocolate is present in the nose but the tase is like a kick in the chocolate brownies. Here the oak is strong with vanilla, alcohol and sugar. Oh my this is great.

UPDATED: MAR 20, 2013 3/20/13 re:rate: less hard to find these days. What is clearly bourbon in the nose comes across as chocolate and caramel. very enticing aroma without any hint of strength. Nearly opaque body with floatilas and a very thin ring of head. very undercarbonated, almost to the point of being flat. Quite enjoyable but im a bit underwhelmed compared to my first foray with this brew. 5/6/07: Growler courtesy of FooFaa at Dark Lord Day 2007. Creamy, bourbon aroma more reminiscent of an imp. stout than a scotch ale. Dark amber body with a yellowish, tan head. Very nice bourbon barrel aspect. Butterscotch and caramel notes. Excellent. Thanks Dan for hooking me up with a hard to find brew from one of my favorite breweries. 9,4,9,5,18

Sampled from a growler thanks to Schutzenliesel.  Very hot nose, straight bourbon whiskey and oak, very faint nose of maple and caramel, the typical scotch-ale qualities.  Yellowish almost glowing green tinted tan head.  Nose is werid crackers and vegetables mixed with the boozy bourbon as it warms.  Flavor is sharp and sweet bourbon creame and cheese even.  Creamy up front, vaporous all over... with flavors on the back of sweet tobacco, sugary caramel, the sweetness well detatched from the boozy alcohol flavors.  Unique and interesting.

Growler, courtesy of Schutzenliesel.  Thanks, Tom!  Pours a clear, dark amber-brown color; light tan head with light retention.  Strong, bourbony and boozy aroma; coconut and vanilla notes.  Full mouthfeel: plenty of sweet bourbon (coconut and vanilla); chewy malt character; nice, complex bourbon presence.  Lengthy, bourbon and sour-mash finish.  Potent stuff!

Founders found a way to improve upon perfection...age their great Scotch ale in a bourbon barrel.   Huge sweet nose...caramel and toffee...along with molasses, smoke, oak, vanilla and bourbon.  All of this hinting towards a really substantial brew.   Big hit of bourbon upfront, riding on a wave of smoke and darkly roasted malt sweetness, with some really complex sweet notes underneath, like dates and plums.   So very nicely brewed!

What a Bourbon barrel aged beer should be, carrying all of the qualities of its orginal brew with a smooth blending of both the liquors and the barrels characteristics.  Not great looking, but the aroma more than makes up for it - toffee, caramel, vanilla, oak, smoke, dark fruits, and Bourbon, of course.  Smooth and creamy in the mouth, all flavors represented in the nose are there skillfully blended into a warming, satisfying drink.<font size=-4><a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/events-detail.asp?eve Lord Day 2007 at Three Floyds, Munster, IN, 4/28/2007.<font size=-1>

thanks to the wandering fella from toronto who poured this for me from his growler.  it was really fantastic.  there was a lot of barrel character in the nose, but the most astounding part was how balanced and seamless the flavor was.  a huge improvement over the very good dirty bastard.  i probably thought it would be listed as a strong ale, but now that i think it about it, scotch ale works.  probably the best scotch ale ive ever had, except maybe BA wee heavy.  there was alcohol here, sure, but it was warming and,like i said, balanced well with the vanilla/sweetmalt/caramel flavors.

Much thanks to FooFaa for opening this growler up at DL Day 07.  Pours a lightly hazy brownish amber with a medium creamy light tan head that left some nice lacing.  Aroma had a lot of vanilla, oak, dark fruits, caramel and bourbon.  Flavor was also a lot of vanilla, bourbon and oak, caramel, dark fruits, very rich yet smooth.  Very nice glad I got to give this one a try and spend some time with it while waiting for some Dark Lord.
had this on tap at the brewpub.  very dark/thick beer.  alchol taste is there but not over powering.  went down real smooth

on tap at founders ale house in GR, this is one dark and strong beer. strong aroma of roasty malt, theres some fruit and a faint alcohol smell after that, alcohol is evident in the flavor but does not overpower, and finishes with a more smooth than bitter feel.

Pours a thin brown with a red hue.  Smells of roasted malt, then something that smells like pineapple, maybe vanilla mixed with bourbon.  You can taste the bourbon more then you can smell it.  It is very sweet and malty but finishes smooth yet bitter as it warms you.

UPDATED: SEP 29, 2009 Tap from the brewery...i tried to get a growler of this for takehome but they turned me down!....appearance was very cola like with a a very thin head that disappeared rather quickly...nose was very pronounced in from the bourbon barrels which i though was nice.  also had some vanilla and caramel as well.....taste was consistent to the aroma which comprised of equal parts malt, bourbon, and caramely goodness....i liked this one alot and only wish i had some to take home.
bottled versions just havent quite lived up to what was originally on draft.

Growler from Founders.  This beer is awesome!  Very beautiful to look at.  Dark reddish/brownish body with a little bit of lasting foam on top.  Color looks a little bit like a very dark high quality maple syrup.  Aromas of vanilla, oak, bourbon, maybe a little bit of fruit.  Tastes also of bourbon, oak, sweet malts, brown sugar.  This beer starts sweet but finishes very bitter and acidic, which is really nice.  The bourbon is really prominent on this beer, but it works really well with the style.  Love this stuff

Tap @ Founders. Murky brown body with no head. The aroma is sweet oak, cherry, dark fruits and toffee. The flavor is vanilla, plum skins, some black cherry, toffee, light sweetness. Medium body, dense carbonation, with a bitter, tannic finish. Nicely done.

Got this from Sephiroth who went to the brewery.  He brought this back in a growler.  Dark garnet in color....absolutely beautiful.  Caramel, vanilla, and bourbon on the nose.  Smooth from start to finish with a pleasant finish that lasts and lasts.  The palate shows chocolate, caramel, roasted malts, and vanilla.  Beautiful and a wonderful brew for the night. Check the color against a bright light from under the glass.

From the tap, sampled in a snifter.

Poured a dark, deep blackish brown with a nice foamy, creamy head, just a tasty looking appearance.

Aromas of roasted grains, chocolate, caramel, smoky peat, the alcohol meshes with the bourbon barrel vanilla, and dark fruity esters.

Good, smooth moderate carbonation and a malty crisp, dryish, slick, velvety full bodied mouthfeel.

Delicious roasted malt taste, chocolate, butterscotch toffee, a nice soft smoky peat, raisin fruitiness, vanilla and molasses, towards the end the bourbon barrel flavors combines with the alcohol to provide a smooth warmth in the back of the palate, and a dry roasted malty finish.

An exceptional smooth sipper, the taste coats the mouth and makes you want more and more, one of the best brews Ive tasted from Founders, a must try.

UPDATED: FEB 25, 2008 Draft at 2007 MBG winter fest.  Deep dark brown color, with small diminishing head.  Flavor is bourbon, some dark fruits, caramel and malt, peat, picks up hints of vanilla from the barrel.  big and tasty.  Would like to try this one again.   Ive heard rumors that they might bottle this, would definitely like to see how it ages.

Re rate.  Tried this out of the bottle and it was incredibly woody.  Not nearly as good.  first time: 4.4
Last time 3.9
Strong aroma of bourbon.  Tastes of bourbon and vanilla.  Strong taste and very smooth.

Draft at 2007 Michigan BGWF. Poured dark brown color with a moderate light brown head that diminished slowly with good lacing.  Good caramel toasted malt aroma. Medium  to full body with a smooth texture. Good well balanced bourbon and tart fruit malty flavor with a moderate smooth balanced finish of moderate duration. Good brew.

MI BG Winter Fest.   Pours a hazy ruby tinted brown color with a thin off white head.   Aroma is bourbon, oak, sweet amlts, caramel.   Flavor is peat, bourbon, sweet malt, hint of oak, vanilla, toffee, dried fruit.   Palate is medium bodied, mildly carbonated, sweet silky smooth finish.   Wonderful stuff, one of the best of the fest!

On Tap at a special tapping at Landmark In Milwuakee.Aroma was somewhat subtle,dark Scottish carmels and just a touch of the whiskey, wow,nothing subtle about the taste,big bold smooth sweet bourbon,mixed with carmel,toffee, and hints of dark fruit, the silky palate is wonderful. As good as any barrel aged Ive had

On tap at the brewery. Deep ruddy orange-brown body, medium tan head. Potent aroma with sweet caramels, dark fruit, oak, and hot alcohol. Dense, heavy body with strong barrel flavors, but not overwhelming the malt slurry. Reminded me of a caramel apple in a way, or an apple cider on steroids. Heavy toasts and caramel, touches of smoke too. Sharp alcohol notes, too. We have a winner.

EBF 2007: Hazy deep amber in color not much head. Aroma, dark fruits, some molasses, a bit peaty, not much of the barrel on the aroma. Flavor, sweet, with some heat on it, oak, some caramel, and a fruitiness to it. It wasnt bad, but I dont think it holds a candle to that other barrel aged brew that they have.

EBF 2007 - another bourbon-aged beer from Founders?  sure, why not - and this one actually turned out pretty well - unlike many bourbon-aged beers, this one isnt as sweet and boozy (unlike the previous rating - maybe I am wrong, but this was only the third beer I had that night) - the barrel adds a nice compliment to the smokey flavors already present in the beer, combining with the bourbon and malt to make the beer taste similar to very peaty scotch at times - some plum and other dark fruit at the back end - very well-executed.

UPDATED: FEB 20, 2007 this is a oak-aged version of their Dirty Bastard...on tap at the brewery...deep chesnut body with minimal head...nice oaky/bourbon aroma, large in caramels and spicy hops...flavor is very similar to the aroma, and is a tad too boozy (heavy in the bourbon, heavy in the sugars)...could use a little less aging or a little less bourbon additive (whatever is the case)...outside of that, this was very good; another good one from Founders
